column5:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Other countries have different approaches, including granting access to data to private sector companies or decentralizing access and storage. Different types of sharing economies and frameworks provide various opportunities, but also raise questions about the ethical usage of data and its reuse in research and development (see, for example, Courbier et al. (2019), who provide an overview on risks and potentials as well as recommendations for sharing and protecting health data). Open access to data might undermine participants’ trust that their data are handled with care. In this scenario, readiness to provide data or to take part in studies might be limited. A model of full commercialization of data might have similar effects for studies and surveys that see patients and participants only as data bonanzas. On the other hand, commercialization and privately driven research and development will ultimately provide better medical devices and treatments, in spite of all reservations. Even a public approach or emphasis on public value is not the answer to all
### Input: What are the potential ethical concerns and benefits associated with different approaches to data access and commercialization in the context of health research and development?
### Response: The text suggests that different approaches to data access and commercialization in the context of health research and development can raise ethical concerns about the usage and reuse of data. For instance, open access to data might undermine participants' trust in how their data is handled, potentially limiting their willingness to provide data or participate in studies. Similarly, a model of full commercialization of data might view patients and participants merely as sources of data, which could also affect their participation. However, the text also suggests that commercialization and privately driven research and development could ultimately lead to better medical devices and treatments, despite these ethical concerns. The text implies that a public approach or emphasis on public value might not resolve all these issues.

column3: Experimenting with Open Innovation in Science (OIS) practices:  A novel approach to co-developing research proposals 49 questions. The study of Courbier et al. (2019) shows that the majority of rare disease patients are willing to share their data in the hopes that this will help to develop new treatments, improve diagnosis, and better understand causes and mechanisms of the disease. Thus restrictive data sharing rules might also cause patients and participants to re-think their attitudes towards sharing data when therapeutic progress and health care improvements are not happening fast enough (see Foege et al. (2019) for similar issues in crowdsourcing).

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Experimenting with Open Innovation in Science (OIS) practices:  A novel approach to co-developing research proposals 49 questions. The study of Courbier et al. (2019) shows that the majority of rare disease patients are willing to share their data in the hopes that this will help to develop new treatments, improve diagnosis, and better understand causes and mechanisms of the disease. Thus restrictive data sharing rules might also cause patients and participants to re-think their attitudes towards sharing data when therapeutic progress and health care improvements are not happening fast enough (see Foege et al. (2019) for similar issues in crowdsourcing). 
### Input: What impact might restrictive data sharing rules have on patients' willingness to share their data, particularly in the context of slow therapeutic progress and health care improvements?
### Response: The text suggests that restrictive data sharing rules might cause patients to re-think their attitudes towards sharing data, particularly if therapeutic progress and health care improvements are not happening fast enough. This implies that patients might become less willing to share their data under such circumstances.

column3: In the practice of conducting clinical trials, financial remuneration for participants might be an additional motivating factor for taking part in studies. In general, remuneration is primarily intended to compensate participants for working time, traveling, invested resources, etc. (see for example the 2019 Guideline from the European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations (EFPIA 2019) on “Working together with patients”). This is typically a one-time payment though. A second approach to encouraging data sharing is to provide prioritized access to medical technology or therapies (when available) for individual patients and participants who previously shared data for the study. But it might also raise ethical concerns if access to scarce technology or therapies is not primarily based on the medical needs of the patients.
column4: 2023 - Experimenting with Open Innovation in Science (OIS
column5:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: In the practice of conducting clinical trials, financial remuneration for participants might be an additional motivating factor for taking part in studies. In general, remuneration is primarily intended to compensate participants for working time, traveling, invested resources, etc. (see for example the 2019 Guideline from the European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations (EFPIA 2019) on “Working together with patients”). This is typically a one-time payment though. A second approach to encouraging data sharing is to provide prioritized access to medical technology or therapies (when available) for individual patients and participants who previously shared data for the study. But it might also raise ethical concerns if access to scarce technology or therapies is not primarily based on the medical needs of the patients. 
### Input: What ethical concerns might arise if access to scarce medical technology or therapies is given based on participation in clinical trials rather than the medical needs of the patients?
### Response: The text suggests that ethical concerns might arise if access to scarce medical technology or therapies is given based on participation in clinical trials rather than the medical needs of the patients because it could potentially prioritize those who have participated in trials over those who may have a greater medical need. This could lead to an unfair distribution of resources, potentially disadvantaging those who are in greater need but have not participated in clinical trials.

column3: In practice there are limits to both the methods of efficient data collection and to the motivation that financial incentives can provide to patients and participants. Patients who are ready to contribute receive a reward that is primarily non-monetary (beyond remuneration). In addition, they contribute to research projects that are risky and could fail and therefore might not even be rewarded at all. At the same time, patients are deeply emotionally connected to the specific research project they seek to contribute to. These factors contribute to the same power and knowledge asymmetry between patients and health companies that exists between patients and public health care providers. A flexible, transparent model for a “Fair Share” or return value for the input of patients, participants, and other actors involved is necessary in these times of proliferating health care and medical data.

Text: In practice there are limits to both the methods of efficient data collection and to the motivation that financial incentives can provide to patients and participants. Patients who are ready to contribute receive a reward that is primarily non-monetary (beyond remuneration). In addition, they contribute to research projects that are risky and could fail and therefore might not even be rewarded at all. At the same time, patients are deeply emotionally connected to the specific research project they seek to contribute to. These factors contribute to the same power and knowledge asymmetry between patients and health companies that exists between patients and public health care providers. A flexible, transparent model for a “Fair Share” or return value for the input of patients, participants, and other actors involved is necessary in these times of proliferating health care and medical data.  
### Input: What kind of flexible, transparent model could be developed to ensure a "Fair Share" or return value for the input of patients, participants, and other actors involved in health care and medical data research?
### Response: The text does not provide specific information on what kind of flexible, transparent model could be developed to ensure a "Fair Share" or return value for the input of patients, participants, and other actors involved in health care and medical data research.

column3: Building on this, our research questions are descriptive and explanatory: First, we seek to investigate which models of value distribution currently exist between patients, researchers, universities, and companies, how they are used, and in which context. Second, we seek to understand how particular arrangements for the distribution of value are associated with individual sharing behavior. Third, we aim to define the main design principles of a novel model of flexible and transparent value distribution among every stakeholder that is participating (also with their data) in the co-development effort.

Text: Building on this, our research questions are descriptive and explanatory: First, we seek to investigate which models of value distribution currently exist between patients, researchers, universities, and companies, how they are used, and in which context. Second, we seek to understand how particular arrangements for the distribution of value are associated with individual sharing behavior. Third, we aim to define the main design principles of a novel model of flexible and transparent value distribution among every stakeholder that is participating (also with their data) in the co-development effort.

column3: How can the research question be answered? In order to address our first research question, we propose conducting multiple case studies in different settings with various stakeholders, including patients and patient organizations, company representatives, hospital personnel, and scientists. Via observations and interviews, we want to identify how value is distributed between the different actors and how they capture value under different conditions in different contexts. Building on the findings from the case studies and in order to shed more light on our second research question aiming to identify under which conditions individuals engage in sharing behaviour, we propose an experimental research design. Thereby we can test the effects of different conditions - e.g., increased transparency - on the data sharing behaviour of patients and the willingness of companies to make more ethical decisions and share more of their returns with patients. Moreover, scenario-based experiments could be helpful in order to elucidate the conditions under which patients would be willing to share their data. Answers to the descriptive and explanatory research questions will then also inform considerations regarding the normative aspects of patient data sharing. For example, we might gain insights into how the opportunistic behavior of companies vis-à-vis patients can be avoided and what the “right” model of value distribution should be. Moreover, we might learn what considerations of fairness should be made with respect to who benefits from the research.

Text: How can the research question be answered? In order to address our first research question, we propose conducting multiple case studies in different settings with various stakeholders, including patients and patient organizations, company representatives, hospital personnel, and scientists. Via observations and interviews, we want to identify how value is distributed between the different actors and how they capture value under different conditions in different contexts. Building on the findings from the case studies and in order to shed more light on our second research question aiming to identify under which conditions individuals engage in sharing behaviour, we propose an experimental research design. Thereby we can test the effects of different conditions - e.g., increased transparency - on the data sharing behaviour of patients and the willingness of companies to make more ethical decisions and share more of their returns with patients. Moreover, scenario-based experiments could be helpful in order to elucidate the conditions under which patients would be willing to share their data. Answers to the descriptive and explanatory research questions will then also inform considerations regarding the normative aspects of patient data sharing. For example, we might gain insights into how the opportunistic behavior of companies vis-à-vis patients can be avoided and what the “right” model of value distribution should be. Moreover, we might learn what considerations of fairness should be made with respect to who benefits from the research. 
### Input: What research methods can be used to understand the distribution of value in patient data sharing and under what conditions individuals are willing to engage in this behavior?
### Response: The research methods that can be used to understand the distribution of value in patient data sharing and under what conditions individuals are willing to engage in this behavior include conducting multiple case studies in different settings with various stakeholders and an experimental research design. The case studies would involve observations and interviews to identify how value is distributed between different actors and how they capture value under different conditions. The experimental research design would test the effects of different conditions on the data sharing behavior of patients and the willingness of companies to make more ethical decisions. Scenario-based experiments could also be used to elucidate the conditions under which patients would be willing to share their data.

Text: We are currently  conducting studies to examine the extent to which such human/AI ensembles may give purpose to  imperfect ML models as an intermediate practicable step toward fully automated solutions. Our  workshop sought to motivate and communicate this approach via three talks followed by a Hybrid AI  simulation game, in which workshop participants broke out into teams to design hybrid AI  architectures that employ CrowdBots for existing and imagined citizen science scenarios.
### Input: What is the purpose of using human/AI ensembles in imperfect ML models and how was this approach communicated in the workshop through talks and a Hybrid AI simulation game?
### Response: The purpose of using human/AI ensembles in imperfect ML models is to provide a practicable intermediate step towards fully automated solutions. This approach was communicated in the workshop through three talks that aimed to motivate and explain this method. Following the talks, a Hybrid AI simulation game was conducted. In this game, participants formed teams to design hybrid AI architectures that use CrowdBots for existing and imagined citizen science scenarios, further illustrating the concept.

column3: 1. Introduction Hybrid intelligence represents the collaboration of humans and machines, where artificial intelligence (AI) is augmenting human skills and creativity in order to achieve complex goals. Instead of replacing humans with AI, this technique leverages complementary strengths and learning reciprocity between humans and machines. As hybrid intelligence may take many forms, it was the topic of a recent workshop where people that are engaged in citizen science projects in various capacities have come together to model and innovate the design of hybrid intelligence systems. The teams were provided with a set of concepts to work with and had the liberty of representing an existing hybrid process or creating a new model, for example one that introduces hybrid intelligence to an existing crowdsourcing system. This report summarizes the workshop talks, activities, and outcomes.

Text: 1. Introduction Hybrid intelligence represents the collaboration of humans and machines, where artificial intelligence (AI) is augmenting human skills and creativity in order to achieve complex goals. Instead of replacing humans with AI, this technique leverages complementary strengths and learning reciprocity between humans and machines. As hybrid intelligence may take many forms, it was the topic of a recent workshop where people that are engaged in citizen science projects in various capacities have come together to model and innovate the design of hybrid intelligence systems. The teams were provided with a set of concepts to work with and had the liberty of representing an existing hybrid process or creating a new model, for example one that introduces hybrid intelligence to an existing crowdsourcing system. This report summarizes the workshop talks, activities, and outcomes.
### Input: What is hybrid intelligence and how was it explored in a recent workshop involving citizen science projects?
### Response: Hybrid intelligence is the collaboration of humans and machines, where artificial intelligence augments human skills and creativity to achieve complex goals. It leverages the complementary strengths and learning reciprocity between humans and machines. In a recent workshop involving citizen science projects, hybrid intelligence was explored by bringing together individuals engaged in various capacities. They were tasked with modeling and innovating the design of hybrid intelligence systems. The teams were given a set of concepts to work with and could either represent an existing hybrid process or create a new model, such as introducing hybrid intelligence to an existing crowdsourcing system.

column3: 2. Challenges and opportunities with artificial intelligence in biomedical research In a talk by Jennifer Couch, Branch Chief in the Division of Cancer Biology at NIH, we learned that recent technological advances have led to exciting and promising new applications of artificial intelligence in biomedical research. Still, there are a lot of challenges when applying artificial intelligence to biomedical research. For example, some AI tools used by researchers were not developed specifically for biomedical data, so their design is often missing key elements for a successful application. Another important challenge in this field is the limited interpretability of AI models. Being able to understand the decision making process of an intelligent algorithm is valuable in building trust and gaining novel biological insights.

Still, there are a lot of challenges when applying artificial intelligence to biomedical research. For example, some AI tools used by researchers were not developed specifically for biomedical data, so their design is often missing key elements for a successful application. Another important challenge in this field is the limited interpretability of AI models. Being able to understand the decision making process of an intelligent algorithm is valuable in building trust and gaining novel biological insights.
### Input: What are some of the challenges faced when applying artificial intelligence to biomedical research according to Jennifer Couch, Branch Chief in the Division of Cancer Biology at NIH?
### Response: According to Jennifer Couch, some of the challenges faced when applying artificial intelligence to biomedical research include the fact that some AI tools used by researchers were not developed specifically for biomedical data, so their design often lacks key elements for successful application. Another significant challenge is the limited interpretability of AI models, which makes it difficult to understand the decision-making process of an intelligent algorithm. This is important for building trust and gaining novel biological insights.

### Response: The study found evidence of racial bias in the commercial health management system in the form of black patients being deemed healthier than equally sick white patients. column3: 4. On the flip side, interpretable machine learning models can provide valuable insights to researchers. For example, [2] developed a machine learning model able to predict the metastatic efficiency of a melanoma cell by capturing very subtle properties, impossible to identify by human experts. The interpretable nature of the model allowed for visual validation of the amplified cellular features used for prediction, revealing functional hallmarks of highly metastatic melanoma.

### Response: The researchers were able to gain insights into the very subtle properties of a melanoma cell that could predict its metastatic efficiency. The interpretable nature of the model also allowed for visual validation of the amplified cellular features used for prediction, revealing functional hallmarks of highly metastatic melanoma.

Hybrid intelligence In a talk by Jacob Sherson, Director of the Center for Hybrid Intelligence at Aarhus University, we were presented with the current state of AI development in the industry and were introduced to the concept of hybrid intelligence. Although machine learning models can achieve state-of-the-art performance in the lab, they often fail in real world settings. According to a study performed by [3], there are many obstacles when trying to integrate AI in organizations and 70% of AI projects generate little impact. There are also risks posed by AI operating autonomously, with humans out of the loop. Bias in the training data could lead to bias amplification, relying on AI to.
### Input: What are some of the challenges and risks associated with integrating AI in organizations, as discussed by Jacob Sherson, Director of the Center for Hybrid Intelligence at Aarhus University?
### Response: The challenges associated with integrating AI in organizations, as discussed by Jacob Sherson, include the fact that machine learning models, despite achieving state-of-the-art performance in labs, often fail in real-world settings. A study cited in his talk found that 70% of AI projects generate little impact when integrated into organizations. The risks associated with AI integration include the potential for AI to operate autonomously, with humans out of the loop. This could lead to bias amplification if there is bias in the training data.

column3: PoS(CitSci2022)122 PoS(CitSci2022)122Exploring CrowdBots make decisions could lead to the deskilling of humans, and training black-box systems could potentially lead to value misalignment. As opposed to having AI be completely disruptive, in human-centered AI [4] it can be used as a tool for human augmentation. This means pursuing simultaneously high degrees of automation and also human control, with the goal of having reliable, safe and trustworthy systems. Hybrid intelligence is a variety of human computation that stipulates optimal human-AI synergies that are focused on mutual learning, with the user continuously learning from the machine, and the machine being augmented in parallel.

column3: 4.CrowdBots Stall Catchers1 is a citizen science project that accelerates data analysis to help understand why there is reduced brain blood flow in Alzheimer’s disease patients. In mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease, about 2% of the brain capillaries are stalled, causing a 30% overall reduction in brain blood flow. This is consistent with what is observed in human patients. Restoring blood flow in these mice restores memories and reduces other cognitive symptoms. [5]

column3: Due to painstaking manual analysis required for the brain imagery in these studies, it would take between 6 and 12 months to answer one research question in the lab. Therefore, this image analysis represents a great opportunity for crowdsourcing. With over 45,000 registered participants, and 50-100 human volunteers analyzing data every day, analyzing a complete dataset can now be accomplished in only 1 or 2 months without loss of data quality.

Text: Due to painstaking manual analysis required for the brain imagery in these studies, it would take between 6 and 12 months to answer one research question in the lab. Therefore, this image analysis represents a great opportunity for crowdsourcing. With over 45,000 registered participants, and 50-100 human volunteers analyzing data every day, analyzing a complete dataset can now be accomplished in only 1 or 2 months without loss of data quality.
### Input: What is the impact of crowdsourcing on the time required to analyze a complete dataset in brain imagery studies?
### Response: Crowdsourcing significantly reduces the time required to analyze a complete dataset in brain imagery studies. Instead of taking 6 to 12 months, it can now be accomplished in only 1 or 2 months.

column3: The Stall Catchers platform allows participants to watch short clips of blood vessels in mouse brains and search for clogged capillaries where blood has stopped flowing, also known as stalls. Each player has a score and may compete on the leaderboard with the other players or teams. Playing Stall Catchers accelerates Alzheimer’s disease research. Since the crowd answers exceed 99% sensitivity and 95% specificity, they are considered reliable in discriminating flowing and stalled blood vessels. On average, a reliable crowd score is obtained by combining seven separate annotations from different volunteers about the same vessel segment.

column5:

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: The Stall Catchers platform allows participants to watch short clips of blood vessels in mouse brains and search for clogged capillaries where blood has stopped flowing, also known as stalls. Each player has a score and may compete on the leaderboard with the other players or teams. Playing Stall Catchers accelerates Alzheimer’s disease research. Since the crowd answers exceed 99% sensitivity and 95% specificity, they are considered reliable in discriminating flowing and stalled blood vessels. On average, a reliable crowd score is obtained by combining seven separate annotations from different volunteers about the same vessel segment.
### Input: What is the purpose of the Stall Catchers platform and how does it contribute to Alzheimer's disease research?
### Response: The purpose of the Stall Catchers platform is to allow participants to watch short clips of blood vessels in mouse brains and search for clogged capillaries where blood has stopped flowing, also known as stalls. It contributes to Alzheimer's disease research by accelerating the process. The crowd answers obtained from the platform are considered reliable in discriminating flowing and stalled blood vessels, with a sensitivity exceeding 99% and specificity of 95%. This reliable crowd score is obtained by combining seven separate annotations from different volunteers about the same vessel segment.

column3: Over 45,000 Stall Catchers volunteers have contributed over 12 million classification labels for this biomedical research application. Bespoke "wisdom of the crowd" methods, which effectively create ensemble models out of humans, combined multiple individual labels for the same input to produce 1.5 million research grade labels. These gold standard data were used by over 900 participants in a machine learning competition to train 55 unique models exhibiting a range of performance characteristics. Though none of these models produces research grade labels, the sensitivity and bias distributions of these models are similar to those of individual human volunteers, suggesting the models’ suitability for crowd-based participation.

### Response: The similarity in sensitivity and bias distributions between the models and human volunteers suggests that the models are suitable for crowd-based participation in the Stall Catchers biomedical research application.

This time, instead of limiting the study to a 24-hour event, the bots and humans annotated an entire dataset that was previously analyzed only by humans. They became active on October 6th, 2021, and were stopped a bit under a month later, when each bot had analyzed all vessel segments exactly once.

### Response: The duration of the study in which the bots ZFTurbo and Clsc2 participated in Stall Catchers was a bit under a month. They started their activity on October 6th, 2021, and stopped when each bot had analyzed all vessel segments exactly once, which was a bit under a month later.

column3: 5.3 Galaxy Zoo Galaxy Zoo 3is an astronomy project which invites people to assist in the morphological classification of large numbers of galaxies. In Galaxy Zoo, participants classify images of galaxies according to a series of questions. Some questions are approachable with minimal domain knowledge (e.g., “Does this galaxy have spiral arms?”), while others benefit from experience (e.g., “Is there anything odd?”). The research team developed a Bayesian DNN able to learn to classify images of galaxies from volunteers’ responses. They also use this modeltoselectonlythemostchallenginggalaxiestopredictforlabelingbyvolunteers,which allows them to fine-tune models with the smallest and most informative set of labeled data. In this process, humans are annotating data in order to train the AI to solve the task and the AI decideswhichnewdatais mostuseful,as shownin Figure3.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: 5.3 Galaxy Zoo Galaxy Zoo 3is an astronomy project which invites people to assist in the morphological classification of large numbers of galaxies. In Galaxy Zoo, participants classify images of galaxies according to a series of questions. Some questions are approachable with minimal domain knowledge (e.g., “Does this galaxy have spiral arms?”), while others benefit from experience (e.g., “Is there anything odd?”). The research team developed a Bayesian DNN able to learn to classify images of galaxies from volunteers’ responses. They also use this modeltoselectonlythemostchallenginggalaxiestopredictforlabelingbyvolunteers,which allows them to fine-tune models with the smallest and most informative set of labeled data. In this process, humans are annotating data in order to train the AI to solve the task and the AI decideswhichnewdatais mostuseful,as shownin Figure3.
### Input: What is the role of volunteers in the Galaxy Zoo project and how does the Bayesian DNN utilize their input?
### Response: In the Galaxy Zoo project, volunteers play the role of classifying images of galaxies according to a series of questions. Their responses are used to train a Bayesian Deep Neural Network (DNN) to classify images of galaxies. The Bayesian DNN utilizes the volunteers' input by learning from their responses. It is also used to select only the most challenging galaxies to predict for labeling by the volunteers. This allows the research team to fine-tune models with the smallest and most informative set of labeled data. In essence, the volunteers are annotating data to train the AI, and the AI decides which new data is most useful based on their input.

Museum visitors (the crowd)inputtheirnon-expertsearchqueriesontheplatform. Forexample,avisitormightinputthe following terms for their art interests: "happy", "family", "farm", "blue", "sunny". Each visitor’s search informs an algorithm and machine learning process. This process includes data from a computervisionprogramthatconductsimageanalysisofthemuseumartcollection. ### Input: What is the purpose of the hybrid intelligence process brainstormed by CrowdBots Table 1 for a museum's digital art catalog?
### Response: The purpose of the hybrid intelligence process brainstormed by CrowdBots Table 1 for a museum's digital art catalog is to improve the customer search experience. This is achieved by using visitor's non-expert search queries to inform an algorithm and machine learning process, which includes data from a computer vision program that conducts image analysis of the museum art collection. The software then returns images matching the queries and presents visitors with a list of art recommendations. This could serve as a personalization program where the museum's AI technology learns visitors' specific art tastes and interpretations.

column3: 6.2 Team 2 Figure 5: Team 2 process model. Table 2 illustrated the diagram from Figure 5 which presents a creativity project where partic- ipants are asked to create as many different dog-like figures as possible out of ten possible blocks. Afterwards, these dog depictions were evaluated based on appropriateness, flexibility, fluency, orig- inality, and elaboration. When evaluated only by experts, there was a lot of individual bias. When the analysis was conducted by a machine using a clustering method, the results were not actually meaningful. Crowdsourcing the evaluation could result in more opinions and less bias.

column3: Hybrid Intelligence approaches achieve futuristic AI capabilities today by seeking out information processing stages where AI struggles, and inserting human cognition into the loop. Researchers and practitioners are accustomed to separately applying AI methods or crowd- sourcing to problem-solving. Our goal with this workshop was to inspire the combined use of these approaches toward achieving new capabilities, and to orient researchers to the possibility of using such methods to tackle new issues.

Researchers and practitioners are accustomed to separately applying AI methods or crowd- sourcing to problem-solving. Our goal with this workshop was to inspire the combined use of these approaches toward achieving new capabilities, and to orient researchers to the possibility of using such methods to tackle new issues. 
### Input: What is the main goal of using Hybrid Intelligence approaches in AI research and problem-solving?
### Response: The main goal of using Hybrid Intelligence approaches in AI research and problem-solving is to achieve futuristic AI capabilities today by identifying stages where AI struggles and incorporating human cognition into the process. This combined use of AI methods and crowdsourcing aims to achieve new capabilities and tackle new issues.

column3: Creativity assessment games and crowdsourcing Janet F. Rafner Aarhus University, Aarhus, Denmark janetrafner@mgmt.au.dk ABSTRACT Digital games used to assess creativity represents an emerging but underexplored topic. These games could allow for the combination of scalability through crowdsourcing and potentially higher ecological testing using fine-grained data acquisition from more natural settings. This development could also provide a promising a testbed for exploring human-AI creativity. However, success both in the design and implementation phases hinges on the games being both valid instruments for measuring creativity as well as engaging enough for the general public to want to play. This paper presents my initial PhD work focused on designing CREA: a suite of freely accessible digital games and tasks to understand and assess creativity. First I describe the CREA games and tasks, then discuss my considerations and challenges for operationalizing creativity within the games, present initial participant feedback, and discuss future work.

Text: Creativity assessment games and crowdsourcing Janet F. Rafner Aarhus University, Aarhus, Denmark janetrafner@mgmt.au.dk ABSTRACT Digital games used to assess creativity represents an emerging but underexplored topic. These games could allow for the combination of scalability through crowdsourcing and potentially higher ecological testing using fine-grained data acquisition from more natural settings. This development could also provide a promising a testbed for exploring human-AI creativity. However, success both in the design and implementation phases hinges on the games being both valid instruments for measuring creativity as well as engaging enough for the general public to want to play. This paper presents my initial PhD work focused on designing CREA: a suite of freely accessible digital games and tasks to understand and assess creativity. First I describe the CREA games and tasks, then discuss my considerations and challenges for operationalizing creativity within the games, present initial participant feedback, and discuss future work.
### Input: What are the potential benefits and challenges of using digital games like CREA to assess creativity, and what has been the initial participant feedback on this approach?
### Response: The potential benefits of using digital games like CREA to assess creativity include scalability through crowdsourcing and potentially higher ecological testing using fine-grained data acquisition from more natural settings. It could also provide a promising testbed for exploring human-AI creativity. The challenges include ensuring the games are valid instruments for measuring creativity and making them engaging enough for the general public to want to play. The initial participant feedback on this approach is not mentioned in the text.

column3: 1 INTRODUCTION Digital, game-based creativity assessments are fruitful yet underexplored grounds in HCI research and thus this work is very relevant for the Creativity and Cognition community. Over the past ten years, only a handful of digital games have attempted to assess creativity [ 1–11] using stealth assessment1. Like the majority of 1Stealth Assessment is a methodology used to systematically analyze and assess elements of complex processes “that can evolve into creative solutions” [ 4], embedded in technology-rich environments (e.g., digital games). In stealth assessment, the player’s in-game actions are continually logged, while the participant is immersed in the activity, without being constantly attuned to the assessment.

Text: 1 INTRODUCTION Digital, game-based creativity assessments are fruitful yet underexplored grounds in HCI research and thus this work is very relevant for the Creativity and Cognition community. Over the past ten years, only a handful of digital games have attempted to assess creativity [ 1–11] using stealth assessment1. Like the majority of 1Stealth Assessment is a methodology used to systematically analyze and assess elements of complex processes “that can evolve into creative solutions” [ 4], embedded in technology-rich environments (e.g., digital games). In stealth assessment, the player’s in-game actions are continually logged, while the participant is immersed in the activity, without being constantly attuned to the assessment.
### Input: What is stealth assessment in the context of digital game-based creativity assessments?
### Response: Stealth assessment in the context of digital game-based creativity assessments is a methodology used to systematically analyze and assess elements of complex processes that can evolve into creative solutions. This is done in technology-rich environments like digital games where the player's in-game actions are continually logged. The participant is immersed in the activity without being constantly aware of the assessment.

C&C ’21, June 22, 23, 2021, Virtual Event, Italy ©2021 Copyright held by the owner/author(s). ACM ISBN 978-1-4503-8376-9/21/06. https://doi.org/10.1145/3450741.3467465psychometric creativity assessment instruments, these games focus on assessing two essential processes of creative thinking, conceptualized by Guilford [ 21]: divergent and convergent thinking. Divergent thinking (DT) is defined as the ability to come up with many different solutions to a prompt, whereas convergent thinking (CT) is defined as the ability to find the single best solution to a defined question [ 21]. Although Guilford drew attention to and acknowledged the importance of both processes, creativity quickly became equated with DT, leading to the majority of assessment instruments focusing on measuring DT [ 22]. These instruments often operationalize DT following Guilford’s [ 23] proposal, in terms of ideational fluency (the number of outputs: ideas, products, solutions), flexibility (how different the proposed outputs are from each other), originality (how unique an output is), and elaboration (the level of details in an output).

Divergent thinking (DT) is defined as the ability to come up with many different solutions to a prompt, whereas convergent thinking (CT) is defined as the ability to find the single best solution to a defined question [ 21]. Although Guilford drew attention to and acknowledged the importance of both processes, creativity quickly became equated with DT, leading to the majority of assessment instruments focusing on measuring DT [ 22]. These instruments often operationalize DT following Guilford’s [ 23] proposal, in terms of ideational fluency (the number of outputs: ideas, products, solutions), flexibility (how different the proposed outputs are from each other), originality (how unique an output is), and elaboration (the level of details in an output).
### Input: What are the two essential processes of creative thinking conceptualized by Guilford and how are they defined?
### Response: The two essential processes of creative thinking conceptualized by Guilford are divergent thinking and convergent thinking. Divergent thinking is defined as the ability to come up with many different solutions to a prompt, whereas convergent thinking is defined as the ability to find the single best solution to a defined question.

column3: Game-based creativity assessment has many benefits in contrast to traditional tests. For example, gamified environments capture more casual and natural behavior than traditional tests, potentially mitigating unintended physiological effects, such as test anxiety, or researcher effect. Digital games also afford the ability to capture detailed, fine-grained steps in an individual’s trajectory towards an output [ 11]. Given their accessibility, appeal and prevalence in peoples’ everyday lives [ 30], digital games could allow for broader sampling (engaging many demographic groups), possibly leading to reliable predictions at the individual level (through validation of demographically fine-grained models). Digital games are more motivating than standardized tests [ 19]. Intrinsic motivation can induce a ‘flow state’ enhancing concentration on the task-at-hand. This state can be achieved when people have clear goals, immediate feedback, and a balance between challenges and skills [ 31]. Being in the flow-state fosters creativity [ 31], affording a great opportunity for assessment. Additionally, digital games enable higher engagement levels, allowing for longer interactions and multifaceted testing. This is necessary to elicit and assess both creative processes and products, without inducing testing fatigue especially when responding to a recent call for the adoption of comprehensive portfolio-based approaches in creativity assessment [ 20].

Text: Game-based creativity assessment has many benefits in contrast to traditional tests. For example, gamified environments capture more casual and natural behavior than traditional tests, potentially mitigating unintended physiological effects, such as test anxiety, or researcher effect. Digital games also afford the ability to capture detailed, fine-grained steps in an individual’s trajectory towards an output [ 11]. Given their accessibility, appeal and prevalence in peoples’ everyday lives [ 30], digital games could allow for broader sampling (engaging many demographic groups), possibly leading to reliable predictions at the individual level (through validation of demographically fine-grained models). Digital games are more motivating than standardized tests [ 19]. Intrinsic motivation can induce a ‘flow state’ enhancing concentration on the task-at-hand. This state can be achieved when people have clear goals, immediate feedback, and a balance between challenges and skills [ 31]. Being in the flow-state fosters creativity [ 31], affording a great opportunity for assessment. Additionally, digital games enable higher engagement levels, allowing for longer interactions and multifaceted testing. This is necessary to elicit and assess both creative processes and products, without inducing testing fatigue especially when responding to a recent call for the adoption of comprehensive portfolio-based approaches in creativity assessment [ 20].
### Input: What are the benefits of using game-based creativity assessment over traditional tests?
### Response: The benefits of using game-based creativity assessment over traditional tests include capturing more casual and natural behavior, potentially reducing test anxiety or researcher effect. Digital games can capture detailed steps in an individual’s creative process. They are accessible, appealing, and prevalent, allowing for broader demographic sampling and possibly leading to reliable individual predictions. Digital games are more motivating than standardized tests, which can induce a 'flow state' that enhances concentration and fosters creativity. They also enable higher engagement levels, allowing for longer interactions and multifaceted testing, which is necessary to assess both creative processes and products without inducing testing fatigue.

column3: However, to the best of my knowledge, no projects thus far have brought together several games and tests into one suite. The possibility of such a digital approach could also allow for assessment of human-algorithmic creativity. Therefore, in my doctoral studies I have led the design and development of CREA: a game-based creativity assessment portfolio which attempts to explore both of these aspects. CREA is a digital, freely accessible combination of innovative creativity games and tests to assess and explore creativity and other cognitive functions. My goal with the project is to reveal insights into creativity and its underlying constructs, and to scope the feasibility of using digital tests and games for large scale psychometric assessment purposes. In this research, I draw on knowledge from the fields of

column3: 2 CREA GAME DESIGN CREA contains two games, crea.tiles and crea.blender, as well as two tests, crea.ideas and crea.logic. for the remainder of the paper I will refer to them as just tiles,ideas ,logic and blender . Initial versions of tiles, ideas and logic can be played here: we- bgl.scienceathome.org/crea. Tiles and blender have three key modes, designed to assess CT, DT, or creativity (defined as novelty and value) [ 32]. Each mode in the CREA games assesses creativ- ity through self-assessment, crowdsourced peer assessment, and stealth assessment, while logic and ideas are digital versions of traditional tests using peer and automatic assessment.

Text: 2 CREA GAME DESIGN CREA contains two games, crea.tiles and crea.blender, as well as two tests, crea.ideas and crea.logic. for the remainder of the paper I will refer to them as just tiles,ideas ,logic and blender . Initial versions of tiles, ideas and logic can be played here: we- bgl.scienceathome.org/crea. Tiles and blender have three key modes, designed to assess CT, DT, or creativity (defined as novelty and value) [ 32]. Each mode in the CREA games assesses creativ- ity through self-assessment, crowdsourced peer assessment, and stealth assessment, while logic and ideas are digital versions of traditional tests using peer and automatic assessment. 
### Input: What are the three key modes designed to assess in the CREA games Tiles and Blender?
### Response: The three key modes designed to assess in the CREA games Tiles and Blender are CT (Computational Thinking), DT (Design Thinking), and creativity (defined as novelty and value).

column3: 2.1 TILES Tiles consists of 10 tiles that can be moved around one at a time. The player must place a tile in an empty spot adjacent to the edge of another tile. However, the shape must always be continuous so they can only move tiles at the edges of the shape so that any other tile does not end up ‘by itself’ (Fig 1, left). tiles is based on the Creative Foraging game [ 11–13], which was designed to study creative exploration processes. In tiles, players complete a tutorial which introduces them to the basic game mechanics and features then proceed through the three modes. The DT mode has three levels. Players are instructed to create and save at least five different digit/dog/animal-like shapes within 4 minutes for each level. At the end of each level, the participants can see the shapes they have saved in their personal gallery (Fig 1, middle). After completing three tasks, players view two shapes at a time, which are randomly selected from the database of submitted shapes, and are asked to rate on a five point likert-scale how similar the two shapes are. They are required to rate at least five pairs before progressing to the next mode. In the CT mode players are presented with a targetfigure and four possible starting figures (Fig 1, right). The objective is to select the best starting shape and rearrange it into the target shape in the fewest possible number of steps. There is only one best choice. Participants have 30 seconds to choose a starting shape and one minute to recreate the target shape. Players must solve 6 challenges with increasing difficulty (two easy, two medium, and two hard). In the free play mode players are instructed to make ‘the most creative shapes you can think of’ and to ‘save at least 5 different shapes’ with in 4 minutes. Players are then instructed to pick the three shapes they think are most creative from their saved shapes. After that, they are shown pairs of figures side by side and are asked to pick the more creative one.

column3: 2.2 BLENDER Inblender , players blend multiple images together in order to get new, interesting compositions. How “much” each image should contribute to the resulting picture is up to the player: each image’s weight can be adjusted using a slider next to each image. blender uses a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) [ 14] which is the most widely used type of ML models for image generation [ 15,16]. Before studying if blender can be used as a creativity assessment tool, I first had to determine that players could express control over the interface and the algorithm [ 1]. Inblender , players first complete a tutorial which introduces them to the basic game mechanics and features. They then proceed through the three modes. In the DT mode players are presented with five images and are asked to create and save as many different "animal-like" creatures as possible in four minutes (Fig 2, left) and save at least three images. After completing the tasks, players are asked to rate on a five-point Likert scale how similar two images are. In the CT mode players are presented with a target image and three sets of three source images. Only one set can produce the exact target image, and players’ objective is first to determine which set was used to create the target image (up to 30 seconds) (Fig 2, right), and then to recreate their closest approximation of the target image (up to three min). There are three levels in this mode. The pilot study [ 1] revealed that it can be very frustrating for players if they have selected the incorrect set and are forced to spend three minutes attempting to create an unattainable solution. Therefore, participants are allowed to end the question early by clicking “I think I choose the wrong set. ” Additionally, there is now a threshold for how close participants should get to the target image values for it to be considered a match to prevent participants from spending excess time fine tuning their images. In free play

### Response: The purpose of the DT mode in the game Inblender is for players to create and save as many different "animal-like" creatures as possible in four minutes. They are presented with five images and are required to save at least three images.

column3: 2.3 IDEAS Ideas is a digital version of Guilford’s Alternate Uses Test [ 24] which asks participants to come up with alternative/unusual uses of everyday objects, such as a brick, or a pencil, and it is one of the most common standardized tests for DT. Players are instructed with, “List as many alternative uses for the object shown as you can before time runs out. Responses must be in English.” Players are given two minutes to complete the task, which was chosen in accordance with typical times for the alternative use test. After the players finish the task, they are presented with ideas of other players, and asked whether they can imagine using the given object in the suggested ways. If they think a use is imaginable, they are asked to indicate how unusual this use would be, on a scale of “completely normal”, “a bit unusual”, and “very alternative”.
column4: Rafner - 2021 - Creativity assessment games and crowdsourcing

Text: 2.3 IDEAS Ideas is a digital version of Guilford’s Alternate Uses Test [ 24] which asks participants to come up with alternative/unusual uses of everyday objects, such as a brick, or a pencil, and it is one of the most common standardized tests for DT. Players are instructed with, “List as many alternative uses for the object shown as you can before time runs out. Responses must be in English.” Players are given two minutes to complete the task, which was chosen in accordance with typical times for the alternative use test. After the players finish the task, they are presented with ideas of other players, and asked whether they can imagine using the given object in the suggested ways. If they think a use is imaginable, they are asked to indicate how unusual this use would be, on a scale of “completely normal”, “a bit unusual”, and “very alternative”.
### Input: What is the IDEAS digital version of Guilford’s Alternate Uses Test and how is it conducted?
### Response: The IDEAS digital version of Guilford’s Alternate Uses Test is a game that asks participants to come up with alternative or unusual uses for everyday objects, such as a brick or a pencil. The game is conducted by instructing players to list as many alternative uses for the object shown as they can before time runs out, with a time limit of two minutes. The responses must be in English. After the task is completed, players are shown the ideas of other players and asked whether they can imagine using the given object in the suggested ways. If they think a use is imaginable, they are asked to indicate how unusual this use would be, on a scale of “completely normal”, “a bit unusual”, and “very alternative”.

column3: 2.4 LOGIC Logic is a tool for assessing abstract reasoning: one’s ability to solve a task without primary knowledge and a base mechanism of human learning, also related to cognitive functions involving processing speed and working memory [ 28]. Previous research suggests that creativity and various aspects of general intelligence, including abstract reasoning are in fact correlated [ 27].logic is built with items from the matrix reasoning item bank (MaRs-IB), Figure 4: logic : An example of a simple matrix with only one relational change: color (right). An example of a complex item containing more relational changes: position, color and shape (left). which contains 80 sets of items in total [ 25]. MaRs-IB was created to potentially serve as a free alternative to the classical abstract reasoning test, the Raven Progressive Matrices [ 26]. Players are presented with three-by-three matrices containing abstract shapes in each cell except for one, and they have to choose the missing one by figuring out the relationships across the provided shapes The items can vary in colour, size, position and shape and the combination of these, and the matrices vary in difficulty based on the amount of dimensions changing. Players have 8 minutes to solve as many puzzles as they can.

Previous research suggests that creativity and various aspects of general intelligence, including abstract reasoning are in fact correlated [ 27].logic is built with items from the matrix reasoning item bank (MaRs-IB), Figure 4: logic : An example of a simple matrix with only one relational change: color (right). An example of a complex item containing more relational changes: position, color and shape (left). which contains 80 sets of items in total [ 25]. MaRs-IB was created to potentially serve as a free alternative to the classical abstract reasoning test, the Raven Progressive Matrices [ 26]. Players are presented with three-by-three matrices containing abstract shapes in each cell except for one, and they have to choose the missing one by figuring out the relationships across the provided shapes The items can vary in colour, size, position and shape and the combination of these, and the matrices vary in difficulty based on the amount of dimensions changing. Players have 8 minutes to solve as many puzzles as they can.
### Input: What is the purpose of the logic tool in assessing abstract reasoning and how is it related to human cognitive functions?
### Response: The purpose of the logic tool in assessing abstract reasoning is to evaluate one's ability to solve a task without primary knowledge. It serves as a base mechanism of human learning. It is related to human cognitive functions as it involves processing speed and working memory.

column3: 3 OPERATIONALIZATION OF CT AND DT For both tilesandblender , I have put in substantial effort determin- ing the metrics for fluency, flexibility and originality in the DT mode. Fluency is the most straightforward and is defined as the number of appropriate solutions submitted. However, even ‘appropriateness’ is difficult to operationalize. Are all submitted shapes appropriate to the prompt? I am considering an additional rating question where participants are presented with submitted figures/images and asked to rate if they feel the items are appropriate to the prompt, similar to how in ideas , players are asked to indicate how unusual the uses are.

Fluency is the most straightforward and is defined as the number of appropriate solutions submitted. However, even ‘appropriateness’ is difficult to operationalize. Are all submitted shapes appropriate to the prompt? I am considering an additional rating question where participants are presented with submitted figures/images and asked to rate if they feel the items are appropriate to the prompt, similar to how in ideas , players are asked to indicate how unusual the uses are. 
### Input: What methods were used to determine the metrics for fluency, flexibility, and originality in the DT mode?
### Response: The text does not provide specific methods used to determine the metrics for fluency, flexibility, and originality in the DT mode. However, it mentions that the author put in substantial effort to determine these metrics and is considering an additional rating question where participants are presented with submitted figures/images and asked to rate if they feel the items are appropriate to the prompt.

column3: For analysis, clustering techniques will be employed but much experimentation is still needed. To test convergent validity2of the DT modes, results will be compared to ideas as it is a digital version of an accepted standardized test. However, in ideas I must first decide on how to combine semantic algorithms [ 33] and human ratings to operationalize flexibility, fluency and originality. For example, the semantic algorithm has been trained to identify gibberish such as “asje” and not to count it as an ‘appropriate’ answer. Additionally, as previously mentioned, to the best of my knowledge, crowdsourcing assessment has never been tried in previous creativity assessment games. Therefore, I welcome advice as to the level of expertise the participants should be able to demonstrate before they rate images.

column3: For the CT modes, it is not straightforward to determine difficulty levels for the questions. For an initial trial I chose sets for blender andtiles based on my own judgements on perceived difficulty, which were then agreed upon by the consortium. For tiles, easy categories of starting shapes having distances to the correct solutions of (1,3,3,3), (2,3,3,3) and (2,5,5,5); medium has distances of (3,5,5,5), (4,6,6,6) and (3,4,5,6) and hard (5,7,7,7), (4,5,5,5) and (4,5,5,6). The first number in the series is the distance to the target from the correct solution and following three numbers are the distances to the target from the incorrect solutions. Participants are scored on ifthey select the correct starting figure and the number of steps itactually takes them to reach the target.

Text: For the CT modes, it is not straightforward to determine difficulty levels for the questions. For an initial trial I chose sets for blender andtiles based on my own judgements on perceived difficulty, which were then agreed upon by the consortium. For tiles, easy categories of starting shapes having distances to the correct solutions of (1,3,3,3), (2,3,3,3) and (2,5,5,5); medium has distances of (3,5,5,5), (4,6,6,6) and (3,4,5,6) and hard (5,7,7,7), (4,5,5,5) and (4,5,5,6). The first number in the series is the distance to the target from the correct solution and following three numbers are the distances to the target from the incorrect solutions. Participants are scored on ifthey select the correct starting figure and the number of steps itactually takes them to reach the target. 
### Input: Based on the text, what factors determine the difficulty level of the questions in the CT modes for blender and tiles?
### Response: The difficulty level of the questions in the CT modes for blender and tiles is determined by the distances to the correct solutions from the starting shapes and the incorrect solutions. The first number in the series is the distance to the target from the correct solution and the following three numbers are the distances to the target from the incorrect solutions.

column3: For blender, I choose the images based on the shapes and colors of the source image sets and the target images. If the correct set visually looked closer to the target than alternatives they were put in the easy category; if all sets had similar components to the target set, they were put in the hard category. The appropriate level of difficulty is important as tasks that are too easy would taint construct validity and lead to ceiling effect, and tasks too hard would frustrate players, possibly causing them to leave. I welcome advice on balancing methodological stringency with optimal support of player engagement. In later stages, convergent validity of the CT mode will be measured by comparing to the Remote Association Test [ 35] which I hope to also later include in CREA.

Text: For blender, I choose the images based on the shapes and colors of the source image sets and the target images. If the correct set visually looked closer to the target than alternatives they were put in the easy category; if all sets had similar components to the target set, they were put in the hard category. The appropriate level of difficulty is important as tasks that are too easy would taint construct validity and lead to ceiling effect, and tasks too hard would frustrate players, possibly causing them to leave. I welcome advice on balancing methodological stringency with optimal support of player engagement. In later stages, convergent validity of the CT mode will be measured by comparing to the Remote Association Test [ 35] which I hope to also later include in CREA. 
### Input: What factors are considered when choosing images for the blender in the game, and why is the appropriate level of difficulty important?
### Response: The factors considered when choosing images for the blender in the game include the shapes and colors of the source image sets and the target images. The images are chosen based on how closely they visually resemble the target. The appropriate level of difficulty is important because tasks that are too easy could taint construct validity and lead to a ceiling effect, while tasks that are too hard could frustrate players and potentially cause them to leave the game. Balancing methodological stringency with optimal support of player engagement is crucial.

column3: 4 INITIAL DESIGN FEEDBACK AND LEVEL OF GAMIFICATION Initial testing was done with three interns, two of whom were first-time users and one was part of the development team. The feedback sessions were held individually over Zoom, and recorded for further analysis. In each session, the participant shared their screen while interacting with the interface and encouraged to speak out loud while playing. The sessions revealed that the timer feature was not prominent enough and that participants wanted more in-game feedback about their performance. I am not sure how much 2Convergent validity is a type of construct validity, which refers to the extent to which two tests that theoretically should be related, are in fact correlated [29].in game feedback should be provided as it is essential to keep the game engaging enough for it to be ‘fun’ enough for the general public to want to play but also stay true to the fact that it is a creativity assessment portfolio.

Text: 4 INITIAL DESIGN FEEDBACK AND LEVEL OF GAMIFICATION Initial testing was done with three interns, two of whom were first-time users and one was part of the development team. The feedback sessions were held individually over Zoom, and recorded for further analysis. In each session, the participant shared their screen while interacting with the interface and encouraged to speak out loud while playing. The sessions revealed that the timer feature was not prominent enough and that participants wanted more in-game feedback about their performance. I am not sure how much 2Convergent validity is a type of construct validity, which refers to the extent to which two tests that theoretically should be related, are in fact correlated [29].in game feedback should be provided as it is essential to keep the game engaging enough for it to be ‘fun’ enough for the general public to want to play but also stay true to the fact that it is a creativity assessment portfolio. 
### Input: What changes were suggested by the initial testers regarding the timer feature and in-game feedback in the creativity assessment portfolio game?
### Response: The initial testers suggested that the timer feature should be made more prominent and that more in-game feedback about their performance should be provided.

column3: Additionally, several play-through sessions and discussions were held to discuss research questions and instructions. In particular I had a difficult time deciding whether or not to use the word “creativity” in the task instructions. 5 FUTURE WORK Initial data collection for tiles,logic and ideas will take place in April 2021 with 20 students. I, supported by the consortium, will then perform exploratory data analysis and iterate on the above mentioned considerations. Once the suite has been developed and validated, I would like to apply it in real world contexts where we can for example compare the performance of novice and expert designers. In later iterations of the suite, I would also like to test different GANs in blender , and incorporating other games such as the OpenCreativity App [34].

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Additionally, several play-through sessions and discussions were held to discuss research questions and instructions. In particular I had a difficult time deciding whether or not to use the word “creativity” in the task instructions. 5 FUTURE WORK Initial data collection for tiles,logic and ideas will take place in April 2021 with 20 students. I, supported by the consortium, will then perform exploratory data analysis and iterate on the above mentioned considerations. Once the suite has been developed and validated, I would like to apply it in real world contexts where we can for example compare the performance of novice and expert designers. In later iterations of the suite, I would also like to test different GANs in blender , and incorporating other games such as the OpenCreativity App [34]. 
### Input: What are the future plans for the data collection and analysis for this project, and how does the author plan to apply the developed suite in real-world contexts?
### Response: The future plans for data collection and analysis for this project involve initial data collection for tiles, logic, and ideas in April 2021 with 20 students. The author, with the support of the consortium, will then perform exploratory data analysis and iterate on the considerations mentioned in the text. The author plans to apply the developed suite in real-world contexts by comparing the performance of novice and expert designers. In later iterations of the suite, the author also plans to test different Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) in Blender and incorporate other games such as the OpenCreativity App.

column3: Digital Games for Creativity Assessment: Strengths, Weaknesses and  Opportunities Janet Rafner a, Michael Mose Biskjæra, Blanka Zanaa, Steven Langsforda, Carsten Bergenholtza,  Seyedahmad Rahimib, Andrea Carugatia, Lior Noyc, and Jacob Sherson a aAarhus University; bUniversity of Florida; cBusiness Administration, Ono Academic College ABSTRACT Creativity assessments should be valid, reliable, and scalable to support various stakeholders (e.g.,  policy-makers, educators, corporations, and the general public) in their decision-making processes.  Established initiatives toward scalable creativity assessments have relied on well-studied standar - dized tests. Although robust in many ways, most of these tests adopt unnatural and unmotivating  environments for expression of creativity, mainly observe coarse-grained snippets of the creative  process, and rely on subjective, resource-intensive, human-expert evaluations. This article presents  a literature review of game-based creativity assessment and discusses how digital games can  potentially address the limitations of traditional testing. Based on an original sample of 127 papers,  this article contributes an in-depth review of 16 papers on 11 digital creativity assessment games.  Despite the relatively small sample, a wide variety of design decisions are covered. Major findings  and recommendations include identifying (1) a disconnect between the potential of scaling up  assessment of creativity with the use of digital games, and the actual reach achieved in the  examined studies (2) the need for complementary methods such as stealth assessment, algorithmic  support and crowdsourcing when designing creativity assessment games, and (3) a need for  interdisciplinary dialogs to produce, validate and implement creativity assessment games at scale.

Established initiatives toward scalable creativity assessments have relied on well-studied standar - dized tests. Although robust in many ways, most of these tests adopt unnatural and unmotivating  environments for expression of creativity, mainly observe coarse-grained snippets of the creative  process, and rely on subjective, resource-intensive, human-expert evaluations. column3: Introduction Calls for valid (accurate), and reliable (consistent) meth - ods for assessing creativity can be traced back to  Guilford’s (1950 ) presidential address to the members of  the American Psychological Association (APA). This call  is accentuated in the introduction to the 2019 special issue  of Philosophy, Esthetics, Creativity and the Arts,  “Creativity Assessment: pitfalls, solutions and standards,”  where the editors assert: “Without proper instruments to  measure creativity or adequate standards of assessment,  the validity of any creativity study is seriously questioned”  (Barbot & Reiter-Palmon, 2019 ).

Text: Introduction Calls for valid (accurate), and reliable (consistent) meth - ods for assessing creativity can be traced back to  Guilford’s (1950 ) presidential address to the members of  the American Psychological Association (APA). This call  is accentuated in the introduction to the 2019 special issue  of Philosophy, Esthetics, Creativity and the Arts,  “Creativity Assessment: pitfalls, solutions and standards,”  where the editors assert: “Without proper instruments to  measure creativity or adequate standards of assessment,  the validity of any creativity study is seriously questioned”  (Barbot & Reiter-Palmon, 2019 ). 
### Input: What is the importance of valid and reliable methods for assessing creativity as emphasized by Guilford and the editors of the 2019 special issue of Philosophy, Esthetics, Creativity and the Arts?
### Response: The importance of valid and reliable methods for assessing creativity, as emphasized by Guilford and the editors of the 2019 special issue of Philosophy, Esthetics, Creativity and the Arts, is that without proper instruments to measure creativity or adequate standards of assessment, the validity of any creativity study is seriously questioned. This means that the results of a study may not be trustworthy or accurate if the methods used to assess creativity are not valid and reliable.

column3: Recently, organizations  such as the OECD (Schleicher, n.d) and the World  Economic Forum (Belsky, 2020 ; Grey, 2016 ; Future of  Jobs Report, 2020 ) underscored the importance of 21st  century skills like creativity for meeting the requirements  of an increasingly globalized and digitized world. Calls  from these major public institutions triggered an immi - nent need for large-scale assessments and training of these  skills, both in corporate and educational sectors. As  a student, worker or work-seeker, employer, or govern - mental agency, the assessment of one’s own skill or those  of others is paramount for upward mobility and appro - priate job placement (Indeed Editorial Team, 2021 ; Stuart, 2009 ; Zojceska, 2019 ). Thus, ensuring the accessibility of  assessment mechanisms, such as through freely available  online platforms, for creativity and other 21st century  skills, becomes crucial for an equitable society. That  being said, it can be futile or even harmful to scale-up  and provide easy access to invalid or unreliable assess - ment instruments as is the case with the burgeoning  number of apps that promise to evaluate creativity yet  lack a solid theoretical foundation.

### Input: What is the importance of valid and reliable assessment mechanisms for creativity and other 21st century skills in ensuring an equitable society?
### Response: The text suggests that valid and reliable assessment mechanisms for creativity and other 21st century skills are important in ensuring an equitable society because they are paramount for upward mobility and appropriate job placement. These assessments allow individuals, whether they are students, workers, employers, or governmental agencies, to understand their own skills or those of others. This understanding can then be used to ensure that individuals are placed in roles that suit their skills, promoting fairness and equality. Furthermore, the accessibility of these assessment mechanisms, such as through freely available online platforms, is crucial in ensuring that everyone, regardless of their circumstances, has the opportunity to assess and improve their skills. However, the text warns that it can be harmful to scale-up and provide easy access to invalid or unreliable assessment instruments, as they may provide inaccurate results and lead to inappropriate job placements or missed opportunities for skill development.

column3: Over the past decades, standardized tests targeting  creative processes (e.g., idea generation and refinement)  have been developed and successfully deployed in a wide  range of contexts (Keefe & Magaro, 1980 ; Kühn et al.,  2014 ; Lau & Cheung, 2010 ; Maheshwari & Werd, 2019 ;  Matud, Rodríguez, & Grande, 2007 ; Torrance, 1976 ). The  simple and domain-agnostic design of the tasks in these  tests allows for large-scale, albeit resource intensive,  deployment. However, these same design choices are  criticized for not being motivational and/or for not map - ping well onto real-world creativity (i.e., lacking ecological  validity1; discussed later).

column3: This paper investigates how digital games can be used to assess creativity at scale, while achieving psychometric validity and reliability. This investigation is done by means of a systematic literature review, outlining several key design, implementation, and analysis decisions relevant for creating and evaluating digital games which assess creativity. The paper’s primary vision for creativity assessment is to explore ways of meeting the challenge of scaling up to large and diverse sample sizes while capturing data with higher ecological validity and gleaning deeper insights into construct validity of creativity. This paper aims to provide: ●An in depth review of the state of the art of creativity assessment games ●Considerations that can be used to design, implement, and evaluate digital creativity games with respect to validity, reliability, and scalability ●A catalyst for interdisciplinary dialogs The intended audience for this article is researchers who focus on creativity assessments, as well as stakeholders and practitioners seeking to deploy creativity assessments in their concrete field, such as education, or corporate environments.

column3: Creativity assessment and its challenges: past and present Creativity is generally defined as the ability to produce solutions, ideas, or products that are both novel and effective (Runco & Jaeger, 2012). Going one layer deeper, creativity is “the interaction among aptitude, process, and environment by which an individual or group produces a perceptible product that is both novel and useful as defined within a social context” (Plucker, Beghetto, & Dow, 2004, p. 91, original emphasis). In the following sections, standard creativity assessment methods will be introduced, and advantages and disadvantages of those will be discussed.
