column3: Creative process: convergent and divergent thinking The majority of psychometric creativity assessment instruments focus on two essential processes of creative thinking, conceptualized by Guilford (1956): divergent and convergent thinking. Divergent thinking (DT) is defined as the ability to come up with many different solutions to a prompt, whereas convergent thinking (CT) is defined as the ability to find the single best (correct) solution to a defined question (Cropley, 2006; Guilford, 1956). Although Guilford drew attention to and acknowledged the importance of both processes, creativity quickly became equated with DT, leading to the majority of assessment instruments focusing on measuring DT (Cropley, 2006). These instruments often operationalize DT following Guilford’s (Guilford, 1973) proposal, in terms of ideational fluency (the number of outputs: ideas, products, solutions), flexibility (how different the proposed outputs are from each other), originality (how unique an output is), and elaboration (the level of details in an output).

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Creative process: convergent and divergent thinking The majority of psychometric creativity assessment instruments focus on two essential processes of creative thinking, conceptualized by Guilford (1956): divergent and convergent thinking. Divergent thinking (DT) is defined as the ability to come up with many different solutions to a prompt, whereas convergent thinking (CT) is defined as the ability to find the single best (correct) solution to a defined question (Cropley, 2006; Guilford, 1956). Although Guilford drew attention to and acknowledged the importance of both processes, creativity quickly became equated with DT, leading to the majority of assessment instruments focusing on measuring DT (Cropley, 2006). These instruments often operationalize DT following Guilford’s (Guilford, 1973) proposal, in terms of ideational fluency (the number of outputs: ideas, products, solutions), flexibility (how different the proposed outputs are from each other), originality (how unique an output is), and elaboration (the level of details in an output).
### Input: What are the differences between divergent and convergent thinking in the creative process, and how are these concepts typically measured in psychometric creativity assessment instruments?
### Response: Divergent thinking (DT) and convergent thinking (CT) are two essential processes of creative thinking. DT is defined as the ability to come up with many different solutions to a prompt, while CT is the ability to find the single best (correct) solution to a defined question. In psychometric creativity assessment instruments, these concepts are typically measured in different ways. DT is often operationalized in terms of ideational fluency (the number of outputs: ideas, products, solutions), flexibility (how different the proposed outputs are from each other), originality (how unique an output is), and elaboration (the level of details in an output). CT, on the other hand, is typically measured by the ability to find the single best solution to a defined question.

column3: Standard tests for the creative process This operationalization of creativity has led to numerous standardized tests, most of which focus on assessing the creative process (Kaufman & Sternberg, 2019, p. 45). What the authors define as ‘creative process’ is equivalent to Guilford’s definition of creative potential (Guilford, 1950, 1968; Runco & Acar, 2012). Guilford’s Alternate Uses Test (Guilford, 1968) asks participants to come up with alternative/unusual uses of everyday objects, such as a brick, or a pencil. A widely used battery (i.e., collection of tests) is the Torrance Test of Creative Thinking (Torrance, 1966), which includes a variety of verbal (e.g., Unusual Uses, Impossibilities, Consequences, Situations) and non-verbal tasks (Incomplete Figures, Creative Design, Circles and Squares). A similar, popular battery is the Wallach-Kogan Creativity Test (Wallach & Kogan, 1965), which includes three verbal, and two visual tasks. Evidence of reliability of these and similar tests is fairly convincing (Kaufman & Sternberg, 2019; Torrance, 1981; Williams, 1980), however the predictive and discriminant (not CREATIVITY RESEARCH JOURNAL 29.

What the authors define as ‘creative process’ is equivalent to Guilford’s definition of creative potential (Guilford, 1950, 1968; Runco & Acar, 2012). Guilford’s Alternate Uses Test (Guilford, 1968) asks participants to come up with alternative/unusual uses of everyday objects, such as a brick, or a pencil. A widely used battery (i.e., collection of tests) is the Torrance Test of Creative Thinking (Torrance, 1966), which includes a variety of verbal (e.g., Unusual Uses, Impossibilities, Consequences, Situations) and non-verbal tasks (Incomplete Figures, Creative Design, Circles and Squares). A similar, popular battery is the Wallach-Kogan Creativity Test (Wallach & Kogan, 1965), which includes three verbal, and two visual tasks. ### Input: What is the definition of 'creative process' as used in standardized tests for creativity, and what are some examples of these tests?
### Response: The 'creative process' in standardized tests for creativity is defined as the ability to come up with alternative or unusual uses of everyday objects, which is equivalent to Guilford’s definition of creative potential. Some examples of these tests include Guilford’s Alternate Uses Test, the Torrance Test of Creative Thinking, and the Wallach-Kogan Creativity Test. The Guilford’s Alternate Uses Test asks participants to think of different uses for common items like a brick or a pencil. The Torrance Test of Creative Thinking includes a variety of verbal and non-verbal tasks, such as Unusual Uses, Impossibilities, Consequences, Situations, Incomplete Figures, Creative Design, Circles and Squares. The Wallach-Kogan Creativity Test includes three verbal and two visual tasks.

column3: Correlating with irrelevant measures) validity of DT tests has mixed support (Bachelor, 1989 ; Clapham, 1996 ; Cooper, 1991 ; Kaufman & Sternberg, 2019 ; Thompson & Andersson, 1983 ). Some scholars have also noted that scores on divergent production tests are susceptible to training and intervention effects (Clapham, 1996 ; Kaufman & Sternberg, 2010 ; Torrance, 1988 ). CT is commonly measured with the Remote Associations Test (Mednick, 1962 ), in which a participant is shown three cue words that are linked by a fourth word, which is the correct answer that the participant has to find. While widely used, the Remote Association Test has been criticized for relying heavily on the participant’s language skills (Cortes, Weinberger, Daker, & Green, 2019 ).

column3: Limitations of these standard tests The aforementioned tests are so well studied that they are often used as a point of reference for convergent validity3 of any newly developed creativity instrument. However, they are criticized for the following reasons: ●They are often administered in strict testing conditions and in artificial contexts (e.g., in laboratories) to ensure internal validity.4 These are however far removed from natural situations, where one would express their creativity (Cotter & Silvia, 2019 ) and can induce unintended physiological effects such as test anxiety (Schram & Ule, 2019 ) and Hawthorne effect (McCambridge, Witton, & Elbourne, 2014 ). ●They are not particularly meaningful to the participants (Valladares-Rodríguez, Pérez-Rodríguez, Anido-Rifón, & Fernández-Iglesias, 2016 ). ●They rely on fairly simple interactions and only analyze the final product, which does not afford the ability to capture detailed, fine grained steps in an individual’s trajectory toward an output (Schulte-Mecklenbeck, Kühberger, & Johnson, 2019 ). ●They rely on resource-intensive administration and human raters (Cseh & Jeffries, 2019 ). When there are few raters, individual taste, preferences and idiosyncrasies will have an impact. Employing multiple raters and measuring interrater reliability (the extent to which judges agree on the scoring of the answers) is effective but resource-intensive. If raters spend long hours assessing items, they are susceptible to fatigue, compromising the reliability of their judgments (Cseh & Jeffries, 2019 ).

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Limitations of these standard tests The aforementioned tests are so well studied that they are often used as a point of reference for convergent validity3 of any newly developed creativity instrument. However, they are criticized for the following reasons: ●They are often administered in strict testing conditions and in artificial contexts (e.g., in laboratories) to ensure internal validity.4 These are however far removed from natural situations, where one would express their creativity (Cotter & Silvia, 2019 ) and can induce unintended physiological effects such as test anxiety (Schram & Ule, 2019 ) and Hawthorne effect (McCambridge, Witton, & Elbourne, 2014 ). ●They are not particularly meaningful to the participants (Valladares-Rodríguez, Pérez-Rodríguez, Anido-Rifón, & Fernández-Iglesias, 2016 ). ●They rely on fairly simple interactions and only analyze the final product, which does not afford the ability to capture detailed, fine grained steps in an individual’s trajectory toward an output (Schulte-Mecklenbeck, Kühberger, & Johnson, 2019 ). ●They rely on resource-intensive administration and human raters (Cseh & Jeffries, 2019 ). When there are few raters, individual taste, preferences and idiosyncrasies will have an impact. Employing multiple raters and measuring interrater reliability (the extent to which judges agree on the scoring of the answers) is effective but resource-intensive. If raters spend long hours assessing items, they are susceptible to fatigue, compromising the reliability of their judgments (Cseh & Jeffries, 2019 ).
### Input: What are some of the criticisms of standard creativity tests and how do they potentially impact the validity and reliability of these tests?
### Response: Standard creativity tests are criticized for several reasons. Firstly, they are often administered in strict testing conditions and artificial contexts, such as laboratories, which are far removed from natural situations where creativity is typically expressed. This can induce unintended physiological effects like test anxiety and the Hawthorne effect, potentially impacting the validity of the tests. Secondly, these tests are not particularly meaningful to the participants, which could affect their engagement and performance. Thirdly, they rely on simple interactions and only analyze the final product, which does not allow for capturing detailed steps in an individual’s creative process, potentially limiting the validity of the tests. Lastly, these tests rely on resource-intensive administration and human raters. The individual tastes, preferences, and idiosyncrasies of a small number of raters can impact the results. While employing multiple raters and measuring interrater reliability can be effective, it is resource-intensive and raters are susceptible to fatigue, which can compromise the reliability of their judgments.

column3: Additionally, Runco, Abdulla, Paek, Al-Jasim, and Alsuwaidi (2016 ) compared results from seven different DT batteries and observed that each test seems to measure a slightly different process, and the results are often not highly intercorrelated (i.e., low convergent correlation with each other). This led them to conclude that “research using only one divergent thinking test will not provide generalizable results” (Runco et al., 2016 , p. 4). If the purpose of an evaluation is to assess general DT or CT, researchers call for multiple domains and tasks to be included (Acar & Runco, 2019 ; Cortes et al., 2019 ; Reiter-Palmon, Forthmann, & Barbot, 2019 ). However, a significant downside to employing multiple test-like tasks is the increased risk of test fatigue (Ackerman & Kanfer, 2009 ).

Text: Additionally, Runco, Abdulla, Paek, Al-Jasim, and Alsuwaidi (2016 ) compared results from seven different DT batteries and observed that each test seems to measure a slightly different process, and the results are often not highly intercorrelated (i.e., low convergent correlation with each other). This led them to conclude that “research using only one divergent thinking test will not provide generalizable results” (Runco et al., 2016 , p. 4). If the purpose of an evaluation is to assess general DT or CT, researchers call for multiple domains and tasks to be included (Acar & Runco, 2019 ; Cortes et al., 2019 ; Reiter-Palmon, Forthmann, & Barbot, 2019 ). However, a significant downside to employing multiple test-like tasks is the increased risk of test fatigue (Ackerman & Kanfer, 2009 ).
### Input: What is the downside of using multiple test-like tasks in the evaluation of general Divergent Thinking (DT) or Convergent Thinking (CT)?
### Response: The downside of using multiple test-like tasks in the evaluation of general Divergent Thinking (DT) or Convergent Thinking (CT) is the increased risk of test fatigue.

column3: Solving part of the problem: Digital standardized tests Digital, standardized creativity assessments are increasing in popularity (e.g., Bowden & Jung-Beeman, 2003 ; Dow & Mayer, 2004 ; Guo, 2019 ; Olteţeanu & Zunjani, 2020 ; Palaniappan, 2012 ; Pásztor, Molnár, & Csapó, 2015 ) as they may lower the barrier to algorithmic scoring of responses, thus reducing human subjectivity (Beketayev & Runco, 2016 ; Lau & Cheung, 2010 ), and make testing more accessible to administer (Kwon, Goetz, & Zellner, 1998 ). In principle, the digital nature of tasks in digital tests allows for a more fine-grained data analysis, in which not only the final product, but also the process (e.g., time-ordering of inputs) is taken into account for the evaluation (Evans, Holmes, & Trueblood, 2019 ). However, this potential is far from being fully exploited in creativity assessment.

Text: Solving part of the problem: Digital standardized tests Digital, standardized creativity assessments are increasing in popularity (e.g., Bowden & Jung-Beeman, 2003 ; Dow & Mayer, 2004 ; Guo, 2019 ; Olteţeanu & Zunjani, 2020 ; Palaniappan, 2012 ; Pásztor, Molnár, & Csapó, 2015 ) as they may lower the barrier to algorithmic scoring of responses, thus reducing human subjectivity (Beketayev & Runco, 2016 ; Lau & Cheung, 2010 ), and make testing more accessible to administer (Kwon, Goetz, & Zellner, 1998 ). In principle, the digital nature of tasks in digital tests allows for a more fine-grained data analysis, in which not only the final product, but also the process (e.g., time-ordering of inputs) is taken into account for the evaluation (Evans, Holmes, & Trueblood, 2019 ). However, this potential is far from being fully exploited in creativity assessment.
### Input: What are the potential benefits of using digital, standardized creativity assessments and how can the digital nature of these tests contribute to a more detailed data analysis?
### Response: The potential benefits of using digital, standardized creativity assessments include reducing human subjectivity in scoring responses, making testing more accessible to administer, and allowing for a more fine-grained data analysis. The digital nature of these tests can contribute to a more detailed data analysis by not only evaluating the final product, but also taking into account the process, such as the time-ordering of inputs. However, the text suggests that this potential is not yet fully exploited in creativity assessment.

column3: An example of a promising algorithmic scoring method for assessing DT tasks employs a specific variant of semantic networks, namely an association network . Association networks capture the relationships between concepts and words used in natural language (Beketayev & Runco, 2016 ). Acar and Runco (2014 ) use a semantic-based algorithm (SBA) to calculate how distant (in conceptual space) ideas or answers of an individual are from each other. They found that SBA flexibility is strongly correlated (r = 0.74) with traditional scoring of flexibility scores from the Many Uses Test (similar to the Alternative Uses Test; Guilford, 1968 ), suggesting strong convergent validity. While the approach holds potential, Forthmann, Oyebade, Ojo, Günther, and Holling (2019 ) highlight that this system is susceptible to certain biases, which can taint the calculations of the system. It must also be noted that automated assessments are far from capturing the complexity and nuance of human judgment needed for some assessments such as scoring originality or flexibility of figural elements of the Torrance 30 J. RAFNER ET AL.

column3: Test of Creativity Thinking. Furthermore, digitized tests  are not necessarily more meaningful to the participants  than the pen- and paper-based versions. Product-oriented assessment In contrast to process-oriented assessments, among  others, Baer and Kaufman (Baer, Kaufman, & Gentile,  2004 ) argue that product-based assessments (e.g., poetry,  collage, music) are probably “the most appropriate  assessments of creativity” as they “indicate ability to  produce creative products past or present” (Kaufman  & Sternberg, 2019 , p. 54). The evaluation of such tasks  was operationalized by Amabile in a method known as  the Consensual Assessment Technique (Amabile, 1982 ).  This method involves a group of expert raters (i.e.,  appropriate observers familiar with the domain of the  creative product) individually and independently scor- ing a set of products. The Consensual Assessment  Technique has been espoused as a, if not the gold stan- dard (Baer et al., 2004 ) in creativity assessment and  considered a versatile, reliable measure of creativity  negating the need for explicit definitions (Cseh &  Jeffries, 2019 ). This technique relies completely on  resource-intensive human rating, especially as expert  raters are sometimes hard to find. However, the require - ments for one to be an expert, and information on  training or guidance of judges is not well defined (Cseh  & Jeffries, 2019 ). This uncertainty, coupled with rapid  technological developments, has led to initial studies of  crowdsourced consensual assessment, however the  results have been mixed (see McKenna, Arnone, Kaarst-  Brown, McKnight, & Chauncey, 2013 ).

The Consensual Assessment  Technique has been espoused as a, if not the gold stan- dard (Baer et al., 2004 ) in creativity assessment and  considered a versatile, reliable measure of creativity  negating the need for explicit definitions (Cseh &  Jeffries, 2019 ). ### Input: What is the Consensual Assessment Technique in creativity assessment and what are some of its potential limitations?
### Response: The Consensual Assessment Technique in creativity assessment is a method that involves a group of expert raters, who are familiar with the domain of the creative product, individually and independently scoring a set of products. This technique is considered a reliable measure of creativity and does not require explicit definitions. However, it has some potential limitations. It relies completely on resource-intensive human rating and expert raters can sometimes be hard to find. The requirements for one to be an expert, and information on training or guidance of judges is not well defined. This uncertainty, along with rapid technological developments, has led to initial studies of crowdsourced consensual assessment, but the results have been mixed.

column3: Other traditional testing instruments Before moving on to discuss digital game-based assess - ments, one should note that there are also well-known  assessments for creative personality, behavior, and envir - onments. Aspects of personality and behavioral correlates  of creativity are evaluated with self-perception assess - ments such as personality scales and questionnaires  (Kaufman & Sternberg, 2019 ). Self-reporting can be use- ful in some contexts despite its vulnerability to biases  (Kaufman, 2019 ). Creativity can be assessed from obser - ving a particular activity, which is common practice in  education (Katz-Buonincontro & Anderson, 2018 ). One  can map the process toward a creative solution by record - ing verbal transcripts of thought. One commonly used  method employing this is the ‘Think Aloud’ method  (Dorst & Cross, 2001 ; Kaplan & Simon, 1990 ). However,  these are also resource intensive to manually code.

Text: Other traditional testing instruments Before moving on to discuss digital game-based assess - ments, one should note that there are also well-known  assessments for creative personality, behavior, and envir - onments. Aspects of personality and behavioral correlates  of creativity are evaluated with self-perception assess - ments such as personality scales and questionnaires  (Kaufman & Sternberg, 2019 ). Self-reporting can be use- ful in some contexts despite its vulnerability to biases  (Kaufman, 2019 ). Creativity can be assessed from obser - ving a particular activity, which is common practice in  education (Katz-Buonincontro & Anderson, 2018 ). One  can map the process toward a creative solution by record - ing verbal transcripts of thought. One commonly used  method employing this is the ‘Think Aloud’ method  (Dorst & Cross, 2001 ; Kaplan & Simon, 1990 ). However,  these are also resource intensive to manually code.
### Input: What are some traditional testing instruments used for assessing creativity, and what are their potential limitations?
### Response: Traditional testing instruments used for assessing creativity include self-perception assessments such as personality scales and questionnaires, observation of a particular activity, and the 'Think Aloud' method which involves recording verbal transcripts of thought. However, these methods have potential limitations. Self-reporting, for instance, can be useful in some contexts but it is vulnerable to biases. Observing a particular activity is a common practice in education, but it may not provide a comprehensive assessment of creativity. The 'Think Aloud' method, while effective, is resource-intensive as it requires manual coding.

column3: Digital game-based assessment of creativity In contrast to traditional instruments, well-designed digi- tal games may be suited better for assessing creativity for  many reasons. Broadly, game-based assessment can be  described as “using data from in-game actions to make  inferences about players’ knowledge, skills, and attributes,  allowing us to make use of information in the ocean of  data produced by daily digital interactions with software ”  (DiCerbo, 2014 , p. 26). In the context of creativity assess - ment, there are several factors which could allow for the  combination of scalability and refined data acquisition.  First, the gamified environment elicits behavior that is  more casual and natural than the completion of tradi - tional tests. This can mitigate unintended physiological  effects, such as test anxiety, or researcher effect and in  turn may result in data with higher ecological validity  (Lumsden, Edwards, Lawrence, Coyle, & Munafò, 2016 ;  Shute & Kim, 2014 ). Digital games are also more motivat - ing to people than standardized tests are (Gee, 2005 ).  Intrinsic motivation can induce a ‘flow state,’ in which  people fully concentrate on and enjoy the task-at-hand.  This state can be achieved when people have clear goals,  immediate feedback, and a balance between challenges  and skills (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997 ). Being in the flow-  state also allows for creativity (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997 ),  and thus creates a good opportunity for creativity  assessment.

First, the gamified environment elicits behavior that is  more casual and natural than the completion of tradi - tional tests. This can mitigate unintended physiological  effects, such as test anxiety, or researcher effect and in  turn may result in data with higher ecological validity  (Lumsden, Edwards, Lawrence, Coyle, & Munafò, 2016 ;  Shute & Kim, 2014 ). Digital games are also more motivat - ing to people than standardized tests are (Gee, 2005 ).  Intrinsic motivation can induce a ‘flow state,’ in which  people fully concentrate on and enjoy the task-at-hand.  This state can be achieved when people have clear goals,  immediate feedback, and a balance between challenges  and skills (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997 ). Being in the flow-  state also allows for creativity (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997 ),  and thus creates a good opportunity for creativity  assessment.
### Input: What are the advantages of using digital game-based assessments for evaluating creativity compared to traditional testing methods?
### Response: The text mentions several advantages of using digital game-based assessments for evaluating creativity compared to traditional testing methods. Firstly, the gamified environment elicits more casual and natural behavior, which can reduce unintended physiological effects like test anxiety or researcher effect, resulting in data with higher ecological validity. Secondly, digital games are more motivating than standardized tests, which can induce a 'flow state' where people fully concentrate on and enjoy the task at hand. This state, which can be achieved when people have clear goals, immediate feedback, and a balance between challenges and skills, also allows for creativity, making it a good opportunity for creativity assessment. Lastly, game-based assessment allows for the use of data from in-game actions to make inferences about players' knowledge, skills, and attributes, providing a combination of scalability and refined data acquisition.

column3: Additionally, digital games enable higher engagement  levels. This could allow for longer interactions and multi - faceted testing of creativity in a complex environment,  which is necessary to elicit and assess both creative pro- cesses and products, without inducing testing fatigue.  This point is paramount in creativity research, as more  and more emphasis is placed on the inclusion of multiple  domains and tasks, in order to adequately make general - izations about an individual’s creativity. Digital games  also afford the ability to capture detailed, fine grained  steps in an individual’s trajectory toward an output  (Hart et al., 2017 ). Given their accessibility, appeal and  prevalence in peoples’ everyday lives (Ghuman &  Griffiths, 2012 ) digital games could allow for broader  sampling (engaging many demographic groups), possibly  leading to reliable predictions at the individual level  (through validation of demographically fine-grained  models), higher external validity, and more generalizable  results. On the one hand, if the games are freely accessible  online, there are several risk factors from lack of research  supervision such as people playing without paying atten - tion. On the other hand, freely accessible digital games  could support the equitable access to creativity assess - ment. These factors underscore the potential digital  games hold for assessing creativity.

Given their accessibility, appeal and  prevalence in peoples’ everyday lives (Ghuman &  Griffiths, 2012 ) digital games could allow for broader  sampling (engaging many demographic groups), possibly  leading to reliable predictions at the individual level  (through validation of demographically fine-grained  models), higher external validity, and more generalizable  results. ### Input: What potential do digital games hold for assessing creativity and how can they contribute to higher engagement levels and more generalizable results in creativity research?
### Response: Digital games hold significant potential for assessing creativity by enabling higher engagement levels, allowing for longer interactions, and facilitating multi-faceted testing of creativity in a complex environment. They can capture detailed, fine-grained steps in an individual's trajectory toward an output, which can be crucial in creativity research. Digital games' accessibility, appeal, and prevalence in everyday lives could allow for broader sampling, engaging many demographic groups, and possibly leading to reliable predictions at the individual level. This could result in higher external validity and more generalizable results. Furthermore, if these games are freely accessible online, they could support equitable access to creativity assessment. However, the lack of research supervision could pose several risk factors, such as people playing without paying attention.

column3: In the absence of valid, reliable, scalable, and accessible  solutions for assessing creativity, non-scientifically driven  corporate enterprises have leveraged new technologies,  creating widely used games and gamified platforms.  These games claim to foster and/or assess creativity and  other 21st century skills. Examples include: KnackApp (u.  d.), Kettlemind (u.d.), Figment (u.d.), BrainSparker (u.d.),  and Lumosity (u.d.). Some of these companies charge fees  based on promises to “find hidden talent and build your  strongest workforce” (KnackApp, u.d.), and encourage  people to purchase and play so they “do not get left  behind” (KnackApp, u.d.) . These games provide a user  friendly ‘creativity score’ which allows one to ‘certify’ their  creativity. Very few of these describe transparent meth - odologies or any scientific documentation for their  claims, and the validity of some that do have been ser- iously questioned (Shute, Ventura, & Ke, 2015 ). Despite  their caveats, these apps maintain substantial user bases in  the tens of thousands to millions (Strobach & Kupferberg,  2020 ). This information truly highlights the imminent  need for accessible, scalable, scientific, and transparently  documented solutions.

### Input: What is the need for accessible, scalable, scientific, and transparently documented solutions in assessing creativity, considering the popularity and questionable validity of current gamified platforms like KnackApp and Lumosity?
### Response: The need for accessible, scalable, scientific, and transparently documented solutions in assessing creativity is highlighted by the popularity and questionable validity of current gamified platforms like KnackApp and Lumosity. These platforms claim to foster and assess creativity, but often lack transparent methodologies or scientific documentation to support their claims. Despite this, they maintain substantial user bases, indicating a high demand for such services. Therefore, there is an imminent need for solutions that are not only accessible and scalable, but also scientifically valid and transparently documented to ensure the accurate assessment of creativity and other 21st century skills.

column3: Fortunately, efforts to systematically analyze and assess  elements of creativity and “processes that can evolve into  creative solutions” (Shute & Rahimi, 2021 ), embedded in  technology-rich environments (e.g., digital games) are  underway. Assessment in these environments is called  stealth assessment , where the player’s in-game actions  are continually logged, while the participant is immersed  in the activity, without being constantly attune to the  assessment. Stealth assessment is rooted in evidence cen- tered design (Mislevy, Almond, & Lukas, 2003 ), which  combines knowledge from both computational, and con- ceptual models. This method requires the researcher to  “(a) define the claims concerning learners’ competencies,  (b) establish what represents valid evidence of a claim, and  (c) determine the kind of tasks or situations that will elicit  that evidence ” (Shute & Kim, 2014 , p. 107). Stealth assess - ment systems use two main processes, which incorporate  the requisites of evidence centered design. These are evi- dence identification (i.e., identifying the predefined vari- ables or observables from log files), and evidence  accumulation (i.e., statistically linking the observables to  the facets of the competency at hand), which allow for the  assessment of the player’s competency level in real-time.  Assuming that the underlying theory is robust, the more  data the players generate, the more accurate the estimate  for each player becomes. Additionally, the fine-grained  tracking and recording of player’s interactions (i.e., via the  accumulation of log data generated by keystrokes, mouse  clicks, and choice patterns) can be used to analyze the  player’s learning progress and provide ongoing feedback  (Shute, Lu, & Rahimi, 2021 ).

Text: Fortunately, efforts to systematically analyze and assess  elements of creativity and “processes that can evolve into  creative solutions” (Shute & Rahimi, 2021 ), embedded in  technology-rich environments (e.g., digital games) are  underway. Assessment in these environments is called  stealth assessment , where the player’s in-game actions  are continually logged, while the participant is immersed  in the activity, without being constantly attune to the  assessment. Stealth assessment is rooted in evidence cen- tered design (Mislevy, Almond, & Lukas, 2003 ), which  combines knowledge from both computational, and con- ceptual models. This method requires the researcher to  “(a) define the claims concerning learners’ competencies,  (b) establish what represents valid evidence of a claim, and  (c) determine the kind of tasks or situations that will elicit  that evidence ” (Shute & Kim, 2014 , p. 107). Stealth assess - ment systems use two main processes, which incorporate  the requisites of evidence centered design. These are evi- dence identification (i.e., identifying the predefined vari- ables or observables from log files), and evidence  accumulation (i.e., statistically linking the observables to  the facets of the competency at hand), which allow for the  assessment of the player’s competency level in real-time.  Assuming that the underlying theory is robust, the more  data the players generate, the more accurate the estimate  for each player becomes. Additionally, the fine-grained  tracking and recording of player’s interactions (i.e., via the  accumulation of log data generated by keystrokes, mouse  clicks, and choice patterns) can be used to analyze the  player’s learning progress and provide ongoing feedback  (Shute, Lu, & Rahimi, 2021 ).
### Input: What are the two main processes used in stealth assessment systems and how do they contribute to the assessment of a player's competency level in real-time?
### Response: The two main processes used in stealth assessment systems are evidence identification and evidence accumulation. Evidence identification involves identifying the predefined variables or observables from log files. Evidence accumulation, on the other hand, involves statistically linking the observables to the facets of the competency at hand. These processes allow for the assessment of the player’s competency level in real-time. As the players generate more data, the estimate for each player becomes more accurate. The fine-grained tracking and recording of player’s interactions can be used to analyze the player’s learning progress and provide ongoing feedback.

column3: Given the combination of rich, fine-grained data and  versatile task design, stealth assessment has been applied  to target “hard-to-measure constructs,” including creativ - ity (Shute & Rahimi, 2021 ), basic and executive cognitive  functions (Pedersen et al., 2020 ), problem solving (Akram  et al., 2018 ; Shute et al., 2015 ; Shute, Wang, Greiff, Zhao,  & Moore, 2016 ), persistence (Rahimi, Shute, & Zhang,  2021 ), computational thinking (Min et al., 2015 ), social  skills (DeRosier, Craig, & Sanchez, 2012 ), and conscien - tiousness (Shute & Ventura, 2013 ). In general, any tech- nology-rich environment that includes human-computer  interaction and requires the assessment of a particular  knowledge, skill, or attribute should be amenable to the  application of stealth assessment. For a comprehensive  review on stealth assessment see (Shute, Lu, Rahimi,  2021 ) and (Shute & Moore, 2017 ).

column3: Summary of assessment methods Main principles, pros and cons of assessment meth - ods discussed before, are summarized in the Table 1 . column3: Methods A literature review and iterative coding exercise was  performed in order to understand how digital games  measure creativity. The following section describes the  review’s sampling methodology and coding scheme. Sampling In this review, papers that report on digital game-based  creativity assessments were included regardless of their  scoring mechanism (human or algorithmic). While only  the three papers written by Shute et al. use the terminology  ‘stealth assessment’ and ‘evidence centered design’ expli - citly, all papers build on a theoretical foundation of crea- tivity (mostly divergent thinking or convergent thinking),  operationalize it given their experimental set up (e.g.,  explain their metrics for flexibility, fluency and originality),  and collect data from the game play, based on the oper - ationalization. Text: Methods A literature review and iterative coding exercise was  performed in order to understand how digital games  measure creativity. The following section describes the  review’s sampling methodology and coding scheme. Sampling In this review, papers that report on digital game-based  creativity assessments were included regardless of their  scoring mechanism (human or algorithmic). column3: Multiple sources were used in this review. Given  the historical roots of modern creativity research  (i.e., since Guilford’s (1950 ) inaugural presidential  APA address), APA-based outlets were first  searched. However, as Gardner wrote, creativity is  “precisely the kind of problem which eludes expla - nation within one discipline” (Gardner, 1988 , p. 22),  the scope of sources was expanded to include other  affiliated disciplines and their main publication  channels. The final list of libraries and journals  included: Creativity Research Journal, PubMed,  ACM, Wiley, the APA library, and Google Scholar.

### Input: What are the main principles, pros, and cons of different creativity assessment instruments as discussed in the paper?
### Response: The paper discusses several creativity assessment instruments, each with its own principles, pros, and cons. 

1. Pen and paper standardized process-oriented assessments: These assess creative processes through individual or batteries of tests targeting components of divergent thinking (DT) or convergent thinking (CT). They have a large corpus of research, decades of practical use, and are often easy to manually administer. However, they are resource-intensive, potentially unmotivating, capture only final products, and may induce unintended psychological effects.

2. Digital standardized process-oriented assessments: These also assess creative processes through individual or batteries of tasks targeting components of DT or CT. They are scalable if automated assessment is possible. However, they are new and not widely studied yet, potentially unmotivating, resource-intensive when human raters are employed, and may induce unintended psychological effects.

3. Product-oriented assessment: This assesses the creativity of a product by individual and independent consensus of expert raters. It has a large corpus of research, decades of practical use, and clearly indicates ability to produce creative products. However, it is resource-intensive and therefore often not easily scalable.

4. Person and environmental focused assessment: This includes assessment of creative behavior, creative self-perception. It has a large corpus of research, decades of practical use. However, it has an increased risk of confounding variables given the broad scope, bias due to self-reporting, and is resource-intensive and therefore often not easily scalable.

5. Commercial game-based assessments: These can be forms of digitized psychometric and non-psychometric tests, or other unspecified mechanisms. They are designed to be used at scale and have engaging interaction design. However, they have little (if any) scientific backing or disclosure of methodology, and costs limit equitable access.

6. Digital game employing stealth assessment: Evidence needed to assess the creative process is provided by the players’ interactions with the game itself. It could offer opportunities for higher ecological and construct validity, is scalable when automated assessment is used, potentially more motivating than standard tests, and afford fine grain metrics. However, it is new and not widely studied yet.

column3: Analysis The process described above resulted in a pool of 127  studies in total. These papers were manually read and  evaluated by the first and third authors to determine if  they fit the above stated criteria. Papers that did not fit  the criteria, and duplicate papers were removed from the  review. In total, 16 papers fit the review’s criteria (digital  games used to assess creativity, regardless of their scor- ing mechanism). Google Sheets were used to organize  and collaboratively discuss the resultant publications  among the coauthors.

column3: The coding scheme was developed through an iterative  process that involved discussions among all coauthors. As  a first naive approach, open-ended data was collected on  research focus and definition of creativity in order to get  a broad sense of the studies. Then granularity was increased  to include the game description, scoring methods used, the  number of participants , whether individual, dyadic , or  group creativity was being assessed, the stated motivations  for using game-based assessments, the method of validat - ing the game, and the level of correlation observed. Some  seemingly straightforward codes such as the number of  participants proved to be problematic. For example, due  to anonymized data, one study reported the number of  game sessions, not the number of players. With regards to  the focus of the study being individual, dyadic or group  creativity, an additional option of co-creative was added,  when a paper describing a game that a child plays together  with a robot was encountered. Following a variation of  Remy, MacDonald Vermeulen, Frich, Biskjaer, and  Dalsgaard (2020 ), codes were systematically divided into  three categories: open ended, numeric, and nominal.

### Response: The three categories into which codes were systematically divided in the coding scheme developed by the coauthors were open ended, numeric, and nominal.

column3: The next iteration of codes was inspired by fundamen - tal questions one might ask while designing a digital game  to assess creativity. For example, in addition to the defini - tion of creativity, the component of creativity measured  (e.g., DT-flexibility, DT-fluency, DT-originality, CT) was  added. In addition to the number of participants , the codes  of location, expertise, recruitment method and compensa - tion was added, in order to address the issues of scalability  and reaching a diverse pool of participants. The publica - tion outlets were also recorded and sorted to glean insight  into the diversity of domains exploring game-based crea- tivity assessment. The open code venue of publication was  added to highlight the diversity of publication outlets. See  table 2 for the final list of codes used in the analysis.

column3: Motivation for using games Each paper was searched for explanations as to why  games had been used to assess creativity and the  reasons authors provided were identified. The papers were blindly coded by the first and third author and  then through iterative discussions, the motivations  presented in the papers were coalesced into seven  categories. Data richness, player motivation and  engagement, and scalable assessment were the three  most commonly cited reasons for using digital games.

column3: Game design: mechanics and metrics The types of games used in the reported studies varied  widely. Three studies designed their experiment around  preexisting, commercially developed games (Chuang  et al., 2015 ; Gal et al., 2017 ; Voiskounsky et al., 2017 ),  while all other studies used games that had been designed  for academic purposes. The core game play interactions  varied from sandbox games such as Minecraft  (Voiskounsky et al., 2017 ) through image blending with  neural networks (Rafner et al., 2020 ), to educational games  focused on Newtonian physics (Shute & Rahimi, 2021 ). The games also differed in their inclusion of various  levels of difficulty, progression, multiple rounds, or mul- tiple modes of play. Here, a ‘mode of play’ refers to  different types of tasks within a game, while ‘rounds’  refer to the number of times a participant completes the  same type of task (no varying difficulty) and levels refers  to similar tasks with increasing difficulty. For example,  crea.blender (Rafner et al., 2020 ) includes three modes,  Create, Challenge and Open Play, all of which are dif- ferent types of tasks with same core game play, image  blending with a neural network. In contrast, the  reviewed study on Minecraft (Voiskounsky et al., 2017 )  consists of two rounds of a single mode, with partici - pants instructed to build two objects, a house and a ship,  which can be considered to require the same competen - cies. Overall, four games implemented progression  explicitly in their design, out of which, three worked  with level-based, and one with time-based progression.

### Input: What does the term 'mode of play' refer to in the context of game design and how does it differ from 'rounds' and 'levels'?
### Response: In the context of game design, the term 'mode of play' refers to different types of tasks within a game. It differs from 'rounds' and 'levels' in that 'rounds' refer to the number of times a participant completes the same type of task without varying difficulty, while 'levels' refer to similar tasks with increasing difficulty.

column3: Two of the games explore digitally augmented creativity  by allowing players to interact directly with an algorithm in  the process of game-play. As seen in Table 5, seven of the games measure DT  through some combination of fluency, flexibility, and  originality, while only crea.blender explicitly measures  CT (Rafner et al., 2020 ) but does not provide metrics for  those measures. The Creativity Game-based Evaluation  System (Yeh et al., 2016 ) utilized insight problems which  could be solved with different paths. As seen in Table 5, seven of the games measure DT  through some combination of fluency, flexibility, and  originality, while only crea.blender explicitly measures  CT (Rafner et al., 2020 ) but does not provide metrics for  those measures. ### Input: What methods do the games crea.blender and Droodle use to explore digitally augmented creativity and how do they measure divergent thinking (DT) and convergent thinking (CT)?
### Response: The games crea.blender and Droodle explore digitally augmented creativity by allowing players to interact directly with an algorithm during game-play. In crea.blender, participants interact with a neural network to create images. In Droodle, participants interact with a social robot by taking turns playing the game. Seven of the games, including these two, measure divergent thinking (DT) through some combination of fluency, flexibility, and originality. However, only crea.blender explicitly measures convergent thinking (CT), but it does not provide metrics for these measures. The Creativity Game-based Evaluation System uses insight problems that can be solved with different paths, which requires both CT and DT.

column3: The study only reports and measures creativity through a binary variable, the correctness of the solution. BuzzWords (Howell & Veale, 2009) reports on verbal creativity and word association which is commonly linked to CT. In Immune Defense (Krebs et al., 2020), creativity is calculated through the measurement of diversity in the player’s solutions toward the same goal.

### Response: The study by Howell & Veale (2009) measured creativity through verbal creativity and word association. The study by Krebs et al. (2020) measured creativity through the diversity in the player’s solutions toward the same goal.

column3: Results and synthesis In this section, the results from the coding exercise are described, and the prescriptive findings are presented. As a point of clarification, from the 16 papers included in the review, 11 unique games (Ali, Moroso, & Breazeal, 2019; Chuang, Liu, & Shiu, 2015; Gal, Hershkovitz, Morán, Guenaga, & Garaizar, 2017; Hart et al., 2017; Howell et al. 2010 Krebs et al., 2020; Rafner et al., 2020; Shillo, Hoernle, & Gal, 2019; Shute & Rahimi, 2021; Voiskounsky, Yermolova, Yagolkovskiy, & Khromova, 2017; Yeh, Lai, & Lin, 2016) were identified. An overview of the results from the nominal and numeric codes can be seen in Appendix B, Table B2. Screen shots of each game can be found in Appendix A, Figures A1-A10.

column3: Scientific context: research questions and publication outlets All studies were coded on their research questions and approach. The research approach was either empirical, when data collection was involved, or theoretical, when there was no data involved. In total, there were 13 empirical, and 3 theoretical papers. Among the empirical studies, it was possible to distinguish between usability studies (participant’s user behavior and interaction with the tool was observed; Rafner et al., 2020), experimental (creativity was studied under two or more experimental conditions; Ali et al., 2019; Noy et al., 2012; Voiskounsky et al., 2017; Yeh et al., 2016), correlational (investigated which variables have a natural relationship with creativity; Gal et al., 2017; Rozenkrantz et al., 2017; Voiskounsky et al., 2017; Yeh et al., 2016), and validation (tested for correlation with preexisting, standard measures; Chuang et al., 2015; Hart et al., 2017; Howell & Veale, 2010; Krebs et al., 2020; Rozenkrantz et al., 2017; Shute & Rahimi, 2021) studies (some belonging to multiple categories). Among the theoretical papers, it was possible to differentiate between descriptive (described a tool/proposal; Howell & Veale, 2009; Shute & Wang, 2016), and comparative studies (analyzed/compared ideas/methods; Almond, Kim, Velasquez, & Shute, 2014).

Text: Scientific context: research questions and publication outlets All studies were coded on their research questions and approach. The research approach was either empirical, when data collection was involved, or theoretical, when there was no data involved. In total, there were 13 empirical, and 3 theoretical papers. Among the empirical studies, it was possible to distinguish between usability studies (participant’s user behavior and interaction with the tool was observed; Rafner et al., 2020), experimental (creativity was studied under two or more experimental conditions; Ali et al., 2019; Noy et al., 2012; Voiskounsky et al., 2017; Yeh et al., 2016), correlational (investigated which variables have a natural relationship with creativity; Gal et al., 2017; Rozenkrantz et al., 2017; Voiskounsky et al., 2017; Yeh et al., 2016), and validation (tested for correlation with preexisting, standard measures; Chuang et al., 2015; Hart et al., 2017; Howell & Veale, 2010; Krebs et al., 2020; Rozenkrantz et al., 2017; Shute & Rahimi, 2021) studies (some belonging to multiple categories). Among the theoretical papers, it was possible to differentiate between descriptive (described a tool/proposal; Howell & Veale, 2009; Shute & Wang, 2016), and comparative studies (analyzed/compared ideas/methods; Almond, Kim, Velasquez, & Shute, 2014).
### Input: What are the different research approaches and categories used in the empirical and theoretical studies mentioned in the text?
### Response: The research approaches used in the studies mentioned in the text are empirical and theoretical. In the empirical studies, data collection was involved, and the categories within this approach include usability studies, experimental studies, correlational studies, and validation studies. Usability studies observed participant’s user behavior and interaction with the tool. Experimental studies studied creativity under two or more experimental conditions. Correlational studies investigated which variables have a natural relationship with creativity. Validation studies tested for correlation with preexisting, standard measures.

On the other hand, the theoretical approach did not involve data collection. The categories within this approach include descriptive and comparative studies. Descriptive studies described a tool or proposal, while comparative studies analyzed or compared ideas or methods.

column3: Some games used narratives (i.e., a context description beyond what is necessary for the execution of the task) to induce a game-like environment. These included three projects that used a preexisting game, such as Kodetu (Gal et al., 2017), in which players had to “guide the astronaut to the end of a maze,” Minecraft (Voiskounsky et al., 2017), and Arctic Quest (Chuang et al., 2015), and one self-designed initiative, the Creativity Game-based Evaluation System (Yeh et al., 2016), which used the context of finding a way out from a kitchen or a living room. BuzzWords (Howell & Veale, 2009) and Immune Defense (Krebs et al., 2020) were designed to resemble existing games. BuzzWords is a Tetris-like word game, while Immune Defense is designed as a tower defense game. Other projects used the game instructions to create an intrinsically motivated playful environment. For instance, in the Droodle Game (Ali et al., 2019), a social robot asked kids if they wanted to play, while in crea.blender (Rafner et al., 2020), Physics Playground (Shute & Rahimi, 2021), Creative Foraging Game (Hart et al., 2017), and the Table 2. column3: Scoring mechanisms and instrument validation The sampled studies apply a diverse range of analyses appropriate to their wide variety of goals and subject matter domains. A primary distinction was made between analysis methods that apply manual human rating and those that employ automated scoring of in-game creativity. Among human rating methods, it is possible to distinguish between self, peer (other players), and expert judgment, as is traditionally done in creativity research (Sawyer, 2011 ). Among the games, Droodle (Ali et al., 2019 ) and Minecraft (Voiskounsky et al., 2017 ) used human rating only in the form of expert raters (although Droodle calculated the novelty using automated Natural Language Processing methods).

### Input: What methods do games use to automatically calculate creativity, and how do they categorize solutions based on creativity levels?
### Response: Games use various in-game information and calculation approaches such as Bayesian Networks to automatically calculate creativity. A game called BuzzWords categorizes solutions as low, medium, or high creativity based on compound word-frequency, which is informed by WordNet. Other games employ automated scoring based on some arbitrary baselines of creative behavior, such as expert input or previous gameplay data.

### Input: What are the motivations for using games for creativity assessment as described in various studies?
### Response: The motivations for using games for creativity assessment as described in various studies include scalable assessment, increased sample size, objective assessment, ecological validity of data, data richness, player motivation and engagement, and familiarity with games. Scalable assessment refers to the automated evaluation of creativity as opposed to manual assessment. Increased sample size means that the study can reach a wider population sample. Objective assessment refers to the elimination of certain levels of subjectivity in creativity assessment through automation. Ecological validity of data means that data collected from a game environment may reflect real-life behavior more authentically. Data richness refers to the ability of games to track progressing and provide more refined and richer data. Player motivation and engagement refers to the positive effect games can have on the players, such as reducing test anxiety and being more enjoyable than traditional tests. Familiarity with games refers to the convenience of games as a mode of data collection since they are common in everyday life.

column3: Evaluation details: Duration, location, participants Out of 16 papers, 12 included information on the duration of the gameplay and evaluation sessions. Chuang et al. (2015 ) reported that participation spanned two weeks without giving the amount of time spent on gameplay. For all other reporting papers, interventions lasted between eight minutes and four hours (average 50 minutes). Only six studies noted information on the location of the study explicitly. These varied between school (2), research laboratory (2), and online platform (2). Twelve papers reported the number of participants, ranging from eight to 266, with a mean of 85 (SD = 79.4). The participant pools were students from varying grades of elementary school (four studies), university (six studies), or general population (one study). One study used MTurk to recruit participants, two studies mentioned reaching participants through e-mails or social media, and one study recruited people on a snow-ball basis. Six studies reported some form of compensation (money, gift card, sweets) in exchange for participation.

column3: Discussion The following sections discuss the results and synthesis of the review as well as provide recommendations for future work. Size matters and so does accessibility From the analysis, a clear gap can be identified between the potential of scaling up assessment of creativity with the use of digital games, and the actual reach achieved in the examined studies. It is important to differentiate between two distinct purposes of scaling up. In research driven studies, scale up typically involves crowdsourcing and public participation through efforts to enhance engagement; the benefits of increased number of participants may include the possibility of posing and validating increasingly granular scientific models or group comparisons through the increased statistical power (Meehl, 1967 ). Thus, a given model granularity for e.g. an assessment tool sets a threshold requirement for participant numbers to achieve validity. After that is achieved the tool is ready for implementation scale-up that only aims to broaden the accessibility of the tool, not to provide further research validity. Such scale-up will typically be pursued through the established primarily educational networks such as inclusion in international or national educational testing initiatives.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Discussion The following sections discuss the results and synthesis of the review as well as provide recommendations for future work. Size matters and so does accessibility From the analysis, a clear gap can be identified between the potential of scaling up assessment of creativity with the use of digital games, and the actual reach achieved in the examined studies. It is important to differentiate between two distinct purposes of scaling up. In research driven studies, scale up typically involves crowdsourcing and public participation through efforts to enhance engagement; the benefits of increased number of participants may include the possibility of posing and validating increasingly granular scientific models or group comparisons through the increased statistical power (Meehl, 1967 ). Thus, a given model granularity for e.g. an assessment tool sets a threshold requirement for participant numbers to achieve validity. After that is achieved the tool is ready for implementation scale-up that only aims to broaden the accessibility of the tool, not to provide further research validity. Such scale-up will typically be pursued through the established primarily educational networks such as inclusion in international or national educational testing initiatives.
### Input: What are the two distinct purposes of scaling up in research driven studies and how do they contribute to the assessment of creativity with the use of digital games?
### Response: The two distinct purposes of scaling up in research-driven studies are to enhance engagement through crowdsourcing and public participation, and to broaden the accessibility of the tool. The first purpose contributes to the assessment of creativity with the use of digital games by increasing the number of participants, which allows for the posing and validating of increasingly granular scientific models or group comparisons through increased statistical power. This sets a threshold requirement for participant numbers to achieve validity. The second purpose, broadening the accessibility of the tool, does not aim to provide further research validity but rather to make the tool more widely available, typically through established educational networks. This could potentially allow for the tool to be included in international or national educational testing initiatives.

column3: Out of the reviewed papers, the highest number of participants was 226 (Yeh et al., 2016 ) with an average of 85 per study (See Figure 1). The reasons for the relatively low sample sizes in these studies could be due to the fact that achieving large sample size was not a priority, that the presented games are still in the early, laboratory stages, or due to the challenges of scaling up (e.g. technical and recruitment challenges). To elaborate on this, only three studies reported that scaling up is one of the primary reasons for using games (Shute & Wang, 2016 ; Gal et al., 2017 ; Krebs et al., 2020 ). Moreover, the nature of studies can determine the possibility for scaling up. For example, in Ali et al. (2019 ), participants physically interact with social robots which makes scaling up much more difficult than in the purely digital studies. Furthermore, Krebs et al. (2020 ) states in the abstract that the work is “preliminary data” and then in the conclusion emphasizes several times the need for further studies with more participants.

To elaborate on this, only three studies reported that scaling up is one of the primary reasons for using games (Shute & Wang, 2016 ; Gal et al., 2017 ; Krebs et al., 2020 ). Moreover, the nature of studies can determine the possibility for scaling up. For example, in Ali et al. ### Input: What are some reasons for the relatively low sample sizes in the reviewed studies on gaming?
### Response: The reasons for the relatively low sample sizes in the reviewed studies on gaming could be that achieving large sample size was not a priority, the games being studied are still in the early, laboratory stages, or due to the challenges of scaling up, such as technical and recruitment challenges. Additionally, the nature of the studies can also determine the possibility for scaling up. For instance, studies where participants physically interact with social robots make scaling up more difficult than in purely digital studies.

column3: With regards to the challenges of scaling up, evidence is mounting from previous and ongoing crowdsourcing games (e.g., Sea Hero Quest, Foldit, Skill Lab) that they can, in principle, elicit massive recruitment, but only a small fraction of projects achieve this “viral” status (Hyde et al., 2016 ; Koepnick et al., 2019 ; Pedersen et al., 2020 ). For this to happen, a number of factors have to be fulfilled simultaneously, including high fun factor, clear sense of purpose, engaging interaction design, sufficiently compelling graphics and narrative, and substantial marketing campaign.

For this to happen, a number of factors have to be fulfilled simultaneously, including high fun factor, clear sense of purpose, engaging interaction design, sufficiently compelling graphics and narrative, and substantial marketing campaign.

### Response: The factors that need to be fulfilled simultaneously for crowdsourcing games to achieve "viral" status and elicit massive recruitment include a high fun factor, clear sense of purpose, engaging interaction design, sufficiently compelling graphics and narrative, and a substantial marketing campaign.

column3: Traditional behavioral studies are conducted in labs or other relatively controlled environments to maintain internal validity. In the lab, the participant is supervised to ensure comprehension of the instructions and attention to the activity (Casaletto & Heaton, 2017 ). These types of studies find participants through open calls (flyers, etc.), via teaching, and often offer compensation. In many cases social scientists have turned to paid, recruiting platforms such as mTurk and Prolific in order to scale up sample sizes (Casler, Bickel, Hackett, 2013 ); however, these platforms also have several drawbacks (Aguinis, Villamor, & Ramani, 2021 ; Huber & Oded, 2017 ). For example (Pedersen et al., 2020 ), compared data from mTurk participants and data from volunteer players in a series of game-based cognitive ability tasks, showing detrimental trends in parts of the mTurk data set where participants sacrificed accuracy for speedy task completion.

Text: Traditional behavioral studies are conducted in labs or other relatively controlled environments to maintain internal validity. In the lab, the participant is supervised to ensure comprehension of the instructions and attention to the activity (Casaletto & Heaton, 2017 ). These types of studies find participants through open calls (flyers, etc.), via teaching, and often offer compensation. In many cases social scientists have turned to paid, recruiting platforms such as mTurk and Prolific in order to scale up sample sizes (Casler, Bickel, Hackett, 2013 ); however, these platforms also have several drawbacks (Aguinis, Villamor, & Ramani, 2021 ; Huber & Oded, 2017 ). For example (Pedersen et al., 2020 ), compared data from mTurk participants and data from volunteer players in a series of game-based cognitive ability tasks, showing detrimental trends in parts of the mTurk data set where participants sacrificed accuracy for speedy task completion.

### Response: The text mentions that one of the drawbacks of using paid recruiting platforms such as mTurk and Prolific for behavioral studies is that participants may sacrifice accuracy for speedy task completion. Other potential drawbacks are not specified in the text.

column3: For creativity tasks in particular, the collection of data via paid platforms may be particularly challenging because, compared to many basic psychology tasks, they typically exhibit a higher degree of open-endedness, which can make it harder to create alignment between scientifically productive and pay-off maximizing solution strategies (Dontcheva, Gerber, & Lewis, 2011 ; Kittur, 2010 ; Oppenlaender, Milland, Visuri, Ipeirotis, & Hosio, 2020 ). Volunteer-based outside-of the-lab studies, in which participants contribute at their own leisure (e.g., using their phone or computer), allow for millions of participants, but at the cost of losing some of the control over the testing environment. Fully understanding and finding ways of overcoming this loss of control represents one of the most urgent challenges of volunteer-based outside-of-the-lab assessment.

Text: For creativity tasks in particular, the collection of data via paid platforms may be particularly challenging because, compared to many basic psychology tasks, they typically exhibit a higher degree of open-endedness, which can make it harder to create alignment between scientifically productive and pay-off maximizing solution strategies (Dontcheva, Gerber, & Lewis, 2011 ; Kittur, 2010 ; Oppenlaender, Milland, Visuri, Ipeirotis, & Hosio, 2020 ). Volunteer-based outside-of the-lab studies, in which participants contribute at their own leisure (e.g., using their phone or computer), allow for millions of participants, but at the cost of losing some of the control over the testing environment. Fully understanding and finding ways of overcoming this loss of control represents one of the most urgent challenges of volunteer-based outside-of-the-lab assessment.
### Input: What are the challenges and potential solutions for data collection in creativity tasks via paid platforms and volunteer-based outside-of-the-lab studies?
### Response: The challenges of data collection in creativity tasks via paid platforms include the high degree of open-endedness of these tasks, which makes it difficult to align scientifically productive and pay-off maximizing solution strategies. On the other hand, volunteer-based outside-of-the-lab studies, where participants contribute at their leisure, can involve millions of participants but may lose some control over the testing environment. The potential solutions to these challenges involve fully understanding and finding ways to overcome this loss of control, which is considered one of the most urgent challenges of volunteer-based outside-of-the-lab assessment.

column3: While another promising line of research, the methodological challenges of pursuing such an approach remain  daunting: (1) either the gameplay data is not freely available  or the appropriate data is not recorded in the log files, (2) in  order to achieve alignment with existing creativity research  either games with suitable subtasks have to be identified or  the game developers convinced to insert these modes into  the game, and finally, (3) in order to enable reliable testing  conditions in outside-of-the-lab studies, one would ideally  structure conditions so that many players go through  roughly the same dynamics, which is not necessarily in  agreement with commercial interests in maximizing player  freedom of choice and enjoyment.

Text: While another promising line of research, the methodological challenges of pursuing such an approach remain  daunting: (1) either the gameplay data is not freely available  or the appropriate data is not recorded in the log files, (2) in  order to achieve alignment with existing creativity research  either games with suitable subtasks have to be identified or  the game developers convinced to insert these modes into  the game, and finally, (3) in order to enable reliable testing  conditions in outside-of-the-lab studies, one would ideally  structure conditions so that many players go through  roughly the same dynamics, which is not necessarily in  agreement with commercial interests in maximizing player  freedom of choice and enjoyment.
### Input: What are some of the methodological challenges in pursuing research on gameplay data and its alignment with existing creativity research?
### Response: The methodological challenges in pursuing research on gameplay data and its alignment with existing creativity research include: (1) the difficulty in accessing the necessary gameplay data as it may not be freely available or the appropriate data may not be recorded in the log files, (2) the need to identify games with suitable subtasks that align with existing creativity research or convincing game developers to insert these modes into the game, and (3) the challenge of structuring conditions in outside-of-the-lab studies to ensure many players experience roughly the same dynamics, which may conflict with commercial interests in maximizing player freedom of choice and enjoyment.

column3: Game complexity and its relation to ecological- and  construct validity Next, game elements which support higher ecological-  and construct validity are considered. As discussed  above, well-designed digital games can facilitate the  ‘flow state’ when there are clear goals, immediate feedback and an appropriate balance between challenges and  skills (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997 ). The flow state is important for creating an environment which affords the creativity of the players so creativity can be assessed.  Additionally, just as researchers assert that multiple  tasks are needed to assess elements of creativity (Acar  & Runco, 2019 ; Cortes et al., 2019 ; Runco et al., 2016 ), it  can be asserted that progression through game levels,  modes and rounds are also needed in order for digital  games to supply sufficiently comprehensive and diverse  data to accurately and reliably assess creativity.

Text: Game complexity and its relation to ecological- and  construct validity Next, game elements which support higher ecological-  and construct validity are considered. As discussed  above, well-designed digital games can facilitate the  ‘flow state’ when there are clear goals, immediate feedback and an appropriate balance between challenges and  skills (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997 ). The flow state is important for creating an environment which affords the creativity of the players so creativity can be assessed.  Additionally, just as researchers assert that multiple  tasks are needed to assess elements of creativity (Acar  & Runco, 2019 ; Cortes et al., 2019 ; Runco et al., 2016 ), it  can be asserted that progression through game levels,  modes and rounds are also needed in order for digital  games to supply sufficiently comprehensive and diverse  data to accurately and reliably assess creativity.
### Input: How does the complexity of a game relate to its ecological and construct validity in assessing creativity?
### Response: The complexity of a game relates to its ecological and construct validity in assessing creativity by providing clear goals, immediate feedback, and an appropriate balance between challenges and skills. This facilitates the 'flow state' which is important for creating an environment that affords the creativity of the players. Additionally, the complexity of a game, through progression through game levels, modes and rounds, provides sufficiently comprehensive and diverse data to accurately and reliably assess creativity.

column3: In other words, although the possibility of a single, sufficiently  rich interaction can capture the creativity is not  excluded, a certain amount of “playful repetition,” and  a feeling of challenge is most likely needed in order to  reliably assess creativity at a single player level (El-Den,  Schneider, Mirzaei, & Carter, 2020 ). This aligns well  with how construct validity is inferred from gradually  accumulated data by a diversity of approaches (Messick,  1987 ). Taking the recommendation for multiple tasks  one step further, if properly managed, robust data sets  from suites of games could glean vastly more information on the complex process of creativity than any one  individual game or task alone. For instance, crea.blender  belongs to a suite of games that has been designed in  response to the call for portfolio-based assessment of  creativity (Rafner, 2021 ; Rafner et al., 2020 ). A major  challenge for such a suite would be ensuring sufficient  engagement and motivation so that it does not induce  testing fatigue and player disengagement (Lieberoth,  Pedersen, & Sherson, 2015 ).

column3: Out of the reviewed papers, only four games implemented progression (modal-, level-, or round- based)  explicitly in their design. This can be taken as an indication of the “prototype” level of many of the examined  games. The games without progression of any kind  simply presented the player with a task and ended either  when the task was completed or the time ran out (Hart  et al., 2017 ; Krebs et al., 2020 ; Rozenkrantz et al., 2017 ).  In contrast, Physics Playground (Shute & Rahimi, 2021 )  has an extensive standard playmode with level-based  progression, which scores creativity of the players  using stealth assessment. Additionally, it has a level editor mode, where participants can build their own levels,  which are scored by expert raters. Crea.blender (Rafner  et al., 2020 ) includes three modes, all with the same core  game mechanics (AI-enhanced image blending), but  different goals. Each of these modes are designed to  assess either DT, CT, or creative products. Similar to  Physics Playground, the ‘creative products’ mode is  envisioned to be assessed by human raters. Within the  CT mode, there are three levels, each increasing in  difficulty.

Text: Out of the reviewed papers, only four games implemented progression (modal-, level-, or round- based)  explicitly in their design. This can be taken as an indication of the “prototype” level of many of the examined  games. The games without progression of any kind  simply presented the player with a task and ended either  when the task was completed or the time ran out (Hart  et al., 2017 ; Krebs et al., 2020 ; Rozenkrantz et al., 2017 ).  In contrast, Physics Playground (Shute & Rahimi, 2021 )  has an extensive standard playmode with level-based  progression, which scores creativity of the players  using stealth assessment. Additionally, it has a level editor mode, where participants can build their own levels,  which are scored by expert raters. Crea.blender (Rafner  et al., 2020 ) includes three modes, all with the same core  game mechanics (AI-enhanced image blending), but  different goals. Each of these modes are designed to  assess either DT, CT, or creative products. Similar to  Physics Playground, the ‘creative products’ mode is  envisioned to be assessed by human raters. Within the  CT mode, there are three levels, each increasing in  difficulty.
### Input: What are some examples of games that have implemented progression in their design and how do they assess player creativity?
### Response: The text mentions two games that have implemented progression in their design. The first one is Physics Playground, which uses level-based progression. It assesses player creativity through stealth assessment in its standard play mode. Additionally, it has a level editor mode where players can create their own levels, which are then scored by expert raters. The second game is Crea.blender, which includes three modes with the same core game mechanics but different goals. Each mode is designed to assess either divergent thinking (DT), convergent thinking (CT), or creative products. Similar to Physics Playground, the 'creative products' mode is assessed by human raters. Within the CT mode, there are three levels, each increasing in difficulty.
