column3: (i.e., low convergent validity). Taken at face value, this  could imply a failure to capture the essence of creativity.  However, the authors report similarly low correlations  among the variety of standard tests they employed in the  study. Therefore, it can be seen that the low correlations  of the game metrics with standard values could be taken  as an indication of limited construct validity of the  standard tasks, or, as Runco et al. (2016 ) suggest, as an  indication that different standard tests capture different  aspects of creativity. The largest validation study,  Physics Playground (N = 167; Shute & Rahimi, 2021 )  reports similarly low convergent validity with standard  tests (r = 0.18). BuzzWords (Howell & Veale, 2009 ),  Arctic Quest (Chuang et al., 2015 ), and Immune  Defense (Krebs et al., 2020 ) stand out with reports of  higher correlation values (r > 0.5). This could indicate  that these approaches should be particularly promising  for creativity assessment. However, such an interpreta - tion should be moderated by both the lack of correlation  among standardized measures, combined with the low  participant numbers observed (N < 30) in games report - ing high correlation. Given all the above, these values  may simply indicate that the game-based interaction has  been in fact, successfully implemented to match the  particular processes of the selected reference task rather  than capturing the general underlying phenomenon of  creativity. We therefore recommend that convergent  validity be used in combination with other complemen - tary validity measures (e.g., ecological and construct) in  order to more deeply understand creativity.

column3: Mixed methods to assess and understand creativity All of the reviewed games in this study utilize stealth  assessment approaches (either implicitly or explicitly).  However, stealth assessment hinges on the ability to “(a)  define the claims concerning learners’ competencies, (b)  establish what represents valid evidence of a claim, and  (c) determine the kind of tasks or situations that will elicit  that evidence ” (Shute et al., 2016 , p. 2). That is, the  methodology involves a thorough literature review of  the competency that one wants to assess (e.g., creativity).  The deep review of the literature serves as the basis for  crafting a multifaceted, interconnected graphical repre - sentation of creativity. As we have discussed above, realiz - ing such established construct validity is by no means  a solved problem. This underscores the general call in  this paper to not only use games to assess creativity but  also to deeper understand creativity. This could poten - tially be achieved by combining well-structured tasks  tapping into CT and DT behavior and more free open-  ended exploration such as in the final modes of crea.  blender and Physics Playground.

column5:

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Mixed methods to assess and understand creativity All of the reviewed games in this study utilize stealth  assessment approaches (either implicitly or explicitly).  However, stealth assessment hinges on the ability to “(a)  define the claims concerning learners’ competencies, (b)  establish what represents valid evidence of a claim, and  (c) determine the kind of tasks or situations that will elicit  that evidence ” (Shute et al., 2016 , p. 2). That is, the  methodology involves a thorough literature review of  the competency that one wants to assess (e.g., creativity).  The deep review of the literature serves as the basis for  crafting a multifaceted, interconnected graphical repre - sentation of creativity. As we have discussed above, realiz - ing such established construct validity is by no means  a solved problem. This underscores the general call in  this paper to not only use games to assess creativity but  also to deeper understand creativity. This could poten - tially be achieved by combining well-structured tasks  tapping into CT and DT behavior and more free open-  ended exploration such as in the final modes of crea.  blender and Physics Playground.
### Input: What are the steps involved in the stealth assessment approach to understanding and assessing creativity in games, and how can this method be improved to better understand creativity?
### Response: The stealth assessment approach to understanding and assessing creativity in games involves three steps. First, it requires defining the claims concerning learners' competencies. Second, it involves establishing what represents valid evidence of a claim. Third, it determines the kind of tasks or situations that will elicit that evidence. This methodology also involves a thorough literature review of the competency that one wants to assess, such as creativity. The deep review of the literature serves as the basis for crafting a multifaceted, interconnected graphical representation of creativity. 

To improve this method and better understand creativity, the paper suggests not only using games to assess creativity but also to deepen the understanding of creativity. This could potentially be achieved by combining well-structured tasks that tap into convergent thinking (CT) and divergent thinking (DT) behavior and more free open-ended exploration such as in the final modes of creative blender and Physics Playground.

column3: The open-ended responses or products are typically not amenable to direct  algorithmic scoring and have therefore traditionally been  subject to expert consensual assessment. This methodol - ogy represents a major roadblock for the scaling up of  these kinds of initiatives. Building off of the literature around consensual assess - ment, crowdsourced peer rating of in-game produced  products may present a solution to this problem. When  gameplay is simple enough that anyone can learn within  a relatively short period of time to distinguish various  characteristics of a set of solutions/products, crowd - sourced peer assessment could be a promising method  for scalable creative product assessment. An example of  implementation of consensual assessment based on peer  feedback could be asking a player to rank on a Likert scale  how creative is a product (or solution) produced by  another player. It is recommended that such assessment  comes after a player has completed a tutorial/introduction  and has tried the game themself, so that they are aware of  how difficult/rare it is to make certain products. If crowd - sourced, these products could have many peer raters, with  a subset of products cross-validated by expert raters.  Crowdsourced assessment could be employed as long as  wording at the point of creation is identical to wording at  the point of rating (e.g., “Make a creative shape,” and  “Which shape is more creative?,” respectively). Notably,  peer assessment was not addressed in any of the reviewed  papers. Combining creativity information from products  via crowdsourcing and processes via stealth assessment  could possibly result in stronger construct validity of an  instrument.

### Response: The potential solution to the problem of algorithmic scoring of open-ended responses or products, as suggested in the text, is crowdsourced peer rating of in-game produced products. This method could be implemented by asking a player to rank on a Likert scale how creative a product (or solution) produced by another player is.

column3: Game-based Convergent Thinking assessment  warrants more attention As DT and CT are interwoven during creative cogni - tion, in many creativity assessments it may be difficult  to distinguish between the two constructs based on  task performance (Cortes et al., 2019 ). In other words  some game tasks may tap into both convergent and  divergent processes. Generally speaking, games with  an emphasis on solving concrete challenges with  a well-defined correct solution seem to lend them - selves well to capturing the CT process (selection of  and iteration on correct solutions). This is particularly  relevant as developing a robust, and non-verbal  assessment for CT is one of the bigger challenges in  the field. Notably, CT was under-explored compared  to DT in the reviewed games: two games assessing CT  (Howell & Veale, 2009 ; Rafner et al., 2020 ) versus nine  explicitly assessing DT (Ali et al., 2019 ; Chuang et al.,  2015 ; Gal et al., 2017 ; Hart et al., 2017 ; Krebs et al.,  2020 ; Rafner et al., 2020 ; Rozenkrantz et al., 2017 ; CREATIVITY RESEARCH JOURNAL  41

Text: Game-based Convergent Thinking assessment  warrants more attention As DT and CT are interwoven during creative cogni - tion, in many creativity assessments it may be difficult  to distinguish between the two constructs based on  task performance (Cortes et al., 2019 ). In other words  some game tasks may tap into both convergent and  divergent processes. Generally speaking, games with  an emphasis on solving concrete challenges with  a well-defined correct solution seem to lend them - selves well to capturing the CT process (selection of  and iteration on correct solutions). This is particularly  relevant as developing a robust, and non-verbal  assessment for CT is one of the bigger challenges in  the field. Notably, CT was under-explored compared  to DT in the reviewed games: two games assessing CT  (Howell & Veale, 2009 ; Rafner et al., 2020 ) versus nine  explicitly assessing DT (Ali et al., 2019 ; Chuang et al.,  2015 ; Gal et al., 2017 ; Hart et al., 2017 ; Krebs et al.,  2020 ; Rafner et al., 2020 ; Rozenkrantz et al., 2017 ; CREATIVITY RESEARCH JOURNAL  41
### Input: What challenges exist in developing a robust, non-verbal assessment for Convergent Thinking (CT) in game-based creativity assessments, and how does this compare to the assessment of Divergent Thinking (DT)?
### Response: The text suggests that one of the main challenges in developing a robust, non-verbal assessment for Convergent Thinking (CT) in game-based creativity assessments is distinguishing between CT and Divergent Thinking (DT) based on task performance. This is because some game tasks may tap into both convergent and divergent processes. Games that emphasize solving concrete challenges with a well-defined correct solution seem to be more suitable for capturing the CT process. However, the text also notes that CT has been under-explored compared to DT in the reviewed games, with only two games assessing CT versus nine explicitly assessing DT.

column3: Shillo et al., 2019 ; Shute & Rahimi, 2021 ; Voiskounsky  et al., 2017 ). As discussed in the introduction, this bias  toward DT assessment is common in current creativ - ity research. Crea.blender (Rafner et al., 2020 )  describes a visual CT mode, in which players are pre- sented with a target image and three sets of starting  images. The players must choose which set produced  the target image, and then recreate it. In contrast to  BuzzWords (Howell & Veale, 2009 ; 2010 ; Howell &  Veale, 2009 ), this task does not rely on the player’s  verbal skills for finding the right solution. However, it  relies heavily on the player’s ability to understand and  work with the mechanisms of the image-generating  algorithm, otherwise the player could not make  a correct prediction. The authors addressed this  exact issue in a small pilot study, and the results  suggest that participants are able to understand and  control the mechanics successfully (Rafner et al.,  2020 ), based on which, this could be a promising  approach for non-verbal CT assessment.

The players must choose which set produced  the target image, and then recreate it. In contrast to  BuzzWords (Howell & Veale, 2009 ; 2010 ; Howell &  Veale, 2009 ), this task does not rely on the player’s  verbal skills for finding the right solution. ### Input: What is the difference between the Crea.blender task and the BuzzWords task in terms of the skills they rely on, according to the text?
### Response: The Crea.blender task relies on the player's ability to understand and work with the mechanisms of the image-generating algorithm, while the BuzzWords task relies on the player's verbal skills to find the right solution.

column3: The  Creativity Game Based Evaluation System (Yeh et al.,  2016 ) employs insight problems which can measure  elements of both CT and DT; however, the particular  study only collects data on the correctness of the  responses, not the process itself. With appropriate  adaptations, insight problems could potentially be  a promising direction for achieving non-verbal CT  assessment. However, the importance of capturing  the process in addition to the correctness of the  response should be underscored in future studies.

Text: The  Creativity Game Based Evaluation System (Yeh et al.,  2016 ) employs insight problems which can measure  elements of both CT and DT; however, the particular  study only collects data on the correctness of the  responses, not the process itself. With appropriate  adaptations, insight problems could potentially be  a promising direction for achieving non-verbal CT  assessment. However, the importance of capturing  the process in addition to the correctness of the  response should be underscored in future studies.
### Input: What are the potential benefits and limitations of using the Creativity Game Based Evaluation System for assessing non-verbal CT, and how could future studies improve upon this method?
### Response: The Creativity Game Based Evaluation System has the potential to measure elements of both convergent thinking (CT) and divergent thinking (DT) through the use of insight problems. This could be beneficial for assessing non-verbal CT as it provides a different approach to traditional verbal assessments. However, a limitation of this system, as it currently stands, is that it only collects data on the correctness of the responses, not the process itself. This means it may not fully capture the depth and complexity of an individual's thinking process. Future studies could improve upon this method by adapting it to also capture the process of problem-solving, not just the final answer. This would provide a more comprehensive understanding of an individual's CT abilities.

column3: A call for interdisciplinary projects and dialogs In order to shed more light on the scientific disci - plines from which the selected papers originated,  a count was made of how many of papers had at  least one coauthor from the following disciplines:  computer science /engineering (8), other natural  science (4), education (6), psychology (8), and other  (4). Of course, disciplinary boundaries can vary and  not all affiliations were specified fully in the papers,  meaning that the reported numbers were in some  cases qualitative estimates. Still, accepting these clas- sifications and performing a slight aggregation, an  even split can be observed, following the traditional  division: education/psychology (10), all natural  science (10). Interestingly, only four papers were  assessed to have representatives of both of these  traditions. It can be speculated that the field of game-  based creativity assessment has so far primarily been  investigated in relatively narrowly defined scientific  contexts. This could explain the generally low participation numbers reported above. Any long-  term, scalable creativity assessment game could  greatly benefit from in-depth interdisciplinary com - munication and collaboration.

Interestingly, only four papers were  assessed to have representatives of both of these  traditions. ### Input: What does the even split between education/psychology and all natural science in the coauthorship of the selected papers suggest about the field of game-based creativity assessment?
### Response: The even split between education/psychology and all natural science in the coauthorship of the selected papers suggests that the field of game-based creativity assessment has been investigated primarily within these specific scientific contexts. However, there has been limited interdisciplinary collaboration and communication, as evidenced by the low number of papers with representatives from both traditions. This could potentially limit the scope and applicability of the research in this field.

column3: Additionally, none of the papers found during this  review were published in the Creativity Research  Journal, or Journal of Creative Behavior which “pub - lish the most studies on creativity and were cited the  most in the field” (Long, Plucker, Yu, Ding, &  Kaufman, 2014 as seen in Long, 2014 ) or  Philosophy, Esthetics, Psychology and the Arts  which is a relatively new but prominent journal in  the field (Long, 2014 ). This highlights a need for  facilitating interdisciplinary dialogs between funda - mental research on the constructs of creativity,  assessment considerations, and those designing new  innovative assessment instruments, which is by no  means an easy task. However, it is a goal of this  paper to encourage greater cooperation between  those conducting fundamental research on creativity,  its assessment, and those designing new innovative  assessment instruments. These collaborations are  necessary to address the grand challenge of achieving  large-scale, psychometrically stringent creativity  assessment.

### Input: What is the importance of interdisciplinary dialogues between fundamental research on creativity, assessment considerations, and those designing new innovative assessment instruments in achieving large-scale, psychometrically stringent creativity assessment?
### Response: The text suggests that interdisciplinary dialogues between fundamental research on creativity, assessment considerations, and those designing new innovative assessment instruments are important in achieving large-scale, psychometrically stringent creativity assessment because they can facilitate greater cooperation and collaboration. This is necessary to address the challenge of creating robust and comprehensive assessments of creativity. Without such dialogues, there may be gaps in understanding and application, which could limit the effectiveness and accuracy of creativity assessments.

column3: Conclusions and future directions This article set out to review how digital games have been  used to assess creativity and in particular investigate if  they are already or could potentially be used to combine  scalability of process-oriented assessments with the more  ecologically valid but much less scalable product-oriented  assessments of creativity. The games presented in this  paper not only span a range of disciplines and experi - mental settings, but also a range of game design decisions,  research approach and data analysis. The review portrays  a clear interest in and potential for digital games to assess  creativity. However, the small number of studies indicates  the infancy of the field. Many of the studies in this review  have been conducted by natural or social science teams,  which allows for speculations that at this nascent stage,  the field is dominated by explorative and domain specific  endeavors rather than displaying the strong interdisci - plinary dialogue between computer and social sciences,  which could be an important step to reach scalability.  Scalability is one element that is crucial both to under - stand creativity and to subsequently assess it. As projects  grow in depth and scale, another challenge emerges: it will  be unfeasible to perform expert consensual assessment of  in-game produced products. Further efforts to algorith - mic assessment of such products as well as explorations 42  J. RAFNER ET AL.

Further efforts to algorith - mic assessment of such products as well as explorations 42  J. RAFNER ET AL.
### Input: What steps can be taken to improve the scalability of creativity assessment in digital games and foster interdisciplinary dialogue between computer and social sciences?
### Response: The text suggests that further efforts towards algorithmic assessment of in-game produced products could improve the scalability of creativity assessment in digital games. Additionally, fostering interdisciplinary dialogue between computer and social sciences could be an important step towards scalability and understanding creativity.

column3: Investigations into crowdsourced peer consensual assessment should thus be identified. Promising trends have been identified such as automated assessment using e.g., Bayesian Networks (Shute et al., 2021) and semantic-based natural language processing algorithms (Beaty & Johnson, 2021) as well as in-task AI-assistance to ideally facilitate the creation of unique products without relying on prior domain-specific skills or excessive time commitment (Rafner et al., 2020).

### Input: What are some promising trends identified in investigations into crowdsourced peer consensual assessment?
### Response: Some promising trends identified in investigations into crowdsourced peer consensual assessment include automated assessment using Bayesian Networks and semantic-based natural language processing algorithms, as well as in-task AI-assistance to facilitate the creation of unique products without relying on prior domain-specific skills or excessive time commitment.

column3: Although the games as a whole cover both procedural creativity elements like CT and DT as well as modes that allow for open ended solution search and/or product generation, most studies have prioritized systematic comparisons with traditional (DT) tasks. As established construct validity is by no means a solved problem, convergent validity efforts cannot stand alone. This review therefore highlights the potential of digital games to help build a sufficiently solid methodological foundation of the increasingly complex interactions to foster novel insights into the nature of creativity. To obtain this, various game modes should ideally be aggregated to a comprehensive suite of games exhibiting a diversity of interaction forms and contexts.

As established construct validity is by no means a solved problem, convergent validity efforts cannot stand alone. This review therefore highlights the potential of digital games to help build a sufficiently solid methodological foundation of the increasingly complex interactions to foster novel insights into the nature of creativity. To obtain this, various game modes should ideally be aggregated to a comprehensive suite of games exhibiting a diversity of interaction forms and contexts. 
### Input: What potential do digital games have in building a solid methodological foundation for understanding the nature of creativity?
### Response: The text suggests that digital games have the potential to help build a sufficiently solid methodological foundation for understanding the increasingly complex interactions that foster creativity. This can be achieved by aggregating various game modes to create a comprehensive suite of games that exhibit a diversity of interaction forms and contexts.

column3: In conclusion, many important steppingstones toward scalable game-based assessment have been identified in the reviewed papers. At the same time, this review also highlights many of the unsolved challenges that lie ahead.

### Input: What does the term "ecological validity" refer to in the context of data collection from an experiment?
### Response: In the context of data collection from an experiment, "ecological validity" refers to the degree to which the data reflects real-life behavior and the extent to which the findings can be generalized to real-life settings. It is dependent on the testing environment.

Only one set can produce the exact target image, and players’ objective is first to  determine which set was used to create the target image (up to 30 seconds), and then to recreate their closest  approximation of the target image (up to three min). Text: Appendix B Additional tables Table B1. Game instructions. Game Instructions crea.blender (Rafner et al., 2020 ,  p. 341)(1) Creatures: (Figure 2) Players are presented with six images and are asked to create and save as many different  “animal-like” figures as possible in five minutes.(2)Challenge:(Figure 3) Players are presented with a target image and  three sets of three source images. Only one set can produce the exact target image, and players’ objective is first to  determine which set was used to create the target image (up to 30 seconds), and then to recreate their closest  approximation of the target image (up to three min). There are three levels in the Challenge mode.(3)Open Play:  (Figure 2) Players are presented with the same six source images as they used in Creatures mode. However, now they  are asked to create any image (not just animal-like) they find interesting during five minutes of playtime.
### Input: What are the three modes of the game described in the instructions by Rafner et al., 2020, and what are the objectives of each mode?
### Response: The three modes of the game described in the instructions by Rafner et al., 2020 are Creatures, Challenge, and Open Play. 

In the Creatures mode, players are presented with six images and are asked to create and save as many different "animal-like" figures as possible within five minutes. 

In the Challenge mode, players are presented with a target image and three sets of three source images. The objective is to first determine which set was used to create the target image within 30 seconds, and then to recreate their closest approximation of the target image within three minutes. There are three levels in this mode. 

In the Open Play mode, players are presented with the same six source images as they used in Creatures mode. However, in this mode, they are asked to create any image they find interesting during five minutes of playtime.

column3: Droodle (Ali et al., 2019 , pg. 32) The robot explains the gameplay to the participants: ‘I have a fun game for you today. Do you want to play with me? Do  you like telling stories? We will look at some pictures, and try to think of funny and creative ideas about what they  are. Let your imagination run wild. Come up with as many ideas as you can in 30 seconds. Let me show you an  example.’ The tablet app displays an example droodle selected from our library of Droodles, and the robot responds  with a Droodle title. After the example Droodle, the robot asks, ‘Are you ready to start the game?’ The participants  can respond with a ‘Yes’ or a ‘No’ both through speech and through buttons on the robot’s screen. If the participants  respond with a ‘Yes,’ then the robot begins the game. If the participants respond with a ‘No,’ then the robot proceeds  to provide a second example Droodle. If the participants respond with ‘No’ more than once, experimenters intervene  to help the participants understand the game until they are ready to play.

column3: Minecraft (Voiskounsky et al., 2017 ,  p. 151)Please build a ship/a house which you have never seen. Try to make it as unique, un-usual, and original as possible. You  can build whatever you want. There are no special requirements about the structure and shape of the construction.  Activate the potential of your imagination, throw away all barriers and limitations, and just do it! Upon the  completion of the task, please assign an unusual name to the constructed object. Please verbalize aloud everything  you are doing at the moment, articulate all your intentions concerning the task, and–this is especially important–  express verbally all the ideas you produce. Try to accomplish the mission within one hour. Upon the completion of  the mission, please give a guided tour of your house (or your ship) and tell a short story about it.

column3: We link dispersed knowledge on Open Innovation,  Open Science, and related concepts such as Responsible  Research and Innovation by proposing a unifying Open  Innovation in Science (OIS) Research Framework. This framework  captures the antecedents, contingencies, and consequences of  open and collaborative practices along the entire process of  generating and disseminating scientific insights and translating  them into innovation. Moreover, it elucidates individual-, team-,  organisation-, field-, and society-level factors shaping OIS prac - tices.

column3: 1.Introduction The purpose of scientific research is to produce reliable knowledge and work towards  understanding and solving societal, technical, and environmental challenges (Stokes  2011 ; Bush 1945 ). As these problems increase in complexity, they demand more creative  solutions, highlighting the need for open and collaborative practices that involve non-  scientific actors such as citizens, companies, and policymakers, as well as scientists from  a range of institutions and disciplinary backgrounds (Jones, Wuchty, and Uzzi 2008 ; Van  Noorden 2015 ; Ledford 2015 ).

Text: 1.Introduction The purpose of scientific research is to produce reliable knowledge and work towards  understanding and solving societal, technical, and environmental challenges (Stokes  2011 ; Bush 1945 ). As these problems increase in complexity, they demand more creative  solutions, highlighting the need for open and collaborative practices that involve non-  scientific actors such as citizens, companies, and policymakers, as well as scientists from  a range of institutions and disciplinary backgrounds (Jones, Wuchty, and Uzzi 2008 ; Van  Noorden 2015 ; Ledford 2015 ). 
### Input: What is the importance of open and collaborative practices involving non-scientific actors in solving complex societal, technical, and environmental challenges?
### Response: The text suggests that the importance of open and collaborative practices involving non-scientific actors in solving complex societal, technical, and environmental challenges lies in the need for more creative solutions. As these problems increase in complexity, they require a diverse range of perspectives and expertise. Involving citizens, companies, policymakers, and scientists from various institutions and disciplines can potentially lead to more innovative and effective solutions.

column3: More efficient and effective ways to foster openness and collaboration in science have  long been discussed. Anticipated in early work by critics demanding a more ‘social  orientation of science’ (Schroyer 1984 , 715), new context-driven modes of knowledge  production have developed that are centrally concerned with solving societal problems  and are therefore more likely to transgress traditional disciplinary boundaries or distinc - tions between academic and applied research (Gibbons et al. 1994 ). Taking stock of these  shifts, Dasgupta and David (1994 ) formulated a ‘new economics of science’, today one of  the cornerstones of our understanding of the mechanisms of scientific openness and  collaboration. However, changing conditions both within science (e.g. increased compe - tition for permanent positions, increased specialisation, the globalisation of the scientific  workforce) and outside of it (e.g. professionalisation of non-scientific actors, calls for  public engagement and the democratisation of science, policy-driven agenda setting,  global crises such as the COVID-19 outbreak) require a novel approach to thinking about INDUSTRY AND INNOVATION  137

Text: More efficient and effective ways to foster openness and collaboration in science have  long been discussed. Anticipated in early work by critics demanding a more ‘social  orientation of science’ (Schroyer 1984 , 715), new context-driven modes of knowledge  production have developed that are centrally concerned with solving societal problems  and are therefore more likely to transgress traditional disciplinary boundaries or distinc - tions between academic and applied research (Gibbons et al. 1994 ). Taking stock of these  shifts, Dasgupta and David (1994 ) formulated a ‘new economics of science’, today one of  the cornerstones of our understanding of the mechanisms of scientific openness and  collaboration. However, changing conditions both within science (e.g. increased compe - tition for permanent positions, increased specialisation, the globalisation of the scientific  workforce) and outside of it (e.g. professionalisation of non-scientific actors, calls for  public engagement and the democratisation of science, policy-driven agenda setting,  global crises such as the COVID-19 outbreak) require a novel approach to thinking about INDUSTRY AND INNOVATION  137
### Input: What are some of the changing conditions within and outside of science that require a novel approach to fostering openness and collaboration in the field?
### Response: Within science, some of the changing conditions include increased competition for permanent positions, increased specialisation, and the globalisation of the scientific workforce. Outside of science, the changing conditions include the professionalisation of non-scientific actors, calls for public engagement and the democratisation of science, policy-driven agenda setting, and global crises such as the COVID-19 outbreak.

column3: The antecedents, contingencies, and consequences of openness and collaboration in science in a more integrated way. One domain in which these issues are being worked out by researchers and practitioners alike is that of Open Science (OS). OS can be understood as an umbrella term encompassing a variety of assumptions about knowledge production and dissemination (Fecher et al. 2017). The three pillars of OS are accessibility (e.g. open access to publications and research data), transparency (e.g. reproducibility of results, open peer review), and inclusivity (e.g. citizen science) (Vicente-Sáez and Martínez-Fuentes 2018). While the first and most broadly accepted two focus on access to existing scientific outputs and processes, only the third envisions opening up the knowledge production process itself.
column4: Beck et al. - 2022 - The Open Innovation in Science research field a c
column5:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: The antecedents, contingencies, and consequences of openness and collaboration in science in a more integrated way. One domain in which these issues are being worked out by researchers and practitioners alike is that of Open Science (OS). OS can be understood as an umbrella term encompassing a variety of assumptions about knowledge production and dissemination (Fecher et al. 2017). The three pillars of OS are accessibility (e.g. open access to publications and research data), transparency (e.g. reproducibility of results, open peer review), and inclusivity (e.g. citizen science) (Vicente-Sáez and Martínez-Fuentes 2018). While the first and most broadly accepted two focus on access to existing scientific outputs and processes, only the third envisions opening up the knowledge production process itself.
### Input: What are the three pillars of Open Science and how do they contribute to the knowledge production and dissemination process?
### Response: The three pillars of Open Science (OS) are accessibility, transparency, and inclusivity. Accessibility refers to open access to publications and research data, which allows for the wider dissemination of scientific outputs. Transparency, which includes reproducibility of results and open peer review, ensures that the scientific process is open and accountable, contributing to the credibility and reliability of the knowledge produced. Inclusivity, such as citizen science, opens up the knowledge production process itself, allowing for a broader range of contributors and perspectives in the scientific process. This not only democratizes science, but also potentially enriches the knowledge produced.

column3: Even as members of many scientific communities have promoted public participation in science to varying degrees (Lengwiler 2008; Strasser et al. 2019), the core processes of scientific discovery generally remain closed to outsiders. This feature of scientific knowledge production has received comparatively little attention within the OS research field. However, open and collaborative approaches at earlier stages of the scientific research process are increasingly being discussed, suggesting an evolution and expansion of OS priorities (Beck et al. 2019; Chan et al. 2019; Hossain, Dwivedi, and Rana 2016; Nature editorial 2018; Woelfle, Olliaro, and Todd 2011).

Text: Even as members of many scientific communities have promoted public participation in science to varying degrees (Lengwiler 2008; Strasser et al. 2019), the core processes of scientific discovery generally remain closed to outsiders. This feature of scientific knowledge production has received comparatively little attention within the OS research field. However, open and collaborative approaches at earlier stages of the scientific research process are increasingly being discussed, suggesting an evolution and expansion of OS priorities (Beck et al. 2019; Chan et al. 2019; Hossain, Dwivedi, and Rana 2016; Nature editorial 2018; Woelfle, Olliaro, and Todd 2011).
### Input: What is the current trend in the scientific research process regarding open and collaborative approaches, and how does it suggest an evolution and expansion of Open Science priorities?
### Response: The current trend in the scientific research process is increasingly discussing open and collaborative approaches at earlier stages. This suggests an evolution and expansion of Open Science (OS) priorities as it indicates a shift from the traditional closed processes of scientific discovery to more inclusive and participatory methods. This could potentially lead to a broader engagement in science, fostering innovation and accelerating scientific discovery.

column3: Another domain of research and practice focused on openness and collaboration in knowledge production is that of Open Innovation (OI). Originally discussed in the context of changing research and development strategies at private-sector firms (Chesbrough 2003), OI has since been defined more generally as a distributed innovation process based on purposively managed knowledge flows across organisational and sectoral boundaries using pecuniary or nonpecuniary mechanisms (Bogers et al. 2017). OI entails a paradigm shift towards open and collaborative processes that increasingly displace and compete with producer-driven innovation, through practices that can take place outside (Baldwin and Von Hippel 2011) and between organisational boundaries (Chesbrough and Bogers 2014). OI practices embrace different inbound, outbound, and coupled processes for facilitating knowledge flows across boundaries with the purpose of generating innovations. Such practices include, but are not limited to, co-creating innovation between firms, lead users and user innovation communities, open-source software/hardware development, crowdsourcing and crowdfunding, patenting and licensing, or R&D collaborations (Dahlander and Gann 2010; Grimpe and Kaiser 2010; Jeppesen and Frederiksen 2006; Laursen and Salter 2006; Lilien et al. 2002; Poetz and Schreier 2012; Von Hippel and Von Krogh 2003).
column4: Beck et al. - 2022 - The Open Innovation in Science research field a c

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Another domain of research and practice focused on openness and collaboration in knowledge production is that of Open Innovation (OI). Originally discussed in the context of changing research and development strategies at private-sector firms (Chesbrough 2003), OI has since been defined more generally as a distributed innovation process based on purposively managed knowledge flows across organisational and sectoral boundaries using pecuniary or nonpecuniary mechanisms (Bogers et al. 2017). OI entails a paradigm shift towards open and collaborative processes that increasingly displace and compete with producer-driven innovation, through practices that can take place outside (Baldwin and Von Hippel 2011) and between organisational boundaries (Chesbrough and Bogers 2014). OI practices embrace different inbound, outbound, and coupled processes for facilitating knowledge flows across boundaries with the purpose of generating innovations. Such practices include, but are not limited to, co-creating innovation between firms, lead users and user innovation communities, open-source software/hardware development, crowdsourcing and crowdfunding, patenting and licensing, or R&D collaborations (Dahlander and Gann 2010; Grimpe and Kaiser 2010; Jeppesen and Frederiksen 2006; Laursen and Salter 2006; Lilien et al. 2002; Poetz and Schreier 2012; Von Hippel and Von Krogh 2003).
### Input: What are some practices associated with Open Innovation for facilitating knowledge flows across boundaries to generate innovations?
### Response: Some practices associated with Open Innovation for facilitating knowledge flows across boundaries to generate innovations include co-creating innovation between firms, lead users and user innovation communities, open-source software/hardware development, crowdsourcing and crowdfunding, patenting and licensing, and R&D collaborations.

column3: As a complement to the focus on later stages of the scientific research process in OS, OI emphasises processes and logics of exchange in the early and intermediary steps of knowledge production. Of late, OI-influenced researchers have specifically explored these dynamics in the context of science (Beck et al. 2020; Franzoni and Sauermann 2014; Guinan, Boudreau, and Lakhani 2013; Lifshitz-Assaf 2018), extending the linkages between OI and the science context beyond different forms of technology transfer (Chesbrough 2020; Egelie et al. 2019; Perkmann et al. 2013).

Text: As a complement to the focus on later stages of the scientific research process in OS, OI emphasises processes and logics of exchange in the early and intermediary steps of knowledge production. Of late, OI-influenced researchers have specifically explored these dynamics in the context of science (Beck et al. 2020; Franzoni and Sauermann 2014; Guinan, Boudreau, and Lakhani 2013; Lifshitz-Assaf 2018), extending the linkages between OI and the science context beyond different forms of technology transfer (Chesbrough 2020; Egelie et al. 2019; Perkmann et al. 2013).

### Response: The text does not provide specific details on the early and intermediary steps of knowledge production that Open Innovation (OI) emphasizes in the context of scientific research.

column3: We argue that placing these concepts into relation helps us to form a more compre - hensive picture of the various factors shaping open and collaborative practices in science.  More specifically, we suggest that bringing together the complementary concepts of  Open Science and Open Innovation makes it possible to examine specific exchange  relationships and translation services between science and other sectors of society. To  better integrate these concepts, we propose the concept of Open Innovation in Science  (OIS) as a unifying foundation for advancing our understanding of antecedents, con- tingencies, and consequences related to applying open and collaborative research prac - tices along the entire process of generating and disseminating new scientific insights and  translating them into innovation.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: We argue that placing these concepts into relation helps us to form a more compre - hensive picture of the various factors shaping open and collaborative practices in science.  More specifically, we suggest that bringing together the complementary concepts of  Open Science and Open Innovation makes it possible to examine specific exchange  relationships and translation services between science and other sectors of society. To  better integrate these concepts, we propose the concept of Open Innovation in Science  (OIS) as a unifying foundation for advancing our understanding of antecedents, con- tingencies, and consequences related to applying open and collaborative research prac - tices along the entire process of generating and disseminating new scientific insights and  translating them into innovation.
### Input: What is the proposed concept of Open Innovation in Science (OIS) and how can it advance our understanding of the process of generating and disseminating new scientific insights and translating them into innovation?
### Response: The proposed concept of Open Innovation in Science (OIS) is a unifying foundation that integrates the complementary concepts of Open Science and Open Innovation. It is suggested to help examine specific exchange relationships and translation services between science and other sectors of society. OIS can advance our understanding of the process of generating and disseminating new scientific insights and translating them into innovation by providing a comprehensive picture of the various factors shaping open and collaborative practices in science. It can help us understand the antecedents, contingencies, and consequences related to applying open and collaborative research practices along the entire process.

column3: We define OIS as a process of purposively enabling,  initiating, and managing inbound, outbound, and coupled knowledge flows and (inter/  transdisciplinary1) collaboration across organisational and disciplinary boundaries and  along all stages of the scientific research process, from the formulation of research  questions and the obtainment of funding or development of methods (i.e. conceptualisa - tion) to data collection, data processing, and data analyses (exploration and/or testing)  and the dissemination of results through writing, translation into innovation, or other  forms of codifying scientific insight (i.e. documentation) (see Figure 1).

Text: We define OIS as a process of purposively enabling,  initiating, and managing inbound, outbound, and coupled knowledge flows and (inter/  transdisciplinary1) collaboration across organisational and disciplinary boundaries and  along all stages of the scientific research process, from the formulation of research  questions and the obtainment of funding or development of methods (i.e. conceptualisa - tion) to data collection, data processing, and data analyses (exploration and/or testing)  and the dissemination of results through writing, translation into innovation, or other  forms of codifying scientific insight (i.e. documentation) (see Figure 1).
### Input: What does the process of OIS involve in the stages of the scientific research process?
### Response: The process of OIS involves enabling, initiating, and managing knowledge flows and collaboration across organizational and disciplinary boundaries in all stages of the scientific research process. This includes the formulation of research questions, the obtainment of funding or development of methods (conceptualisation), data collection, data processing, and data analyses (exploration and/or testing), and the dissemination of results through writing, translation into innovation, or other forms of codifying scientific insight (documentation).

column3: To tackle the challenge of mapping this expansive research field, we took a multi-step  collaborative approach involving 47 scholars from the social sciences, humanities, and natural  sciences. Together, we worked to 1) jointly conceptualise the OIS Research Framework; 2) map  relevant literature streams defining the different elements, logics, and interdependencies to be  synthesised; and 3) write this article (see Appendix A for an overview of the entire process and  a reflection on the benefits and difficulties of using a collaborative approach).

Together, we worked to 1) jointly conceptualise the OIS Research Framework; 2) map  relevant literature streams defining the different elements, logics, and interdependencies to be  synthesised; and 3) write this article (see Appendix A for an overview of the entire process and  a reflection on the benefits and difficulties of using a collaborative approach).
### Input: What was the three-step collaborative approach taken by the 47 scholars from various fields to map the expansive research field?
### Response: The three-step collaborative approach taken by the 47 scholars from various fields to map the expansive research field involved 1) jointly conceptualising the OIS Research Framework; 2) mapping relevant literature streams defining the different elements, logics, and interdependencies to be synthesised; and 3) writing the article.

column3: As the principal output of this process, our article contributes to science, policy - making, practice, and society in at least three ways. First, employing an open and  collaborative approach allowed us to bridge disciplinary differences in terms of under - lying norms, theories, assumptions, methods, and languages. This interdisciplinary  approach made it possible to synthesise what dispersed fields within the scientific  community already know about open and collaborative research practices. Second,  integrating different perspectives provided a more comprehensive picture that identifies  robust results but also contradictions, tensions, and inconsistencies across scientific  fields. These highlight the need for methodologically diverse inquiry to better understand  the antecedents, boundary conditions, and consequences of open and collaborative  research. Third, structuring the knowledge about open and collaborative research  1While various definitions of inter- and transdisciplinary research refer to different constitutive elements (e.g. on the level  of knowledge integration, see Piaget 1972 ), we refer to interdisciplinary research in terms of crossing boundaries of  existing scientific disciplines and transdisciplinary research in terms of crossing the boundaries of the science system to  involve actors other than academic scientists such as citizens, companies, and policymakers.

Text: As the principal output of this process, our article contributes to science, policy - making, practice, and society in at least three ways. First, employing an open and  collaborative approach allowed us to bridge disciplinary differences in terms of under - lying norms, theories, assumptions, methods, and languages. This interdisciplinary  approach made it possible to synthesise what dispersed fields within the scientific  community already know about open and collaborative research practices. Second,  integrating different perspectives provided a more comprehensive picture that identifies  robust results but also contradictions, tensions, and inconsistencies across scientific  fields. These highlight the need for methodologically diverse inquiry to better understand  the antecedents, boundary conditions, and consequences of open and collaborative  research. Third, structuring the knowledge about open and collaborative research  1While various definitions of inter- and transdisciplinary research refer to different constitutive elements (e.g. on the level  of knowledge integration, see Piaget 1972 ), we refer to interdisciplinary research in terms of crossing boundaries of  existing scientific disciplines and transdisciplinary research in terms of crossing the boundaries of the science system to  involve actors other than academic scientists such as citizens, companies, and policymakers.
### Input: What are the three ways in which the article contributes to science, policy-making, practice, and society through its focus on open and collaborative research practices?
### Response: The article contributes in three ways. Firstly, it uses an open and collaborative approach to bridge disciplinary differences, synthesising knowledge from various scientific fields about open and collaborative research practices. Secondly, it integrates different perspectives to provide a comprehensive picture that identifies robust results as well as contradictions, tensions, and inconsistencies across scientific fields, highlighting the need for diverse inquiry. Thirdly, it structures the knowledge about open and collaborative research, crossing boundaries of existing scientific disciplines and involving actors other than academic scientists such as citizens, companies, and policymakers.

column3: In what follows, we introduce the OIS Research Framework and provide an overview of OIS practices (section 2.1.), multi-level antecedents to and contingencies for successfully implementing OIS practices (section 2.2.), and (intermediary) outcomes, as well as scientific and societal impacts of applying OIS practices (section 2.3.). In section 3, we outline major contributions from synthesising cross-disciplinary knowledge about open and collaborative scientific practices. Several areas for future research are then presented in section 4, before conclusions are offered in section 5.

column3: First, OIS practices occur at all stages of the scientific research process, from the formulation of research questions and the obtainment of funding and the development of methods (i.e. conceptualisation) to data collection, data processing, and data analyses (i.e. exploration and/or testing), as well as the dissemination of results through writing, translation into innovation or other forms of codifying scientific insight (documentation). Second, whether and under which circumstances these OIS practices can be successfully applied is influenced by contingencies and boundary conditions on multiple levels (i.e. individual, research team or group, organisation, discipline or field, and society or policy levels). These factors (considered independently and in combination) influence the application of OIS practices, as well as the outcomes and impacts they generate.

column3: We emphasise that it is important to take a balanced view that recognises contingency factors: we do not see openness and collaboration as ends in themselves, but as potentially powerful means for improving the novelty, efficiency, and societal impact of scientific research. However, the effectiveness of these approaches depends on the types of factors noted, such that open and collaborative approaches may not be suitable for every scientific undertaking. Third, OIS-based outcomes can ensue along the entire scientific research process (e.g. proposals, datasets, protocols, code, publications, patents, teaching materials, science-based innovations). These outcomes may have scientific and societal impacts , such as an accelerated response to novel diseases.2 Those impacts also 2For example, consider the role of open and collaborative practices in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. A groundswell of scientific knowledge-sharing across disciplinary, organisational, and national boundaries allowed for rapid and coordinated progress to be made (Apuzzo and Kirkpatrick 2020 ). Preprint servers like bioRxiv and medRxiv allowed researchers to report and evaluate findings quickly, while more than thirty scientific publishers agreed to make selected publications openly accessible for the duration of the crisis. And while do-it-yourself efforts to address shortages of medical devices and supplies were stymied at times by a lack of understanding of clinical needs (Zastrow 2020 ), these efforts to ‘hack the crisis’ also revealed societal reserves of insight and generosity that the science system has yet to fully tap.140  S. BECK ET AL.

A groundswell of scientific knowledge-sharing across disciplinary, organisational, and national boundaries allowed for rapid and coordinated progress to be made (Apuzzo and Kirkpatrick 2020 ). Preprint servers like bioRxiv and medRxiv allowed researchers to report and evaluate findings quickly, while more than thirty scientific publishers agreed to make selected publications openly accessible for the duration of the crisis. And while do-it-yourself efforts to address shortages of medical devices and supplies were stymied at times by a lack of understanding of clinical needs (Zastrow 2020 ), these efforts to ‘hack the crisis’ also revealed societal reserves of insight and generosity that the science system has yet to fully tap.140  S. ### Input: What are some of the potential benefits and limitations of open and collaborative approaches in scientific research, as discussed in the text?
### Response: The potential benefits of open and collaborative approaches in scientific research, as discussed in the text, include improving the novelty, efficiency, and societal impact of scientific research. They can also lead to outcomes along the entire scientific research process, such as proposals, datasets, protocols, code, publications, patents, teaching materials, and science-based innovations. These outcomes can have scientific and societal impacts, such as an accelerated response to novel diseases. An example given is the role of open and collaborative practices in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic, where knowledge-sharing allowed for rapid and coordinated progress. 

However, the text also notes that the effectiveness of these approaches depends on certain factors, and they may not be suitable for every scientific undertaking. For instance, do-it-yourself efforts to address shortages of medical devices and supplies during the COVID-19 pandemic were sometimes hindered by a lack of understanding of clinical needs.

column3: Include the identification of under-researched scientific and societal problems that are subsequently prioritised, thus feeding back to the starting point of scientific research. In what follows, we discuss each of these elements of the OIS Research Framework, moving from OIS practices (section 2.1.) and antecedents and boundary conditions (section 2.2.) to OIS-based outcomes and impacts (section 2.3.).

column5:

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Include the identification of under-researched scientific and societal problems that are subsequently prioritised, thus feeding back to the starting point of scientific research. In what follows, we discuss each of these elements of the OIS Research Framework, moving from OIS practices (section 2.1.) and antecedents and boundary conditions (section 2.2.) to OIS-based outcomes and impacts (section 2.3.). 
### Input: What are the elements of the OIS Research Framework and how do they contribute to the identification and prioritization of under-researched scientific and societal problems?
### Response: The text mentions three elements of the OIS (Open Innovation Science) Research Framework: OIS practices, antecedents and boundary conditions, and OIS-based outcomes and impacts. 

1. OIS Practices: These are the methods and approaches used in open innovation science. They could contribute to the identification and prioritization of under-researched scientific and societal problems by providing a platform for open collaboration and knowledge sharing. This could lead to the discovery of new research areas or highlight the need for more research in certain areas.

2. Antecedents and Boundary Conditions: These refer to the factors that influence the implementation and success of OIS practices. Understanding these conditions can help in identifying areas where there is a lack of research or where certain societal problems are not being adequately addressed. This can then lead to these areas being prioritized for further research.

3. OIS-based Outcomes and Impacts: These are the results and effects of implementing OIS practices. By evaluating these outcomes and impacts, researchers can identify which areas of science and society are benefiting from OIS and which are not. This can help in identifying under-researched areas and prioritizing them for future research.

In summary, the elements of the OIS Research Framework contribute to the identification and prioritization of under-researched scientific and societal problems by providing a structure for open collaboration, understanding the factors that influence research, and evaluating the outcomes of research practices.

These practices can involve academic scientists working on research within universities or other institutions. Additionally, individuals without formal scientific training, such as citizens, companies, or policymakers, can also be involved in these practices. Furthermore, scientific actors working outside of academia can also participate in OIS practices.

column3: 3We distinguish between scientists whose primary place of employment is an academic research organisation (i.e. universities and research institutes) and scientists who are independent or employed at other organisations including government agencies, non-profits, and companies with primarily commercial interests. We specifically do not make this distinction with respect to the value or quality of the scientific knowledge produced. However, we see it as relevant in the context of OIS, as academic and non-academic actors may be influenced by different institutional logics (e.g. importance of scientific publications for career advancement) that influence their decision-making and, in turn, their open and collaborative behaviour (Sauermann and Stephan 2013 ).INDUSTRY AND INNOVATION  141

However, we see it as relevant in the context of OIS, as academic and non-academic actors may be influenced by different institutional logics (e.g. importance of scientific publications for career advancement) that influence their decision-making and, in turn, their open and collaborative behaviour (Sauermann and Stephan 2013 ).INDUSTRY AND INNOVATION  141

### Response: The relevance of distinguishing between scientists employed at academic research organisations and those employed at non-academic institutions in the context of Open Innovation Science (OIS) is that these two groups may be influenced by different institutional logics. OIS practices involving academic scientists only OIS practices that exclusively involve academic scientists include collaborations across disciplinary and organisational boundaries (e.g. interdisciplinary, ‘big’, or distributed collaborations), as well as inbound and outbound knowledge flows such as data- and material-sharing and open access publishing. 
### Input: What are some examples of OIS practices that exclusively involve academic scientists?
### Response: Some examples of OIS practices that exclusively involve academic scientists include collaborations across disciplinary and organisational boundaries, data- and material-sharing, and open access publishing.

column3: 2.1.1.1. (Inter)disciplinary collaborations. The boundaries of discipline-based research are blurring, with important research questions lying at the intersection of traditional disciplines (Nowotny, Scott, and Gibbons 2006 ). Interdisciplinary research has been defined as ‘a mode of research by teams or individuals that integrates information, data, techniques, tools, perspectives, concepts, and/or theories from two or more disciplines or bodies of specialised knowledge to advance fundamental understanding or to solve problems whose solutions are beyond the scope of a single discipline or area of research practice’ (National Academy of Sciences, National Academy of Engineering, and Institute of Medicine 2005 , 2). The degree of knowledge integration from source disciplines varies from borrowing and contrasting to integrating and transcending existing bodies of knowledge (Miller 1982 ). Rafols and Meyer (2010 ) thus prefer to describe interdisciplinarity in terms of diversity and coherence, highlighting the breadth and novelty of knowledge integration. It can be difficult to establish when interdisciplinarity takes place, as cognitive overlaps make boundaries between and within disciplines difficult to identify. Thus, a more fine-grained classification for levels of interaction, for example from weak to full, may be suitable (Huutoniemi et al. 2010 ).

Text: 2.1.1.1. (Inter)disciplinary collaborations. The boundaries of discipline-based research are blurring, with important research questions lying at the intersection of traditional disciplines (Nowotny, Scott, and Gibbons 2006 ). Interdisciplinary research has been defined as ‘a mode of research by teams or individuals that integrates information, data, techniques, tools, perspectives, concepts, and/or theories from two or more disciplines or bodies of specialised knowledge to advance fundamental understanding or to solve problems whose solutions are beyond the scope of a single discipline or area of research practice’ (National Academy of Sciences, National Academy of Engineering, and Institute of Medicine 2005 , 2). The degree of knowledge integration from source disciplines varies from borrowing and contrasting to integrating and transcending existing bodies of knowledge (Miller 1982 ). Rafols and Meyer (2010 ) thus prefer to describe interdisciplinarity in terms of diversity and coherence, highlighting the breadth and novelty of knowledge integration. It can be difficult to establish when interdisciplinarity takes place, as cognitive overlaps make boundaries between and within disciplines difficult to identify. Thus, a more fine-grained classification for levels of interaction, for example from weak to full, may be suitable (Huutoniemi et al. 2010 ). 
### Input: What are the challenges in establishing when interdisciplinary research takes place and how can a more fine-grained classification for levels of interaction address these challenges?
### Response: The text suggests that the challenges in establishing when interdisciplinary research takes place lie in the cognitive overlaps that make boundaries between and within disciplines difficult to identify. A more fine-grained classification for levels of interaction, ranging from weak to full, could address these challenges by providing a more nuanced understanding of the degree of interdisciplinarity. This could help to distinguish between different degrees of knowledge integration from source disciplines, from borrowing and contrasting to integrating and transcending existing bodies of knowledge.

column3: 2.1.1.2. Shared scientific infrastructure. A special case of interdisciplinary collaboration are large-scale research infrastructures that provide scientists access to highly specialised instrumentation and experimental conditions beyond the reach of most research organisations. Experiments at such facilities require collaboration between permanent scientists and external users (Hallonsten 2016 ). This can range from short-lived interactions to highly complementary collaborations in which local instrument scientists and visiting scientist-users bring together needed expertise and skills (D’Ippolito and Rüling 2019 ). In this context, a culture of openness can emerge, with norms governing the allocation of credit for the resulting output. Long-term collaborations also help to advance the development of instruments themselves (Tuertscher, Garud, and Kumaraswamy 2014 ), facilitating interdisciplinary collaboration between actors who might not otherwise collaborate (Kaplan, Milde, and Cowan 2017 ). Prominent examples of large-scale or ‘big science’ collaborations include the Manhattan Project, the Human Genome Project, and the Large Hadron Collider experiments at the European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN). Such a shared infrastructure can facilitate or even necessitate the application of OIS practices.

### Input: How has the use of remote collaboration tools impacted the diversity and efficiency in scientific research and data collection, particularly in space physics?
### Response: The use of remote collaboration tools has significantly impacted the diversity and efficiency in scientific research and data collection, particularly in space physics. It has allowed for a more efficient use of expensive instruments and has expanded the number of potential participants in research tasks such as data collection by eliminating the need to travel to remote observatory sites. This has resulted in a more diverse range of participants in terms of experience and expertise.

column3: 2.1.1.3. Data and materials sharing. Another form that (interdisciplinary) scientific  collaboration takes is the sharing of intermediate research products. The ability to build  on existing knowledge depends on access not only to published findings, but also to  underlying data and materials such as cells and cultures used in prior research (e.g.  Andreoli-Versbach and Mueller-Langer 2014 ; Czarnitzki, Grimpe, and Pellens 2015 ;  Furman and Stern 2011 ; Mokyr 2002 ). Data sharing is thus an essential backstop for  the scientific principles of credibility and replication, allowing researchers to build more  quickly on prior work and allowing data sharers to achieve more visibility and impact  (Beck et al. 2019 ; Chan et al. 2019 ; Hossain, Dwivedi, and Rana 2016 ; Nature editorial  2018 ; Woelfle, Olliaro, and Todd 2011 ; Czarnitzki, Grimpe, and Pellens 2015 ; Borgman  2015 ). There are two primary paths for data sharing: voluntary data sharing via private  communication and public repositories (e.g. archives, federated data networks, virtual  observatories), and mandatory data disclosure in response to policies by journals (Rousi  and Laakso 2020 ) and funders (Andreoli-Versbach and Mueller-Langer 2014 ).

Text: 2.1.1.3. Data and materials sharing. Another form that (interdisciplinary) scientific  collaboration takes is the sharing of intermediate research products. The ability to build  on existing knowledge depends on access not only to published findings, but also to  underlying data and materials such as cells and cultures used in prior research (e.g.  Andreoli-Versbach and Mueller-Langer 2014 ; Czarnitzki, Grimpe, and Pellens 2015 ;  Furman and Stern 2011 ; Mokyr 2002 ). Data sharing is thus an essential backstop for  the scientific principles of credibility and replication, allowing researchers to build more  quickly on prior work and allowing data sharers to achieve more visibility and impact  (Beck et al. 2019 ; Chan et al. 2019 ; Hossain, Dwivedi, and Rana 2016 ; Nature editorial  2018 ; Woelfle, Olliaro, and Todd 2011 ; Czarnitzki, Grimpe, and Pellens 2015 ; Borgman  2015 ). There are two primary paths for data sharing: voluntary data sharing via private  communication and public repositories (e.g. archives, federated data networks, virtual  observatories), and mandatory data disclosure in response to policies by journals (Rousi  and Laakso 2020 ) and funders (Andreoli-Versbach and Mueller-Langer 2014 ). 
### Input: What are the two primary paths for data sharing in scientific research and how do they contribute to the principles of credibility and replication?
### Response: The two primary paths for data sharing in scientific research are voluntary data sharing via private communication and public repositories, and mandatory data disclosure in response to policies by journals and funders. These paths contribute to the principles of credibility and replication by providing access to underlying data and materials used in prior research. This allows researchers to build more quickly on prior work and enables data sharers to achieve more visibility and impact. Furthermore, data sharing serves as an essential backstop for these scientific principles, ensuring that the findings can be verified and replicated by other researchers.

column3: Costs for  preparing research data to be reused are high, limiting sharing behaviour even among  advocates (Fecher et al. 2017 ; Plantin 2019 ). These costs, including time to format,  annotate, and curate the data, as well as concerns over privacy, ‘scooping’, and misuse,  must be balanced against the promised efficiencies of data reuse (Pronk 2019 ). One way  to reduce these costs is by (real-time) storing and sharing of certain kinds of data  automatically, without the need for human intervention (Rouder 2016 ). Another relates  to the model of data science as a service (Grossman et al. 2016 ; Mishra, Schofield, and  Bubela 2016 ), in which scientists upload their data to cloud-based service providers that  may also offer some level of processing and analysis. Meanwhile, innovations like the  open materials transfer agreement developed by the BioBricks Foundation are providing  legal frameworks for research organisations to share biological materials on an open  basis.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: Costs for  preparing research data to be reused are high, limiting sharing behaviour even among  advocates (Fecher et al. 2017 ; Plantin 2019 ). These costs, including time to format,  annotate, and curate the data, as well as concerns over privacy, ‘scooping’, and misuse,  must be balanced against the promised efficiencies of data reuse (Pronk 2019 ). One way  to reduce these costs is by (real-time) storing and sharing of certain kinds of data  automatically, without the need for human intervention (Rouder 2016 ). Another relates  to the model of data science as a service (Grossman et al. 2016 ; Mishra, Schofield, and  Bubela 2016 ), in which scientists upload their data to cloud-based service providers that  may also offer some level of processing and analysis. Meanwhile, innovations like the  open materials transfer agreement developed by the BioBricks Foundation are providing  legal frameworks for research organisations to share biological materials on an open  basis.
### Input: What are some strategies to reduce the costs associated with preparing research data for reuse, and what are some potential benefits and concerns associated with these strategies?
### Response: The text suggests two strategies to reduce the costs associated with preparing research data for reuse. The first strategy is the real-time storing and sharing of certain kinds of data automatically, without the need for human intervention. The second strategy is the model of data science as a service, where scientists upload their data to cloud-based service providers that may also offer some level of processing and analysis. 

The potential benefits of these strategies include increased efficiency and reduced time and effort required to format, annotate, and curate the data. The use of cloud-based service providers could also provide additional services such as data processing and analysis. 

However, there are also concerns associated with these strategies. These include issues related to privacy, the risk of 'scooping' (where others use the data to publish results before the original researchers), and misuse of the data. Balancing these concerns against the potential efficiencies of data reuse is a key challenge.

column3: 2.1.1.4. Open publishing. Open flows of knowledge between academic scientists can  also be observed at the later stages of the research process, such as the dissemination of  research results on an open access basis. Open access is defined as ‘mak[ing] research  literature available online without price barriers and without most permission barriers’  (Suber 2012 , 8). Distinctions are made between ‘gold’ and ‘green’ routes to open access:  the former refers to research outputs that are freely available at the point of publication,  while the latter refers to semi-final versions made available by scientists themselves via  repositories and preprint servers like arXiv (European Commision 2020 ).

Text: 2.1.1.4. Open publishing. Open flows of knowledge between academic scientists can  also be observed at the later stages of the research process, such as the dissemination of  research results on an open access basis. Open access is defined as ‘mak[ing] research  literature available online without price barriers and without most permission barriers’  (Suber 2012 , 8). Distinctions are made between ‘gold’ and ‘green’ routes to open access:  the former refers to research outputs that are freely available at the point of publication,  while the latter refers to semi-final versions made available by scientists themselves via  repositories and preprint servers like arXiv (European Commision 2020 ). 
### Input: What are the differences between 'gold' and 'green' routes to open access in academic publishing?
### Response: The 'gold' route to open access refers to research outputs that are freely available at the point of publication. On the other hand, the 'green' route refers to semi-final versions of the research that are made available by the scientists themselves via repositories and preprint servers like arXiv.

column3: 2.1.2. OIS practices with actors other than academic scientists involved Academic engagement has been defined as ‘knowledge-related collaboration between  academic researchers and non-academic organisations’ (Perkmann et al. 2013 ). It repre - sents an important way to transfer scientific research beyond academic boundaries and to  gain novel insights. In this section, we discuss the role of actors other than academic  scientists (e.g. representatives of the public, industry, and politics) in the scientific  research process.

column3: 2.1.2.1. The general public as co-creator in the scientific research process. Historically,  the public understanding of science (Durant, Evans, and Thomas 1989 ) considered  scientists as bearers of knowledge and ‘lay’ citizens as recipients of a scientific education.  More recently, a more democratised model has emerged, in which the public is engaged  with science in a variety of ways. For example, in medicine, deeper interactions between  scientists and patients have increased the motivation of scientists to engage in innovation  activities (Llopis and D’Este 2016 ). Today, members of the public can co-create and  disseminate scientific research through practices such as citizen science or crowd science.  Although these practices are marked by some particularities (e.g. level and stage of  engagement), they have many similar elements (e.g. sourcing external knowledge).  Both can be considered promising approaches to organising science in that they increase  the scope of problems under investigation and multiply types of potential participants.
