Text: The analysis also revealed some limitations and challenges of the crea.visions experiment. As a case in point, participants experienced difficulty in manipulating certain aspects of the images, suggesting that improvements can be made in terms of AI interaction and control (Collective). Furthermore, participants encountered challenges when attempting to visualise abstract or complex problems compared to concrete problems (Context). 
### Input: What were some of the limitations and challenges participants faced during the crea.visions experiment in terms of AI interaction and visualizing abstract or complex problems?
### Response: Participants faced difficulties in manipulating certain aspects of the images, indicating a need for improvements in AI interaction and control. They also encountered challenges when trying to visualize abstract or complex problems as compared to concrete problems.

column3: Figure 5 shows an example of how a participant ideated on the image of the problem, “Health services in Paris are decreasing and many people are lacking health advice and security.” They commented that it was easy to visualise as “It is a very concrete problem that can be seen in Paris every day.” This is in contrast to Participant 28 who ideated on the image of the problem, “Educational practice, research and teacher training is often uncorrelated. As they are uncorrelated, a persistent gap exists between research and practice. ” P28 commented explicitly “ Maybe the problem was too abstract for being visualized easily. ”

Text: Figure 5 shows an example of how a participant ideated on the image of the problem, “Health services in Paris are decreasing and many people are lacking health advice and security.” They commented that it was easy to visualise as “It is a very concrete problem that can be seen in Paris every day.” This is in contrast to Participant 28 who ideated on the image of the problem, “Educational practice, research and teacher training is often uncorrelated. As they are uncorrelated, a persistent gap exists between research and practice. ” P28 commented explicitly “ Maybe the problem was too abstract for being visualized easily. ”
### Input: What were the differences in the participants' experiences when ideating on the images of the problems related to health services in Paris and the correlation between educational practice, research, and teacher training?
### Response: The differences in the participants' experiences when ideating on the images of the problems were related to the concreteness or abstractness of the problems. The participant who ideated on the problem of health services in Paris found it easy to visualize because it was a very concrete problem that could be seen every day. On the other hand, the participant who ideated on the problem of the correlation between educational practice, research, and teacher training found it difficult to visualize because it was too abstract.

column3: Finally, the AI-assisted image generation tool was perceived as a valuable resource for communicating ideas within a community (Community). This finding highlights the potential for AI image generation tools to facilitate collaborative problem-solving and improve idea sharing among diverse groups of individuals. Overall, the thematic analysis highlights the potential of AI- assisted image generation in CPS, while also shedding light on areas for improvement to better support the problem identification and construction process. As AI technology continues to evolve, these insights can guide the development of more effective and user-friendly tools for human-AI co-CPS.

This finding highlights the potential for AI image generation tools to facilitate collaborative problem-solving and improve idea sharing among diverse groups of individuals. Overall, the thematic analysis highlights the potential of AI- assisted image generation in CPS, while also shedding light on areas for improvement to better support the problem identification and construction process. As AI technology continues to evolve, these insights can guide the development of more effective and user-friendly tools for human-AI co-CPS. 
### Input: What potential does AI-assisted image generation hold for collaborative problem-solving and idea sharing among diverse groups, and how can these insights guide the development of more effective tools for human-AI co-CPS?
### Response: AI-assisted image generation holds the potential to facilitate collaborative problem-solving and improve idea sharing among diverse groups. It can serve as a valuable resource for communicating ideas within a community. The insights from the thematic analysis of its use can guide the development of more effective tools for human-AI co-CPS by highlighting areas for improvement. This can help in better supporting the problem identification and construction process. As AI technology continues to evolve, these insights can be used to make the tools more user-friendly and effective.

column3: 7 FUTURE WORK To build upon these findings, future research should explore several questions, such as how AI image generation influences the various phases of CPS and whether people use image generation similarly or differently in each phase. Additionally, potential next steps for analysis of the current data set include performing semantic analysis to examine participant exploration patterns, using thematic analysis to analyze survey responses related to the solution process, investigating descriptions of solutions and their correlations with self-reported levels of creative experience in the co-creation process, examining the image creation process (log data) and its connection to problem formulation and solution ideation, and developing a framework for structuring AI image generation to augment CPS across multiple steps. By addressing these future research questions and conducting further analyses, we can better inform the design and improvement of crea.visions and similar tools, ultimately helping to maximize the benefits of AI image generation in CPS.

column3: Picture This: AI-Assisted Image Generation as a Resource for Problem Construction in Creative Problem-Solving C&C ’23, June 19–21, 2023, Virtual Event, USA Figure 6: Participant 28’s progression towards a final image which represents their selected problem 8 LIMITATIONS AND CONCLUSIONS In this paper, we explored the role of AI-assisted visualization in the problem identification and construction phase of CPS. We examined this aspect through the lens of the ongoing crea.visions research project, a tool designed to visualize citizens’ visions of the future using AI technologies. Our findings demonstrated multiple potential entry points for visualization during the problem construction phase.

column3: However, there are several limitations to the study that should be acknowledged. First, the data collection environment was not controlled, which may have led to distractions and interruptions that impacted the quality of the data. Second, the process required participants to navigate multiple interfaces (crea.visions GAN, Sur- veyXact, and playground.ai), resulting in a somewhat cumbersome experience that might have affected immersion and enjoyment. Lastly, the limited image options available in crea.visions GAN were perceived as constraining factors for creative expression, enjoyment, and immersion.

Text: However, there are several limitations to the study that should be acknowledged. First, the data collection environment was not controlled, which may have led to distractions and interruptions that impacted the quality of the data. Second, the process required participants to navigate multiple interfaces (crea.visions GAN, Sur- veyXact, and playground.ai), resulting in a somewhat cumbersome experience that might have affected immersion and enjoyment. Lastly, the limited image options available in crea.visions GAN were perceived as constraining factors for creative expression, enjoyment, and immersion.
### Input: What were the limitations of the study involving the use of multiple interfaces and limited image options in crea.visions GAN?
### Response: The limitations of the study involving the use of multiple interfaces and limited image options in crea.visions GAN were that the process was somewhat cumbersome, which might have affected the participants' immersion and enjoyment. Additionally, the limited image options available were perceived as constraining factors for creative expression, enjoyment, and immersion.

column3: Despite these limitations, we argue that this study contributes to the CPS research field by investigating the potential applications of text-to-image AI-assisted image generation tools during the problem construction phase of CPS. In conclusion, the findings of this research offer a solid foundation for future work on AI- assisted image generation as a resource in CPS, paving the way for the development of more effective and user-friendly tools that can enhance the problem construction process.

column3: Rapid individual cognitive phenotyping holds the potential to revolutionize domains as wide-ranging as personalized learning, employment practices, and precision psychiatry. Going beyond limitations imposed by traditional lab-based experiments, new efforts have been underway toward greater ecological validity and participant diversity to capture the full range of individual differences in cognitive abilities and behaviors across the general population. Building on this, we developed Skill Lab, a novel game-based tool that simultaneously assesses a broad suite of cognitive abilities while providing an engaging narrative. Skill Lab consists of six mini-games as well as 14 established cognitive ability tasks. Using a popular citizen science platform ( N=10,725), we conducted a comprehensive validation in the wild of a game-based cognitive assessment suite. Based on the game and validation task data, we constructed reliable models to simultaneously predict eight cognitive abilities based on the users’ in-game behavior. Follow-up validation tests revealed that the models can discriminate nuances contained within each separate cognitive ability as well as capture a shared main factor of generalized cognitive ability. Our game-based measures are ﬁve times faster to complete than the equivalent task-based measures and replicate previous ﬁndings on the decline of certain cognitive abilities with age in our large cross-sectional population sample ( N=6369). Taken together, our results demonstrate the feasibility of rapid in-the-wild systematic assessment of cognitive abilities as a promising ﬁrst step toward population-scale benchmarking and individualized mental health diagnostics.

Going beyond limitations imposed by traditional lab-based experiments, new efforts have been underway toward greater ecological validity and participant diversity to capture the full range of individual differences in cognitive abilities and behaviors across the general population. Building on this, we developed Skill Lab, a novel game-based tool that simultaneously assesses a broad suite of cognitive abilities while providing an engaging narrative. Skill Lab consists of six mini-games as well as 14 established cognitive ability tasks. Using a popular citizen science platform ( N=10,725), we conducted a comprehensive validation in the wild of a game-based cognitive assessment suite. Based on the game and validation task data, we constructed reliable models to simultaneously predict eight cognitive abilities based on the users’ in-game behavior. Our game-based measures are ﬁve times faster to complete than the equivalent task-based measures and replicate previous ﬁndings on the decline of certain cognitive abilities with age in our large cross-sectional population sample ( N=6369). column3: Introduction: Individual cognitive phenotyping holds the potential to revolutionize domains as wide-ranging as personalized learning, employment practices, and precision psychiatry. To get there, it will require us to rethink how we study and measure cognitive abilities. Much of what cognitive and behavioral scientists know about cognitive abilities and psychological behavior has been gleaned from studying small, homogeneous groups in the laboratory. Recent pushes to increase the number and diversity of participants (Bauer, 2020) are revolutionizing standards for power and generalizability across the cognitive and behavioral sciences. These advances have been enabled in part by moving from in-person testing to online equivalents, which are less costly for experimenters and more convenient for participants (Birnbaum, 2004). The maturation of these tools will be critical to realizing the promise of individual cognitive phenotyping, customizable diagnostics, and a revamp of intelligence research in general.

Text: Introduction: Individual cognitive phenotyping holds the potential to revolutionize domains as wide-ranging as personalized learning, employment practices, and precision psychiatry. To get there, it will require us to rethink how we study and measure cognitive abilities. Much of what cognitive and behavioral scientists know about cognitive abilities and psychological behavior has been gleaned from studying small, homogeneous groups in the laboratory. Recent pushes to increase the number and diversity of participants (Bauer, 2020) are revolutionizing standards for power and generalizability across the cognitive and behavioral sciences. These advances have been enabled in part by moving from in-person testing to online equivalents, which are less costly for experimenters and more convenient for participants (Birnbaum, 2004). The maturation of these tools will be critical to realizing the promise of individual cognitive phenotyping, customizable diagnostics, and a revamp of intelligence research in general.
### Input: What role does online testing play in the advancement of individual cognitive phenotyping and intelligence research?
### Response: Online testing plays a significant role in the advancement of individual cognitive phenotyping and intelligence research by enabling the inclusion of a larger and more diverse group of participants. This increases the power and generalizability of the studies. Online testing is also less costly for experimenters and more convenient for participants, which further facilitates the expansion and diversification of the participant pool. The maturation of these online tools is critical to realizing the potential of individual cognitive phenotyping, customizable diagnostics, and a revamp of intelligence research.

column3: Going online with more convenient digital versions of traditional tasks makes it possible to scale up participant recruitment via crowdsourcing. Examples include projects, such as LabintheWild (Reinecke & Gajos, 2015), Volunteer Science (Radford et al., 2016), and Test-MyBrain (Germine et al., 2012), which offer a broad suite of digitized tasks from cognitive and behavioral science to volunteers from the general public. The success of these scientiﬁc platforms’ in crowdsourcing data from customizable tasks has established them as a fruitful alternative to laboratory studies.

column3: M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) 3o f2 7 Online digital participation also allows for the possibility of developing novel forms of cog-nitive assessment that are gamiﬁed. Gamiﬁed assessment offers the potential to engage largerand more diverse participant pools in cognitive experiments than traditional tasks and, thus,ampliﬁes the beneﬁts of online crowdsourcing (Baniqued et al., 2013; Lumsden, Edwards,Lawrence, Coyle, & Munafò, 2016). Part of the allure of adding the gamiﬁed assessmentto crowdsourcing is that it motivates players by framing the activity as an entertaining andplayful way to contribute to a meaningful scientiﬁc question (Jennett et al., 2014; Sagarra,Gutiérrez-Roig, Bonhoure, & Perelló, 2016).

Gamiﬁed assessment offers the potential to engage largerand more diverse participant pools in cognitive experiments than traditional tasks and, thus,ampliﬁes the beneﬁts of online crowdsourcing (Baniqued et al., 2013; Lumsden, Edwards,Lawrence, Coyle, & Munafò, 2016). Part of the allure of adding the gamiﬁed assessmentto crowdsourcing is that it motivates players by framing the activity as an entertaining andplayful way to contribute to a meaningful scientiﬁc question (Jennett et al., 2014; Sagarra,Gutiérrez-Roig, Bonhoure, & Perelló, 2016).
### Input: What are the potential benefits of using gamified assessment in online digital participation for cognitive experiments?
### Response: The potential benefits of using gamified assessment in online digital participation for cognitive experiments include the ability to engage larger and more diverse participant pools than traditional tasks. This amplifies the benefits of online crowdsourcing. Gamified assessment also motivates players by framing the activity as an entertaining and playful way to contribute to a meaningful scientific question.

column3: The gamiﬁed approach can take different directions. In one direction, the traditional taskfor measuring cognitive abilities is preserved as much as possible, and game-like elements,such as graphics, points, and narratives, are added to frame the task as a game. Lumsden,Skinner, Woods, Lawrence, and Munafò (2016) is an excellent example of this, where theGo/No-Go task is gamiﬁed by adding wild west illustrations and framing the task as a game,where the villains should be shot and the innocent left alive. These game-like tasks have beenshown to be more engaging, at least according to players’ self-report, compared to their moretraditional counterpart while producing similar results (Hawkins, Rae, Nesbitt, & Brown,2013).

Text: The gamiﬁed approach can take different directions. In one direction, the traditional taskfor measuring cognitive abilities is preserved as much as possible, and game-like elements,such as graphics, points, and narratives, are added to frame the task as a game. Lumsden,Skinner, Woods, Lawrence, and Munafò (2016) is an excellent example of this, where theGo/No-Go task is gamiﬁed by adding wild west illustrations and framing the task as a game,where the villains should be shot and the innocent left alive. These game-like tasks have beenshown to be more engaging, at least according to players’ self-report, compared to their moretraditional counterpart while producing similar results (Hawkins, Rae, Nesbitt, & Brown,2013).
### Input: What is one example of a traditional cognitive ability task being gamified, and how does this approach impact player engagement and results?
### Response: The text provides an example of a traditional cognitive ability task being gamified through the Go/No-Go task. This task was gamified by adding wild west illustrations and framing the task as a game where the villains should be shot and the innocent left alive. This approach has been shown to increase player engagement, as per players' self-reports, compared to the traditional version of the task. Despite the added game-like elements, the gamified task still produces similar results to its traditional counterpart.

column3: In another direction, new games are designed through an evidence-centered design process, whereby assessment tasks are designed to evoke behaviors that reveal targeted competencies(Mislevy, Almond, & Lukas, 2003). By designing a complete game from scratch around spe-ciﬁc cognitive abilities, researchers can obtain richer information than the traditional penand paper version (Hagler, Jimison, & Pavel, 2014). The games can be more complex anddynamic, which allows for more interesting cognitive modeling (Leduc-McNiven, White,Zheng, D McLeod, & R Friesen, 2018). Moreover, cognitive assessment games often applystealth assessment(Shute, Wang, Greiff, Zhao, & Moore, 2016), where the cognitive abilitymeasures are derived from the players’ in-game behavior. Thus, the players are immersed inthe game experience rather than being constantly aware of being tested (Shute et al., 2016;Valladares-Rodríguez, Pérez-Rodríguez, Anido-Rifón, & Fernández-Iglesias, 2016).

Text: In another direction, new games are designed through an evidence-centered design process, whereby assessment tasks are designed to evoke behaviors that reveal targeted competencies(Mislevy, Almond, & Lukas, 2003). By designing a complete game from scratch around spe-ciﬁc cognitive abilities, researchers can obtain richer information than the traditional penand paper version (Hagler, Jimison, & Pavel, 2014). The games can be more complex anddynamic, which allows for more interesting cognitive modeling (Leduc-McNiven, White,Zheng, D McLeod, & R Friesen, 2018). Moreover, cognitive assessment games often applystealth assessment(Shute, Wang, Greiff, Zhao, & Moore, 2016), where the cognitive abilitymeasures are derived from the players’ in-game behavior. Thus, the players are immersed inthe game experience rather than being constantly aware of being tested (Shute et al., 2016;Valladares-Rodríguez, Pérez-Rodríguez, Anido-Rifón, & Fernández-Iglesias, 2016).
### Input: What is the advantage of using cognitive assessment games designed through an evidence-centered design process over traditional pen and paper methods?
### Response: The advantage of using cognitive assessment games designed through an evidence-centered design process over traditional pen and paper methods is that they can provide richer information. These games can be more complex and dynamic, allowing for more interesting cognitive modeling. They often apply stealth assessment, where the cognitive ability measures are derived from the players’ in-game behavior. This immerses the players in the game experience, making them less aware of being tested, which can lead to more accurate results.

column3: Prominent examples of games built for cognitive assessment and applied at a large scaleareSea Hero Quest(Coughlan et al., 2019) andThe Great Brain Experiment(H. R. Brown et al., 2014). Sea Hero Quest delivers a casual game experience and has reached 2.5 millionparticipants, which yielded important insights into spatial navigation impairments in adultsat risk of Alzheimer’s disease (Coutrot et al., 2018). That said, Sea Hero Quest is by designonly intended to measure spatial navigation; thus, if the goal is to measure a portfolio ofdistinct cognitive abilities, it would be a considerable effort to perform similar studies foreach cognitive ability of interest. In contrast, The Great Brain Experiment is a collectionof smaller games that assess multiple cognitive abilities. Through a large-scale deployment,the games have yielded new insights into age-related changes in working memory perfor-mance (McNab et al., 2015) and patterns of bias in information-seeking behavior (Hunt, Rut-ledge, Malalasekera, Kennerley, & Dolan, 2016).

Sea Hero Quest delivers a casual game experience and has reached 2.5 millionparticipants, which yielded important insights into spatial navigation impairments in adultsat risk of Alzheimer’s disease (Coutrot et al., 2018). That said, Sea Hero Quest is by designonly intended to measure spatial navigation; thus, if the goal is to measure a portfolio ofdistinct cognitive abilities, it would be a considerable effort to perform similar studies foreach cognitive ability of interest. ### Input: What are some examples of games designed for cognitive assessment and what insights have they provided into cognitive abilities and impairments?
### Response: The text mentions two games designed for cognitive assessment: Sea Hero Quest and The Great Brain Experiment. Sea Hero Quest, which has reached 2.5 million participants, is designed to measure spatial navigation. It has provided insights into spatial navigation impairments in adults at risk of Alzheimer's disease. On the other hand, The Great Brain Experiment is a collection of smaller games that assess multiple cognitive abilities. It has provided new insights into age-related changes in working memory performance and patterns of bias in information-seeking behavior.

With the aim to contribute new knowledge to the assessment of cognitive abilities in the wild, we designed an ambitious suite of games that would simultaneously test a broad set of cognitive abilities. This process started by identifying how cognitive abilities have been operationalized and measured in laboratories. From this literature search, we selected 13 cognitive abilities (Fig. 1) suitable for gamification while ensuring broad coverage of important areas for everyday cognitive functioning (Lezak, Howieson, Bigler, & Tranel, 2012).

The cognitive abilities we selected have generally been investigated as relatively distinct aspects of cognition: executive functioning, language, and visual function, with indications of more nuanced subcomponents (Carroll, 1993; Deary, 2011; Jensen, 1998; Knopik, Neiderhiser, DeFries, & Plomin, 2017; Mackintosh, 1998). 
### Input: What cognitive abilities were selected for the gamification process and how were they generally investigated?
### Response: The cognitive abilities selected for the gamification process were executive functioning, language, and visual function. They were generally investigated as relatively distinct aspects of cognition, with indications of more nuanced subcomponents.

column3: 5. Simple reaction time Simple reaction time refers to the time needed to respond to a single stimulus as quickly as possible. Performance on simple reaction time tasks very often correlates with the performance of otherpsychometric tests. It is believed to indicate cognitive processing speed and is one of the mostbasic measurements of cognitive performance, underlying all cognitive functions. Studies ofreaction times are critical in studies about aging, as reaction times increase with age (Deary,Liewald, & Nissan, 2011).

Text: 5. Simple reaction time Simple reaction time refers to the time needed to respond to a single stimulus as quickly as possible. Performance on simple reaction time tasks very often correlates with the performance of otherpsychometric tests. It is believed to indicate cognitive processing speed and is one of the mostbasic measurements of cognitive performance, underlying all cognitive functions. Studies ofreaction times are critical in studies about aging, as reaction times increase with age (Deary,Liewald, & Nissan, 2011).
### Input: What is the significance of simple reaction time in studies about aging and cognitive performance?
### Response: Simple reaction time is significant in studies about aging and cognitive performance because it is believed to indicate cognitive processing speed, one of the most basic measurements of cognitive performance. It is often correlated with the performance of other psychometric tests. As reaction times increase with age, studies of reaction times are critical in understanding the effects of aging on cognitive functions.

### Response: Choice reaction time measures the speed of making appropriate responses when presented with two or more response options under complex task conditions. It is moderately to strongly correlated with general fluid intelligence.

### Response: Response inhibition is the ability to stop oneself from performing an action when the action is no longer required or is inappropriate. It is a component of executive functioning because it supports flexible and goal-oriented behavior in changing contexts.

column3: Cognitive ability Description 8 Cognitive ﬂexibility Cognitive ﬂexibility refers to shifting between different tasks depending on contextual demands and is a component of executive function. Cognitive ﬂexibility is vital in life, as we are faced with situations that require multitasking or rapid task switching every day. When talking about cognitive ﬂexibility, the concept of switching costs is fundamental. Studies show that switching back and forth between tasks can harm productivity. On the other hand, task switching can be beneﬁcial when stuck, as it can increase creativity by decreasing cognitive ﬁxation (Geurts, Corbett, & Solomon, 2009; Lu, Akinola, & Mason, 2017; Monsell, 2003).

Text: Cognitive ability Description 8 Cognitive ﬂexibility Cognitive ﬂexibility refers to shifting between different tasks depending on contextual demands and is a component of executive function. Cognitive ﬂexibility is vital in life, as we are faced with situations that require multitasking or rapid task switching every day. When talking about cognitive ﬂexibility, the concept of switching costs is fundamental. Studies show that switching back and forth between tasks can harm productivity. On the other hand, task switching can be beneﬁcial when stuck, as it can increase creativity by decreasing cognitive ﬁxation (Geurts, Corbett, & Solomon, 2009; Lu, Akinola, & Mason, 2017; Monsell, 2003).
### Input: What is the concept of switching costs in relation to cognitive flexibility and how does it affect productivity and creativity?
### Response: The concept of switching costs in relation to cognitive flexibility refers to the potential negative impact on productivity when shifting back and forth between tasks. Studies have shown that this kind of rapid task switching can harm productivity. However, it can also have a positive effect on creativity. When a person is stuck on a task, switching to a different task can decrease cognitive fixation, thereby increasing creativity.

column3: Planning refers to the ability to anticipate and plan actions, as well as to monitor goal attainment, and when necessary, update plans mid-execution. It involves a supervising function that is linked with the frontal activation and is essential for successful problem-solving (Dockery, Hueckel-Weng, Birbaumer, & Plewnia, 2009). Planning is often viewed as a subcomponent of executive functioning (Carlson, Moses, & Claxton, 2004; Krikorian, Bartok, & Gay, 1994).

Text: Planning refers to the ability to anticipate and plan actions, as well as to monitor goal attainment, and when necessary, update plans mid-execution. It involves a supervising function that is linked with the frontal activation and is essential for successful problem-solving (Dockery, Hueckel-Weng, Birbaumer, & Plewnia, 2009). Planning is often viewed as a subcomponent of executive functioning (Carlson, Moses, & Claxton, 2004; Krikorian, Bartok, & Gay, 1994).
### Input: What is the relationship between planning and executive functioning, and why is it essential for successful problem-solving?
### Response: The text suggests that planning is often viewed as a subcomponent of executive functioning. This means that planning is a part of the broader cognitive process of executive functioning, which involves managing and regulating various cognitive processes. Planning is essential for successful problem-solving because it involves the ability to anticipate and plan actions, monitor goal attainment, and update plans mid-execution if necessary. This supervising function, linked with frontal activation, allows for the effective management and adjustment of actions to achieve desired outcomes.

column3: Color perception is the ability to detect differences in stimuli with varying distributions of spectral energy. These differences must be based on the color’s hue or saturation rather than the intensity contrast of the stimuli (Jacobs, 1993).

### Response: According to Jacobs (1993), the basis for differences in color perception is the color’s hue or saturation, not the intensity contrast of the stimuli.

column3: Categorical visual perception refers to the ability to organize concepts (e.g., objects or attributes of objects) into distinct categories, with the consequence that cross-category stimuli will be more easily distinguishable than within-category stimuli (Harnad, 1987).

Text: Categorical visual perception refers to the ability to organize concepts (e.g., objects or attributes of objects) into distinct categories, with the consequence that cross-category stimuli will be more easily distinguishable than within-category stimuli (Harnad, 1987).
### Input: What does categorical visual perception refer to and how does it affect the distinguishability of cross-category and within-category stimuli?
### Response: Categorical visual perception refers to the ability to organize concepts, such as objects or attributes of objects, into distinct categories. This ability affects the distinguishability of cross-category and within-category stimuli in such a way that stimuli from different categories (cross-category) are more easily distinguishable than stimuli from the same category (within-category).

column3: Recognition is the ability to identify information–in this case about objects–from previous encounters or knowledge, such as shape or color. This is a cue-based, associative process and is related to visual search processes (Ullman, 2000).

### Input: What is recognition and how is it related to visual search processes?
### Response: Recognition is the ability to identify information about objects from previous encounters or knowledge, such as shape or color. It is a cue-based, associative process and is related to visual search processes as it involves identifying and associating visual cues from past experiences or knowledge.

column3: M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) 7o f2 7 Fig. 2. The six games making up Skill Lab. (a) Rat Catch is designed to test response inhibition, simple reaction time, and choice reaction time, (b) Shadow Match to test visuospatial reasoning in 3D, (c) Robot Reboot to test reading comprehension and instruction following, (d) Relic Hunt to test visuospatial reasoning and executive functions for simple strategy making in 2D visuospatial scenarios, (e) Electron Rush to test how people navigate and make decisions, and (f) Chemical Chaos to measure visual working memory. overviews of all the tasks used to measure the different cognitive abilities–Sections 3 and 4–and how they are operationalized–Sections 5 and 6).

Text: M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) 7o f2 7 Fig. 2. The six games making up Skill Lab. (a) Rat Catch is designed to test response inhibition, simple reaction time, and choice reaction time, (b) Shadow Match to test visuospatial reasoning in 3D, (c) Robot Reboot to test reading comprehension and instruction following, (d) Relic Hunt to test visuospatial reasoning and executive functions for simple strategy making in 2D visuospatial scenarios, (e) Electron Rush to test how people navigate and make decisions, and (f) Chemical Chaos to measure visual working memory. overviews of all the tasks used to measure the different cognitive abilities–Sections 3 and 4–and how they are operationalized–Sections 5 and 6).
### Input: What are the six games in Skill Lab designed to test according to M. K. Pedersen et al.'s study?
### Response: According to M. K. Pedersen et al.'s study, the six games in Skill Lab are designed to test the following:

(a) Rat Catch is designed to test response inhibition, simple reaction time, and choice reaction time.
(b) Shadow Match is designed to test visuospatial reasoning in 3D.
(c) Robot Reboot is designed to test reading comprehension and instruction following.
(d) Relic Hunt is designed to test visuospatial reasoning and executive functions for simple strategy making in 2D visuospatial scenarios.
(e) Electron Rush is designed to test how people navigate and make decisions.
(f) Chemical Chaos is designed to measure visual working memory.

column3: 2.2. The game–Skill Lab With the theoretical model as a starting point, we held multiple brainstorming sessions with game designers to identify game mechanics that could activate the different cognitive abilities. The game mechanics that were found during the brainstorming sessions were combined into six games through an evidence-centered design process: Rat Catch, Relic Hunt, Electron Rush, Shadow Match, Robot Reboot, and Chemical Chaos (Fig. 2a–f, see Supplementary Information Section 7 for complete descriptions of the designs). These six games were collected into a single application called Skill Lab. Skill Lab contained an overarching structure and a detective narrative theme intended to motivate and guide the participant between the games.

column3: For this paper, we limit the scope of our analysis to the measures derived from participants’ behavior within the six games and the validation tasks. The games were designed to measure the cognitive abilities via stealth assessment (Shute et al., 2016). We created the games with the distinctive feel of a casual game while activating the targeted cognitive abilities. A consequence of this design choice is that the games are not a one-to-one redesign of any particular standard cognitive task. However, there are significant shared elements allowing connections to be drawn between the cognitive abilities most likely to be activated.

column3: 8o f2 7M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) with a series of stimuli. If the stimulus is the correct type, the participant must react as quickly as possible; otherwise, the participant should refrain from reacting. This test procedure has an analog in the ﬁrst two levels of Rat Catch. In the ﬁrst level, a rat appears for a limited time at a random position; the player is asked to tap the rat as quickly as possible, providing simple reaction time measures. The rats disappear faster and faster as the level progresses. Once the player misses three rats, this level of play ends.

If the stimulus is the correct type, the participant must react as quickly as possible; otherwise, the participant should refrain from reacting. This test procedure has an analog in the ﬁrst two levels of Rat Catch. In the ﬁrst level, a rat appears for a limited time at a random position; the player is asked to tap the rat as quickly as possible, providing simple reaction time measures. The rats disappear faster and faster as the level progresses. Once the player misses three rats, this level of play ends. 
### Input: What is the procedure of the test in the first two levels of Rat Catch as described by K. Pedersen et al.?
### Response: In the first two levels of Rat Catch, a rat appears for a limited time at a random position and the player is asked to tap the rat as quickly as possible, providing simple reaction time measures. The rats disappear faster and faster as the level progresses. The level of play ends once the player misses three rats.

column3: In the second level of the game, there is a 50% chance that an “angry” red rat will appear. The player is instructed not to react to red rats but to still tap all other rats as quickly as possible. The level then follows the same progression as the ﬁrst level, ending after three errors have been made (either tapping a red rat or not tapping the other rats before the timer runs out). This taps into choice reaction time and response inhibition. Further, Rat Catch levels add variations, such as an increasing number of stimuli or moving targets that have no analog in the Go/No-Go task. These additions give indicators of visuospatial reasoning components, such as 2D spatial representation and movement perception.

The player is instructed not to react to red rats but to still tap all other rats as quickly as possible. The level then follows the same progression as the ﬁrst level, ending after three errors have been made (either tapping a red rat or not tapping the other rats before the timer runs out). This taps into choice reaction time and response inhibition. Further, Rat Catch levels add variations, such as an increasing number of stimuli or moving targets that have no analog in the Go/No-Go task. These additions give indicators of visuospatial reasoning components, such as 2D spatial representation and movement perception. 
### Input: What skills does the second level of the game test in a player?
### Response: The second level of the game tests a player's choice reaction time, response inhibition, visuospatial reasoning components, 2D spatial representation, and movement perception.

column3: 3. Methods 3.1. Participants Participant engagement typically has an exponential fall-off (Lieberoth, Pedersen, Marin, & Sherson, 2014), and in this case, a substantial player effort was needed to play both the games and complete the validation tasks; thus, broad and efﬁcient recruitment was essential. Skill Lab was, therefore, launched publicly in Denmark in collaboration with the Public Danish Broadcast Company (Danmarks Radio, DR) on the 4th of September 2018 on (https://www.scienceathome.org/games/skill-lab-science-detective/, Retrieved: 2020-07-07), Apple Appstore, and Google Play. The Committee of Research Ethics for Region Midtjylland (Denmark) exempted the study from ethical oversight, and the project received ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board at Cornell University (Protocol ID: 1808008201).

Participants Participant engagement typically has an exponential fall-off (Lieberoth, Pedersen, Marin, & Sherson, 2014), and in this case, a substantial player effort was needed to play both the games and complete the validation tasks; thus, broad and efﬁcient recruitment was essential. Skill Lab was, therefore, launched publicly in Denmark in collaboration with the Public Danish Broadcast Company (Danmarks Radio, DR) on the 4th of September 2018 on (https://www.scienceathome.org/games/skill-lab-science-detective/, Retrieved: 2020-07-07), Apple Appstore, and Google Play. The Committee of Research Ethics for Region Midtjylland (Denmark) exempted the study from ethical oversight, and the project received ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board at Cornell University (Protocol ID: 1808008201). 
### Input: What methods were used to recruit participants for the Skill Lab game study?
### Response: The Skill Lab game study was launched publicly in Denmark in collaboration with the Public Danish Broadcast Company (Danmarks Radio, DR). column3: The study was conducted in accordance with all ethical requirements. Thus, the players provided informed consent before taking part in the study and any data were recorded. The players were made aware that they could, at any time, leave the study and request their data to be anonymized. To attract the broadest possible audience, we drew attention to the project through a series of DR news articles with themes varying from artiﬁcial intelligence and technology to psychology and computer games (https://www.dr.dk/nyheder/viden/nysgerrig/tema/danmarks-nye-superhjerne, Retrieved: 2020-07-07). Furthermore, Skill Lab was part of an educational event across classes at 208 high schools during the ﬁrst week of December 2018. This event accounts for the spike of users at age 16 (Fig. 3).

To attract the broadest possible audience, we drew attention to the project through a series of DR news articles with themes varying from artiﬁcial intelligence and technology to psychology and computer games (https://www.dr.dk/nyheder/viden/nysgerrig/tema/danmarks-nye-superhjerne, Retrieved: 2020-07-07). ### Response: The study attracted a broad audience by drawing attention to the project through a series of DR news articles with themes varying from artificial intelligence and technology to psychology and computer games. column3: M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) 9o f2 7 Fig. 3. Age distribution by gender for players who played at least one game in the wild. There are no qualitative differences in the age and gender distribution between those who played the game on mobile devices and those who played it on computers. All in all, more than 16,000 people signed up to play the publicly available version. The game was available in versions running either on mobile devices or in the browser of personal computers. Since the required user interactions were different between mobile and computer versions, each version was separately validated (Drucker, Fisher, Sadana, Her- ron, & Schraefel, 2013; Muender et al., 2019; Watson, Hancock, Mandryk, & Birk, 2013).

column3: This paper focuses primarily on the mobile version since it had the broadest reach. The results presented in the paper are based on the sample of 6524 players from the in-the- wild data set that played at least one game on the mobile version. We also test the gen- erated models on a sample of 4201 players from the in-the-wild data set that played at least one game on the computer version of which 603 also had cognitive abilities from the tasks.

column3: 3.2. Measuring convergent validity of the game-based cognitive measures Many traditional cognitive tasks aim to assess a limited number of targeted cognitive abil- ities under strict conditions that minimize distractions and maximize experimental control (Salthouse, 2011). In contrast, the Skill Lab games are designed to engage multiple cognitive processes, simultaneously measuring multiple abilities within a convenient, engaging, and scalable package that aims to increase the external validity of the cognitive measures by cre- ating a more realistic context and gameplay compared to traditional tasks (Schmuckler, 2001; Valladares-Rodríguez et al., 2016).

Text: 3.2. Measuring convergent validity of the game-based cognitive measures Many traditional cognitive tasks aim to assess a limited number of targeted cognitive abil- ities under strict conditions that minimize distractions and maximize experimental control (Salthouse, 2011). In contrast, the Skill Lab games are designed to engage multiple cognitive processes, simultaneously measuring multiple abilities within a convenient, engaging, and scalable package that aims to increase the external validity of the cognitive measures by cre- ating a more realistic context and gameplay compared to traditional tasks (Schmuckler, 2001; Valladares-Rodríguez et al., 2016). 
### Input: What is the main difference between traditional cognitive tasks and the Skill Lab games in terms of cognitive abilities assessment and experimental control?
### Response: Traditional cognitive tasks aim to assess a limited number of targeted cognitive abilities under strict conditions that minimize distractions and maximize experimental control. On the other hand, the Skill Lab games are designed to engage multiple cognitive processes, simultaneously measuring multiple abilities within a more realistic context and gameplay. This approach aims to increase the external validity of the cognitive measures, offering a more convenient, engaging, and scalable package compared to traditional tasks.

column3: To obtain quantiﬁable measures of the players’ ability levels, we identiﬁed indicatorsof the cognitive abilities assessed (e.g., number of errors in a task) in both the games (45 indicators,see Supplementary Information Section 8) and the tasks (68 indicators, see SupplementaryInformation Section 6). The game indicators were identiﬁed through a cognitive task analysis(Newell, 1966; Newell & Simon, 1972), whereby the stimuli in the games were connected tothe corresponding actions a player could make and how the player’s cognitive abilities couldinﬂuence these actions. The full theoretical mapping between cognitive abilities, games, andvalidation tasks can be found in Fig. 4.

The game indicators were identiﬁed through a cognitive task analysis(Newell, 1966; Newell & Simon, 1972), whereby the stimuli in the games were connected tothe corresponding actions a player could make and how the player’s cognitive abilities couldinﬂuence these actions. The full theoretical mapping between cognitive abilities, games, andvalidation tasks can be found in Fig. 4.
### Input: What method was used to identify the game indicators of the players' cognitive abilities?
### Response: The method used to identify the game indicators of the players' cognitive abilities was a cognitive task analysis.

column3: Since many tasks conceptually measure aspects of the same cognitive abilities, combiningthe observations from different tasks with a strong theoretical overlap can give rise to morerobust composite measures of cognitive abilities. Measures of cognitive abilities from taskscan be deﬁned on a spectrum of computational granularity; pure indicators (Salthouse, 2011),linear combinations of indicators (Bollen & Bauldry, 2011), all the way to methods like gen-erative models (Guest & Martin, 2021). Here, we form linear combinations of indicators,combining indicators from multiple tasks according to a standard theoretical interpretation,as it is the simplest way to take advantage of the overlap among the indicators. We recog-nize that the association between any particular combination of indicators is open to debateand offer the speciﬁc aggregation of indicators here as the most straightforward theoreticalproposal. (For a list of the standard task indicators associated with each of the 13 cognitiveabilities, see Supplementary Information Section 6).

Here, we form linear combinations of indicators,combining indicators from multiple tasks according to a standard theoretical interpretation,as it is the simplest way to take advantage of the overlap among the indicators. We recog-nize that the association between any particular combination of indicators is open to debateand offer the speciﬁc aggregation of indicators here as the most straightforward theoreticalproposal. (For a list of the standard task indicators associated with each of the 13 cognitiveabilities, see Supplementary Information Section 6).
### Input: What is the simplest way to take advantage of the overlap among indicators of cognitive abilities from different tasks, according to the text?
### Response: The simplest way to take advantage of the overlap among indicators of cognitive abilities from different tasks, according to the text, is to form linear combinations of indicators, combining indicators from multiple tasks according to a standard theoretical interpretation.

column3: 3.3. Modeling cognitive abilities with games and validation tasksTo be included in the validation process, a player had to complete at least one speciﬁccombination of validation tasks for a given cognitive ability. From 6369 players on the mobileversion, we obtained a large sample of wild players ( N=1385) that had taken the right combination of validation tasks to measure at least one cognitive ability (e.g., the three tasksVisual Pattern, Groton Maze, and Corsi Block had to be completed for us to evaluate theability visual working memory).

column3: We started by deﬁning cognitive ability measures by combining indicators–that measure the same construct–from different tasks. To determine which indicators to combine, we reviewed the tasks and identiﬁed the indicators ti(see Theoretical Considerations) of a cognitive ability that had a theoretical overlap (Beaujean & Benson, 2019; Mayo, 2018). For each of the 68 task indicators ti, we assigned 13 coefﬁcients αij∈{−1,0,1} depending on its theoretical contribution to each of the cognitive abilities Cjby assigning: 0 if there is no contribution, 1 if there is a positive correlation between the task indicator and the cognitive ability, and −1i f there is a negative correlation (see Supplementary Information Section 5 for a comprehensive list of coefﬁcients and justiﬁcations). The task indicators were standardized and combined into measures of cognitive abilities (Bollen & Bauldry, 2011) by taking weighted averages.

Text: We started by deﬁning cognitive ability measures by combining indicators–that measure the same construct–from different tasks. To determine which indicators to combine, we reviewed the tasks and identiﬁed the indicators ti(see Theoretical Considerations) of a cognitive ability that had a theoretical overlap (Beaujean & Benson, 2019; Mayo, 2018). For each of the 68 task indicators ti, we assigned 13 coefﬁcients αij∈{−1,0,1} depending on its theoretical contribution to each of the cognitive abilities Cjby assigning: 0 if there is no contribution, 1 if there is a positive correlation between the task indicator and the cognitive ability, and −1i f there is a negative correlation (see Supplementary Information Section 5 for a comprehensive list of coefﬁcients and justiﬁcations). The task indicators were standardized and combined into measures of cognitive abilities (Bollen & Bauldry, 2011) by taking weighted averages.
### Input: What method was used to determine which indicators to combine when defining cognitive ability measures?
### Response: The method used to determine which indicators to combine when defining cognitive ability measures involved reviewing the tasks and identifying the indicators of a cognitive ability that had a theoretical overlap.

column3: For the games, we identiﬁed 45 indicators gifrom the six games that contained information pertaining to the cognitive abilities. Before any modeling was performed, all game indicators and cognitive ability measures were standardized to mean =0a n dS D =1. Only players who had produced all the task indicators associated with the respective cognitive ability (see Sup- plementary Information Section 6) and at least one game indicator were included in the sam- ple used to ﬁt the linear regression models predicting the cognitive abilities measured from the tasks with game indicators (for sample sizes, see Table 3).

Only players who had produced all the task indicators associated with the respective cognitive ability (see Sup- plementary Information Section 6) and at least one game indicator were included in the sam- ple used to ﬁt the linear regression models predicting the cognitive abilities measured from the tasks with game indicators (for sample sizes, see Table 3).
### Input: What criteria were used to include players in the sample for fitting the linear regression models predicting cognitive abilities?
### Response: The criteria used to include players in the sample for fitting the linear regression models predicting cognitive abilities were that the players must have produced all the task indicators associated with the respective cognitive ability and at least one game indicator.

column3: Any missing game indicators were imputed using multivariate imputation with chained equations (Buuren & Groothuis- Oudshoorn, 2011), which generated one common imputation model for the entire data set. The imputation model was generated from game indicators only and contained no informa- tion about task indicators or demographic information. To prevent overﬁtting, an elastic-net model (Zou & Hastie, 2005) was used. Elastic-net models combine ridge (Hoerl & Kennard, 1988) and lasso (Tibshirani, 1996) regression by adding two penalty terms (regularization) to the loss function when ﬁtting the model.

The imputation model was generated from game indicators only and contained no informa- tion about task indicators or demographic information. To prevent overﬁtting, an elastic-net model (Zou & Hastie, 2005) was used. Elastic-net models combine ridge (Hoerl & Kennard, 1988) and lasso (Tibshirani, 1996) regression by adding two penalty terms (regularization) to the loss function when ﬁtting the model.
### Input: What method was used to prevent overfitting in the imputation model for missing game indicators?
### Response: An elastic-net model was used to prevent overfitting in the imputation model for missing game indicators.

column3: M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) 13 of 27 coefﬁcients of a linear model ˆβ≡argmin β/parenleftbig /bardbly−Xβ/bardbl2+λ2/bardblβ/bardbl2+λ1/bardblβ/bardbl1/parenrightbig , where βare the coefﬁcients of a linear model, and λ1,λ2are determining how much of the, respectively, lasso and ridge penalties to apply. Both ridge and lasso regression prevent over- ﬁtting; ridge regression by shrinking the values of the collinear coefﬁcients closer to zero, that is, grouping collinear game indicators, and lasso by forcing some of the coefﬁcients to be exactly zero, that is, automatic variable selection. The elastic net model increases the relia- bility of the model over ordinary least squares regressions, as it can handle multi-collinearity among the indicators by shrinking the coefﬁcients or zeroing redundant indicators.

Text: M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) 13 of 27 coefﬁcients of a linear model ˆβ≡argmin β/parenleftbig /bardbly−Xβ/bardbl2+λ2/bardblβ/bardbl2+λ1/bardblβ/bardbl1/parenrightbig , where βare the coefﬁcients of a linear model, and λ1,λ2are determining how much of the, respectively, lasso and ridge penalties to apply. Both ridge and lasso regression prevent over- ﬁtting; ridge regression by shrinking the values of the collinear coefﬁcients closer to zero, that is, grouping collinear game indicators, and lasso by forcing some of the coefﬁcients to be exactly zero, that is, automatic variable selection. The elastic net model increases the relia- bility of the model over ordinary least squares regressions, as it can handle multi-collinearity among the indicators by shrinking the coefﬁcients or zeroing redundant indicators.
### Input: What is the purpose of ridge and lasso regression in the elastic net model described by M. K. Pedersen et al.?
### Response: The purpose of ridge and lasso regression in the elastic net model described by M. K. Pedersen et al. is to prevent overfitting. Ridge regression does this by shrinking the values of the collinear coefficients closer to zero, effectively grouping collinear game indicators. Lasso regression, on the other hand, forces some of the coefficients to be exactly zero, enabling automatic variable selection. The elastic net model increases the reliability of the model over ordinary least squares regressions, as it can handle multi-collinearity among the indicators by shrinking the coefficients or zeroing redundant indicators.

column3: Thus, one must be careful when interpreting the coefﬁcients resulting from the elastic-net model as a small or zero coefﬁcient could be either a redundant or irrelevant indicator, and therefore, not an unequivocally sign that the indicator contains no information about the cognitive ability. As our focus is to generate a predictive model of cognitive abilities that can be used with new participant samples, we prioritized increasing the reliability of the model over conﬁrming theoretical relationships between cognitive abilities and game indicators.

Text: Thus, one must be careful when interpreting the coefﬁcients resulting from the elastic-net model as a small or zero coefﬁcient could be either a redundant or irrelevant indicator, and therefore, not an unequivocally sign that the indicator contains no information about the cognitive ability. As our focus is to generate a predictive model of cognitive abilities that can be used with new participant samples, we prioritized increasing the reliability of the model over conﬁrming theoretical relationships between cognitive abilities and game indicators.
### Input: What is the primary focus when generating a predictive model of cognitive abilities using the elastic-net model, and why must one be cautious when interpreting the coefficients resulting from this model?
### Response: The primary focus when generating a predictive model of cognitive abilities using the elastic-net model is to increase the reliability of the model so that it can be used with new participant samples. One must be cautious when interpreting the coefficients resulting from this model because a small or zero coefficient could be either a redundant or irrelevant indicator. This does not necessarily mean that the indicator contains no information about the cognitive ability.

column3: To further reduce the overﬁtting of the model beyond what can be achieved by the reg- ularization performed by the elastic-net model, we used 100 times repeated ﬁve-fold cross- validation (Burman, 1989). The standardization and imputation is performed separately for the training set in each of the cross-validations. The trained models ({ β1j,…,β45j},kj) (see Supplementary Information Section 12) are the result of ﬁtting the elastic net model to the entire training set with the best hyper parameters determined by the cross-validation. If a sin- gle game indicator or the cognitive ability measured by tasks was more than 3 SD’s from the mean, the player was excluded from the ﬁtting, as the ﬁtting would be sensitive to such outliers.

The trained models ({ β1j,…,β45j},kj) (see Supplementary Information Section 12) are the result of ﬁtting the elastic net model to the entire training set with the best hyper parameters determined by the cross-validation. ### Response: The method used to further reduce the overfitting of the model beyond what can be achieved by the regularization performed by the elastic-net model was 100 times repeated five-fold cross-validation.

column3: We utilized the scikit learn library (Pedregosa et al., 2011) with Python 3.8.13 to perform the imputation, ﬁt the elastic net model, and perform the cross-validation. Scikit learn deﬁnes the hyperparameters of the elastic net model that control the regularization ( α,L1) such that λ1 =αL1andλ2=α(1-L1). For the elastic net hyperparameter tuning, we used the recommended L1ratios (0.1, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9, 0.95, 0.99, and 1), and let the elastic net function determine the appropriate α(Sklearn.Linear_model.ElasticNetCV, 2022).

column3: 3.4. Factor analysis of cognitive abilities from games and validation tasks To identify the extent to which our predictive models rely on a generalized cognitive ability, we perform an exploratory factor analysis on the cognitive abilities measured from the tasks and predicted from the games. For this, we apply the FactorAnalyser library (Biggs & Madnani, 2022) using principal factor extraction without any rotation. To evaluate the similarity of the main factor loadings (Fg,iand F t,i), we compute the cosine similarity cos( θ)=/summationtextFg,iFt,i |Fg||Ft|. If the cosine similarity is 0, the main factors are orthogonal, and if it is 1, they are completely identical.

### Input: What does the Cronbach α value indicate about the reliability of the task-measured cognitive abilities in the study conducted by M. K. Pedersen et al.?
### Response: The Cronbach α value in the study conducted by M. K. Pedersen et al. indicates the reliability of the task-measured cognitive abilities. A higher Cronbach α value suggests a higher reliability. For instance, written language comprehension with a Cronbach α of 0.96 and mental rotation with a Cronbach α of 0.90 are highly reliable. However, visual processing with a Cronbach α of 0.25 indicates low reliability. The Cronbach α for color perception and categorical visual perception were not available (N/A) in the study.

column3: 4. Results 4.1. Reliability of task measured cognitive abilities The cognitive abilities measured from the task are formed by averaging the theoretically chosen reﬂective indicators with equal weights. Thus, the internal reliability of the cognitive abilities can be assessed by computing Cronbach α. The Cronbach αof all but Visual Pro- cessing is above 0.7 (Table 2), which indicates good reliability. Categorical Visual Perception and Color Perception both contain only one indicator. Thus, Cronbach αcannot be computed.

column3: 4.2. Cognitive modeling The ﬁtting and cross-validation process resulted in eight accepted ( rcv>.2) prediction models with medium to strong effect sizes and ﬁve rejected models (Table 3). This cutoff turned out to align with whether the model signiﬁcantly predicts more than an intercept-only model ( pcv<.05). More speciﬁcally, we accepted models of choice reaction time, categorical visual perception, central executive functioning, simple reaction time, response inhibition, visual processing, cognitive ﬂexibility, and visual working memory.

Text: 4.2. Cognitive modeling The ﬁtting and cross-validation process resulted in eight accepted ( rcv>.2) prediction models with medium to strong effect sizes and ﬁve rejected models (Table 3). This cutoff turned out to align with whether the model signiﬁcantly predicts more than an intercept-only model ( pcv<.05). More speciﬁcally, we accepted models of choice reaction time, categorical visual perception, central executive functioning, simple reaction time, response inhibition, visual processing, cognitive ﬂexibility, and visual working memory. 
### Input: What were the eight accepted prediction models in the cognitive modeling study and what criteria was used to accept these models?
### Response: The eight accepted prediction models in the cognitive modeling study were choice reaction time, categorical visual perception, central executive functioning, simple reaction time, response inhibition, visual processing, cognitive flexibility, and visual working memory. The criteria used to accept these models was a fitting and cross-validation process that resulted in a rcv value greater than .2, and the model significantly predicting more than an intercept-only model with a pcv value less than .05.

column3: 4.2.1. Model generalizability with data from computer version The analysis above only considered the players on the mobile devices as the interface differences to computers could affect the measurement of the cognitive abilities (Drucker et al., 2013; Muender et al., 2019; Watson et al., 2013). However, if the accepted models that we have trained on the data from the mobile devices represent a mapping between cognitive abilities and game indicators, then applying them on the data collected from players of the computer version will provide a test of the generalizability. To account for systematic interface differences, we standardized the game and task indicators anew with only the computer data. We then computed the cognitive abilities from the task indicators for all the players who had taken the right combinations and correlated them with the predicted cognitive abilities from the models trained on mobile data (Table 4).

Text: 4.2.1. Model generalizability with data from computer version The analysis above only considered the players on the mobile devices as the interface differences to computers could affect the measurement of the cognitive abilities (Drucker et al., 2013; Muender et al., 2019; Watson et al., 2013). However, if the accepted models that we have trained on the data from the mobile devices represent a mapping between cognitive abilities and game indicators, then applying them on the data collected from players of the computer version will provide a test of the generalizability. To account for systematic interface differences, we standardized the game and task indicators anew with only the computer data. We then computed the cognitive abilities from the task indicators for all the players who had taken the right combinations and correlated them with the predicted cognitive abilities from the models trained on mobile data (Table 4). 
### Input: What method was used to test the generalizability of the models trained on data from mobile devices in the context of computer version data?
### Response: The method used to test the generalizability of the models trained on data from mobile devices in the context of computer version data was to apply these models on the data collected from players of the computer version. The game and task indicators were standardized anew with only the computer data to account for systematic interface differences. The cognitive abilities were then computed from the task indicators for all the players who had taken the right combinations and these were correlated with the predicted cognitive abilities from the models trained on mobile data.

column3: 4.3. Assessing the models’ predictive power 4.3.1. Generalized cognitive ability Since the cognitive abilities are related in the theoretical framework (Fig. 1), it is essential to look at shared variation contributing to the observed predictive power. Therefore, we performed a pair of exploratory factor analyses, one on the cognitive abilities computed from validation tasks, and one on cognitive abilities predicted from game data. This allowed us to identify the main factor in both sets, interpretable as a generalized cognitive ability (Knopik et al., 2017).

Text: 4.3. Assessing the models’ predictive power 4.3.1. Generalized cognitive ability Since the cognitive abilities are related in the theoretical framework (Fig. 1), it is essential to look at shared variation contributing to the observed predictive power. Therefore, we performed a pair of exploratory factor analyses, one on the cognitive abilities computed from validation tasks, and one on cognitive abilities predicted from game data. This allowed us to identify the main factor in both sets, interpretable as a generalized cognitive ability (Knopik et al., 2017).
### Input: What method was used to assess the shared variation contributing to the predictive power of the cognitive abilities models?
### Response: The method used to assess the shared variation contributing to the predictive power of the cognitive abilities models was a pair of exploratory factor analyses.

column3: M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) 17 of 27 (a) (b) Fig. 6. (a) Proportion of variance covered by each factor. (b) Loadings of each cognitive ability on the factors. The factor analysis’s exclusion criterion was whether the cognitive ability measure was more than 3 SD’s from the population mean. This criterion was different from the one applied during the ﬁtting procedure, as a single outlier among the game indicators could potentially be compensated for in the predictive model, either by all the other nonoutliers or that a particular game indicator is irrelevant for that particular model. Thus, we decided to exclude based on the predicted value rather than at the game indicator level. The same criterion is used for all the following analyses in this paper.

column3: 18 of 27M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) Fig. 7. The proportion of the models’ predictive strength is not explained by the main factor. For both games and tasks, the main factor corresponds approximately to the mean of all the cognitive abilities (Fig. 6b).

column3: 4.3.2. Discriminant validity of the models. As shown above, the main factor is responsible for explaining a high percentage of variance for both games and validation tasks. Therefore, in order to demonstrate that our model has discriminative power beyond being driven by the main factor, we computed partial correlations between the games and validation tasks while controlling for the games’ main factor. These partial correlations thus reveal the extent to which our models can predict the nuances contained within each separate cognitive ability that goes beyond a generalized cognitive ability. Fig. 7 illustrates the fraction of the correlation between the task and the game-based measures that is not explained by the main factor. For all eight cognitive models, we find that 23–63% of the correlation is not due to the main factor, demonstrating the discriminative validity of the models. In other words, we clearly document that each of our models tap significantly into aspects beyond just the general abilities factor.

### Response: The fraction of the correlation between the task and the game-based measures that is not explained by the main factor indicates that the cognitive models have discriminative validity. This means that the models can predict the nuances within each separate cognitive ability beyond a generalized cognitive ability. This is evidenced by the fact that 23–63% of the correlation is not due to the main factor, showing that each model taps significantly into aspects beyond just the general abilities factor.

column3: 4.4. Skill Lab as a potential cognitive diagnostics tool. One of Skill Lab’s potential use cases is as a low-cost test battery that could be used to track cognitive impairments. We are, therefore, interested in the time it takes compared to current cognitive batteries. The average time taken to complete all six games was 14 min (SD =5 min), in comparison with 72 min needed to complete all the validation tasks (SD =7). In other words, the Skill Lab games could model cognitive abilities in one-fifth of the time as required by the traditional set of cognitive tests.

We are, therefore, interested in the time it takes compared to current cognitive batteries. The average time taken to complete all six games was 14 min (SD =5 min), in comparison with 72 min needed to complete all the validation tasks (SD =7). In other words, the Skill Lab games could model cognitive abilities in one-fifth of the time as required by the traditional set of cognitive tests.
### Input: What is the potential use of Skill Lab as a cognitive diagnostics tool in terms of time efficiency compared to traditional cognitive tests?
### Response: The potential use of Skill Lab as a cognitive diagnostics tool in terms of time efficiency is that it can model cognitive abilities in one-fifth of the time required by traditional cognitive tests. On average, it takes 14 minutes to complete all six games in Skill Lab, compared to 72 minutes needed to complete all the validation tasks in traditional cognitive tests.

column3: M. K. Pedersen et al. / Cognitive Science 47 (2023) 19 of 27 (a) (b) Fig. 8. Cognitive abilities across age groups for (a) simple reaction time ( ntask=225, nwild=6277) and (b) central executive functioning ( ntask=372, nwild=6281). The shaded areas around the curves are the standard error of the mean. The y-axis represents simple reaction time and central executive functioning standardized across the population, thus, higher values on the y-axis correspond to faster reaction times (the curves for the remaining cog- nitive abilities can be found in the Supplementary Information Chapter 14). Each age point in the graph includes at least 30 players. The points were generated by starting at age 16 and checking whether 30 players of that age whose data provided a cognitive ability measure. If there were enough players, the following point was generated starting with those 1 year older; if not, the following ages were added 1 year at a time until a sample size of 30 was reached. cognitive abilities from age 16 to 20 years, followed by a gradual decline from age 20 years.

column3: 5. Discussion We designed the Skill Lab games to simultaneously engage and measure multiple cognitive abilities in a more realistic gameplay context within a single convenient, engaging, and scal- able package. One of this project’s main contributions is a demonstration that we were able to achieve a large-scale in-the-wild within-sample validation of our cognitive assessment.

column3: We ﬁrst constructed predictive models of cognitive abilities based on data from 1351 participants who had completed a sufﬁcient number of both games and tasks, then validated the perfor- mance of these models based on data from 6369 players who played at least one game on mobile devices. We were also able to further validate our model based on the data from the in total 603 players who played the game and took the validation tasks on computers.

We were also able to further validate our model based on the data from the in total 603 players who played the game and took the validation tasks on computers.

### Response: The predictive models of cognitive abilities were constructed using data from 1351 participants. These models were then validated using data from 6369 players who played at least one game on mobile devices and 603 players who played the game and took the validation tasks on computers.

column3: It should be mentioned that there was no nudging toward the tasks within Skill Lab and no requirement to do so; thus, there were no expectations from a data collection perspec- tive toward the in-the-wild players completing all tasks. In particular, it should be noted that such a large fraction of the players identiﬁed sufﬁciently with the scientiﬁc purpose of the games (to help the researchers better understand human cognition) that they spent so much time performing the rather tedious validation tasks without any form of extrinsic reward.

column3: In line with the goals of our design process, results from the study demonstrated good con-vergent validity of the game-based cognitive measures, where eight of the models predictingthe cognitive abilities from game indicators correlated well with the task-based measures. Thefactor analysis revealed a main factor for cognitive abilities that could be interpreted as a gen-eral cognitive ability for both games and tasks (Fig. 6) in line with a priori expectations duringthe design phase (Fig. 1). Via partial correlations (Fig. 7), we demonstrated that the sharedinformation from the main factor is insufﬁcient to explain a substantial proportion of eachcognitive ability’s observed agreement between task and game estimates. Each of our mea-sures, therefore, captures some of the nuances of the cognitive abilities beyond the dominantfactor.
column4: Pedersen et al. - 2023 - Measuring Cognitive Abilities in the Wild Validat

Text: In line with the goals of our design process, results from the study demonstrated good con-vergent validity of the game-based cognitive measures, where eight of the models predictingthe cognitive abilities from game indicators correlated well with the task-based measures. Thefactor analysis revealed a main factor for cognitive abilities that could be interpreted as a gen-eral cognitive ability for both games and tasks (Fig. 6) in line with a priori expectations duringthe design phase (Fig. 1). Via partial correlations (Fig. 7), we demonstrated that the sharedinformation from the main factor is insufﬁcient to explain a substantial proportion of eachcognitive ability’s observed agreement between task and game estimates. Each of our mea-sures, therefore, captures some of the nuances of the cognitive abilities beyond the dominantfactor.
### Input: What did the factor analysis reveal about the correlation between game-based cognitive measures and task-based measures in the study?
### Response: The factor analysis revealed a main factor for cognitive abilities that could be interpreted as a general cognitive ability for both games and tasks. This suggests a correlation between game-based cognitive measures and task-based measures. However, the shared information from the main factor was insufficient to explain a substantial proportion of each cognitive ability’s observed agreement between task and game estimates.

column3: While showing exciting potential for future applications, our current study is limited in thatpeople were only recruited to play the game once. In order to be considered as a potential clin-ical tool in one-off as well as longitudinal applications, a follow-up test-retest study is neededto assess the robustness of our cognitive ability estimates. In such a test-retest setup, we couldcontrol the time between playthroughs to neutralize learning effects and ensure all the gameshave been played in both playthroughs. It is not unreasonable to expect that we could achieveeven more consistent estimates by training models dependent on the playthrough number,compensating for learning effects due to the player familiarizing themselves with the tasks.
column4: Pedersen et al. - 2023 - Measuring Cognitive Abilities in the Wild Validat
column5:
