### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: While showing exciting potential for future applications, our current study is limited in thatpeople were only recruited to play the game once. In order to be considered as a potential clin-ical tool in one-off as well as longitudinal applications, a follow-up test-retest study is neededto assess the robustness of our cognitive ability estimates. In such a test-retest setup, we couldcontrol the time between playthroughs to neutralize learning effects and ensure all the gameshave been played in both playthroughs. It is not unreasonable to expect that we could achieveeven more consistent estimates by training models dependent on the playthrough number,compensating for learning effects due to the player familiarizing themselves with the tasks.
### Input: What limitations does the current study have and what steps could be taken in future studies to improve the robustness of cognitive ability estimates?
### Response: The current study is limited in that participants were only recruited to play the game once. This could potentially affect the robustness of the cognitive ability estimates. To improve the robustness of these estimates in future studies, a follow-up test-retest study could be conducted. This would involve controlling the time between playthroughs to neutralize learning effects and ensuring all the games have been played in both playthroughs. Additionally, more consistent estimates could potentially be achieved by training models dependent on the playthrough number, which would compensate for learning effects due to the player familiarizing themselves with the tasks.

column3: Another consideration regarding reliability is the fact that our validation population set exhib-ited a slightly different gender distribution compared to the overall data set (64% vs. 49%females overall, see Supplementary Information Section 9 for full demographic breakdown).In addition, our sample population, while diverse in age, comes primarily from Denmark.If we want to establish more general demographic norms than those we have collected onthe Danish population, we would naturally have to expand our recruitment efforts. As part ofthese efforts, we have prepared a Spanish translation of Skill Lab in addition to the Danishand English translations that already existed, with plans to launch the game internationally inthe future.

Text: Another consideration regarding reliability is the fact that our validation population set exhib-ited a slightly different gender distribution compared to the overall data set (64% vs. 49%females overall, see Supplementary Information Section 9 for full demographic breakdown).In addition, our sample population, while diverse in age, comes primarily from Denmark.If we want to establish more general demographic norms than those we have collected onthe Danish population, we would naturally have to expand our recruitment efforts. As part ofthese efforts, we have prepared a Spanish translation of Skill Lab in addition to the Danishand English translations that already existed, with plans to launch the game internationally inthe future.
### Input: What steps are being taken to establish more general demographic norms beyond the primarily Danish population sample in the study?
### Response: The steps being taken to establish more general demographic norms beyond the primarily Danish population sample in the study include expanding recruitment efforts and preparing a Spanish translation of Skill Lab. There are also plans to launch the game internationally in the future.

column3: An alternative to the computational approach we present in this paper of aggregating indicators from multiple tasks is testing the feasibility of predicting individual task indicators from game data, which is more in line with the conventional literature (Salthouse, 2011). However, predicting individual indicators is not very robust, so we made the pragmatic choice of deﬁning aggregated cognitive abilities measures (Bollen & Bauldry, 2011) while only combining task indicators associated with a cognitive ability in the theory to strengthen its interpretation. The eight accepted models already represent a broad, strong, and rapid testing battery. We exposed these choices to potential disconﬁrmation in the current work by examining their agreement across independent estimates; rejecting 3 of 13 while accepting 10. Since the dataset is open, it is also open for potential explorations of alternative choices. We have taken preliminary steps in this direction by pursuing a theory-driven approach, in which we only include the game indicators that are theoretically associated with a speciﬁc cognitive ability during the ﬁtting process. The results are qualitatively similar to the ones presented here but somewhat lower in quantitative effects as expected from a restricted model. Further work in this direction may help the iterative development toward games that are optimally suited for high-quality assessment of each ability.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: An alternative to the computational approach we present in this paper of aggregating indicators from multiple tasks is testing the feasibility of predicting individual task indicators from game data, which is more in line with the conventional literature (Salthouse, 2011). However, predicting individual indicators is not very robust, so we made the pragmatic choice of deﬁning aggregated cognitive abilities measures (Bollen & Bauldry, 2011) while only combining task indicators associated with a cognitive ability in the theory to strengthen its interpretation. The eight accepted models already represent a broad, strong, and rapid testing battery. We exposed these choices to potential disconﬁrmation in the current work by examining their agreement across independent estimates; rejecting 3 of 13 while accepting 10. Since the dataset is open, it is also open for potential explorations of alternative choices. We have taken preliminary steps in this direction by pursuing a theory-driven approach, in which we only include the game indicators that are theoretically associated with a speciﬁc cognitive ability during the ﬁtting process. The results are qualitatively similar to the ones presented here but somewhat lower in quantitative effects as expected from a restricted model. Further work in this direction may help the iterative development toward games that are optimally suited for high-quality assessment of each ability.
### Input: What is the alternative approach to aggregating indicators from multiple tasks as discussed in the paper and why was it not chosen?
### Response: The alternative approach to aggregating indicators from multiple tasks discussed in the paper is predicting individual task indicators from game data. This approach was not chosen because it is not very robust. Instead, the authors opted for a more pragmatic choice of defining aggregated cognitive abilities measures, combining only task indicators associated with a specific cognitive ability in the theory to strengthen its interpretation.

column3: In conclusion, the models developed through our work with Skill Lab illustrate the viability of a crowdsourcing approach in validating a cognitive assessment tool, which has several key implications. First, it allows scientists to create better human cognition models and test and validate cognitive abilities, potentially providing efﬁcient ways to scale insights into particular cognitive abilities and how they are related to solving problems (Woolley, Chabris, Pentland, Hashmi, & Malone, 2010). Second, we have generated a unique and open data set, which includes normative benchmarks, that can be used as a basis for other studies. Finally, Skill Lab allows normative data for diverse populations, cultures, and languages to be collected in the future, facilitating the much-needed broadening of the samples typically tested in psychological and social science studies (Henrich, Heine, & Norenzayan, 2010). An advantage of Skill Lab over traditional tests is that it is faster to play all six games once than to go through all the traditional cognitive tasks. Thus, the games could provide a low-cost self-administered test suitable for extensive deployment. This could be of great value to, for example, the psychiatric sector in which current cognitive test batteries are burdensome to administer (Baune et al., 2018), leading to cognitive impairments often going unrecognized (Groves, Douglas, & Porter, 2018; Jaeger, Berns, Uzelac, & Davis-Conway, 2006).

column5:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction: Use the following pieces of context to answer the users question.

Text: In conclusion, the models developed through our work with Skill Lab illustrate the viability of a crowdsourcing approach in validating a cognitive assessment tool, which has several key implications. First, it allows scientists to create better human cognition models and test and validate cognitive abilities, potentially providing efﬁcient ways to scale insights into particular cognitive abilities and how they are related to solving problems (Woolley, Chabris, Pentland, Hashmi, & Malone, 2010). Second, we have generated a unique and open data set, which includes normative benchmarks, that can be used as a basis for other studies. Finally, Skill Lab allows normative data for diverse populations, cultures, and languages to be collected in the future, facilitating the much-needed broadening of the samples typically tested in psychological and social science studies (Henrich, Heine, & Norenzayan, 2010). An advantage of Skill Lab over traditional tests is that it is faster to play all six games once than to go through all the traditional cognitive tasks. Thus, the games could provide a low-cost self-administered test suitable for extensive deployment. This could be of great value to, for example, the psychiatric sector in which current cognitive test batteries are burdensome to administer (Baune et al., 2018), leading to cognitive impairments often going unrecognized (Groves, Douglas, & Porter, 2018; Jaeger, Berns, Uzelac, & Davis-Conway, 2006).
### Input: What are the key implications of using a crowdsourcing approach in validating a cognitive assessment tool as illustrated by the models developed through work with Skill Lab?
### Response: The key implications of using a crowdsourcing approach in validating a cognitive assessment tool, as illustrated by the models developed through work with Skill Lab, include the ability for scientists to create better human cognition models and test and validate cognitive abilities. This could potentially provide efficient ways to scale insights into specific cognitive abilities and their relation to problem-solving. The approach also allows for the generation of a unique and open data set, including normative benchmarks, that can be used as a basis for other studies. Furthermore, Skill Lab allows for the collection of normative data for diverse populations, cultures, and languages in the future, facilitating a much-needed broadening of the samples typically tested in psychological and social science studies. An additional advantage is that Skill Lab is faster and less burdensome to administer than traditional cognitive tests, making it a low-cost, self-administered test suitable for extensive deployment, such as in the psychiatric sector.
